PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilisation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 187 citizens), Bjelke-Petersen (from 1,005 citizens) and Scott (from 164 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Abortion Clinic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned who have great concern for the protection of the unborn child, call upon the Government to reject the Vinson Enquiry recommendation that an Abortion Clinic be established in Canberra.
And your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will reject this recommendation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we strongly oppose the 'A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Jack Evans, because it will adversely affect sporting organisations and small businesses in the A.C.T., it reverses the onus of proof, and represents an unnecessary intrusion by Government into the private affairs of individuals and other groups.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Additional Capital Gains Taxes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showth: Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
They adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy:
The Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

Any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not 'windfall gains' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
The owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;
Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned have great concern for further development and research of the IVF program and express that we are against (Senator Harradine's) Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985. The Bill threatens the provisions of IVF as a treatment for infertility because it defines as prohibited experimentation; 1. Any manipulation of a relevant human embryo; 2. Any procedure undertaken on, or involving the use of a relevant human embryo; 3. Creating a relevant human embryo in anticipation that the development of the full human potential of the relevant human embryo will be interrupted.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will protect our interest into the further research of IVF and your petitioners as is duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Security
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The undersigned are convinced that an alliance, including full military co-operation, between Australian and the United States is indispensable to the defence security of the Australian Commonwealth; that every alliance involves co-operative arrangements of a practical nature; and that the following arrangements are indispensable to the effective conduct of ANZUS and any similar agreement, to wit; the reception of U.S. naval shipping (nuclear and non-nuclear) in Australian ports; the maintenance of the present US installations in Australia; reasonable co-operation by Australia in US missile testing programs.
Your Petitioners, therefore, pray the Senate, in Parliament assembled, that you will give this matter your earnest consideration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Grape Producing Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The financial plight of grape producers, their families and their respective local communities.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that-the Government act now during the 1985-86 Budget considerations to: Remove the sales tax impost on all Australian produced wine; make funds available for the establishment of an institution to administer the restructuring of the grape producing industry; place revenue raising imposts on all imported wine and wine spirit.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Indirect Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows that:
We, the undersigned electors, are deeply concerned at the possibility of an increase in indirect taxation currently being considered by the Government.
To pose a broadly based consumption tax would mean a proportionately greater burden on low income groups and worsen their already precarious and impoverished position.

Women who are supporting mothers, together with their children, are acknowledged as the largest single group forced to exist below the poverty line. As beneficiaries of an already inadequate government pension, their futures would be even more jeopardised if there were to be a change towards increased broadly based consumption taxation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal government not adopt the proposed shift towards increased indirect taxation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post-Secondary Education: Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

(i) That the reintroduction of fees would place at risk the access to tertiary education of Australian students from middle-income families, further disadvantage students from country areas, and restrict part-time enrolments, by imposing substantial financial burdens upon these students.

(ii) That the imposition of tertiary fees would most severely affect those students currently disadvantaged within our education system, and would have the effect of deterring students from lower-income families from entering tertiary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) That post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any category of Australian students.

(ii) That Australian youth be encouraged to enter tertiary education through both increased personal financial assistance and through the funding of tertiary education through other sources than the reintroduction of any 'user pays' principle.
(iii) That the Minister for Education immediately clarify the Government's attitude concerning the imposition of tertiary fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Frozen Pea Industry
PETITION.PARA: To: The Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled in Parliament: The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:

(1) Imports of frozen peas from New Zealand and elsewhere have increased from 4.8 per cent of the Australian market in 1979/80 to an estimated 20 per cent in 1984/85-from 2.2 million kgs. to 8.0 million kgs.

(2) As a result of these escalating imports, in 1985: Growers are faced with cuts of up to 30 per cent both in contract tonnages and prices; Hundreds of jobs in the processing industry will be lost, with many hundreds more under threat in downstream industries; Millions of dollars will be lost from sensitive regional and State economies.
Your petitioners therefore request that: The Australian Government:
(1) Reject the recommendation of the Industries Assistance Commission Interim Report on frozen peas that no assistance be provided to the industry.
(2) Support the proposals made by grower organisations and Trade Unions for import restrictions and other measures of support for the Australian Frozen Pea Industry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Darwin International Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
1. That we are deeply concerned that the redevelopment of the Darwin International Airport is not to continue on schedule.
2. That failure to complete the project will do great damage to the Northern Territory's, and Australia's, tourism industry.
3. That the north of the Northern Territory will be left with a totally inadequate airport to service its resident population.
4. That general aviation facilities and industry will be adversely affected by failure to continue with the redevelopment.
5. That the RAAF Base in Darwin will be hampered by failure to continue with the redevelopment, which could result in interference with effective defence procedures for the north of Australia.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure the Commonwealth stands by its commitment to complete the redevelopment of Darwin International Airport by the scheduled completion date of 1988.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Prices in Isolated Regions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we consider the Federal Government's petrol price increase will have a widespread and adverse effect on the people of the Northern Territory and other outback areas of Australia.
That the Territory's mining and pastoral industries will suffer as a result of the price increase.
That the Territory's tourism industry will suffer as a consequence of increased air fares flowing on from the petrol price rise.
That the already high cost of freight to Territory residents, business and industry will increase even further because of the fuel factor of freight charges.
That the price increase will generally disadvantage the people of the outback, to whom petrol powered vehicles and equipment are a necessity.

Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Federal Government to give further consideration to the people of the Northern Territory and other outback and isolated regions of Australia in the matter of this petrol price rise.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination Against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that ''States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women''.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26/1/85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operation of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.

Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It has been brought to my attention that in the cut and thrust of debate on the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill on Monday I made some comments about the permanent head of the Department of Veterans' Affairs which may be open to misinterpretation. After saying that I believed that it was unfair to attack the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) for the legislation as he was overseas, I made the point that one should not attack permanent heads in this place. I then made the comment that I would prefer not to see the present incumbent in that position. While I do not resile from that position, my attention has been drawn to a further sentence in my speech which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: He may be competent in other areas such as immigration or whatever, but in my view he is not competent in this area.

I was, of course, using the word 'competent' in the sense that it embraces suitability for the particular and specific position in the Department. I was not referring to intellectual capacity, integrity or competence in any other sense. As the record shows quite clearly, this person is a public servant who has distinguished himself in many positions of public trust. I certainly wish to remove any reflection on any aspect of his public service other than, in my view, the suitability of his personality to this particular portfolio.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1985STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I was speaking on this package of three education Bills which give supplementation, in the normal way, to make up for the cost increases in the schools area, in tertiary education and in the participation and equity program. They show no new initiative in education, no new idea, no creativity and, with the lack of any other initiative coming from the Government this year, they are a demonstration of what could be called a rolling on in a rut supplementation in this Government's approach to education. The only initiatives in education that have come from this Government since the election have been cuts in funding to every area of education. Now, over a two-year period, these cuts have raised particularly serious alarm in the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission report which was put before the Senate yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been wide coverage in the newspapers this morning of the serious situation that is described by Mr Hudson, the Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, and the Commission as a whole. The marginal supplementation that has been trumpeted as the additional resources given for tertiary education by this Government has in fact led to serious underresourcing of our universities and colleges.

First of all, however, I continue my remarks about the process of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill relating to the passing of money to schools through the States. I still believe that the initial targets that were set some 12 years ago as goals for resource levels in Australian schools have now been exceeded and well and truly achieved by the Commonwealth over these past 12 years. That has been the fundamental and primary goal of the Commonwealth's involvement in schools; that is, as advised by the Commonwealth Schools Commission, to supplement what the public has been providing, through taxation, to public and private schools in the States. The Commonwealth has been taking an additional initiative over these last 12 years to lift the level of resources in government and non-government schools so that they more suitably provide for the education of our children. The targets that were set have been achieved, and the question that is still in our minds on this side of the Senate is whether there ought to be a fundamental rethinking of the role of the Commonwealth with regard to schools and a fundamental rethinking with regard to the structure of the Schools Commission.

I believe that for the next decade and a half the question about schools, funded by whatever manner, is one of improving quality of outcome, quality of curricula, quality of teaching methodology and quality through in-service training of teachers. The teachers of Australia and the curricula which have been developed in a multitude of areas are to be commended, but there is room for improvement. The improvement that will come to the schools will not be quantitative. In the past decade, there has already been a 50 per cent increase in the real recurrent resources available to schools. We need to ensure that the very much increased financial resources for schools in Australia are put together and used to the best qualitative effect. I do not believe that in the existing format of the Commonwealth Schools Commission, or in the whole paraphernalia of the Bills before us-the States grants machinery Bills-we have the best way of achieving that aim.

A proposition on which I wish to elaborate further and which I have spoken about in this place in the last few years is that the Commonwealth initiative in schools be transferred to a quite different structure. I suggest that the Commonwealth should facilitate the coming together of representatives directly involved in education in the States to discuss curriculum matters, teacher development, the interface of teachers and schools with teacher training and tertiary education matters and the interface between graduates from schools and post-secondary education, be it in various areas of training, technical and further education or higher education. I think that would be the appropriate way for the Commonwealth to be involved with schools over the next 15 years or more.

There is no evidence that this Government has given that sort of fundamental look at the Commonwealth Schools Commission. I refer the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who is present in the chamber, to the Commonwealth Schools Commission annual report for 1984, which was tabled yesterday. Appendices to that report show changes in the definitions of the functions of the Schools Commission. I interpret those changes as superficial because the definitions are still full of phrases such as 'The Commission shall consult and co-operate with representatives of the States', or 'the Commission shall furnish information and advice to the Minister'. The members of the Commission are not involved in direct line implementation of programs and curricula; rather they are facilitators and advisers. Their information and advice to the Government is a duplication of what is happening in the States.

The approach to education that I would rather have in Australia is the approach that I believe a new government in this country would take; namely, setting up the alternative structure that I have proposed. The Commonwealth should set national goals for education and facilitate the appointment of representatives of the bodies actually responsible for education in the States-be they from departments of education or the private schools-to implement new programs that arise from research. The body to which they are appointed should be a national forum-it could be called the Australian Schools Commission-which is not directly a Commonwealth agency but rather a combined States agency. On this new body the sorts of programs that the national Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Council deal with now, and the priorities for developing national programs or ideas that could be injected into the education system to improve the actual practices in the States, would be decided by State representatives.

I note that last week Senator Macklin of the Australian Democrats criticised the razor gang Budget cuts that affected education in the Fraser Government period. In the same breath, he criticised the cuts of some $100m in the Keating mini-Budget of this month that will affect education. The Minister is right to raise an eyebrow at the fact that the cuts in education were only $73.4m, but when we add the cuts that relate to family allowances that have now been denied to tertiary students and the cuts in the subsidy for pre-school child care, in the global sense of provision for education, about $108m has this month been cut by the present Government in the area of education.

It is increasingly well known that whatever the promises of the Labor Government, the Keating mini-Budget has cut back on child care, pre-schools and on the much trumpeted initiative of the Labor Government-the participation and equity program. There have been direct cuts in the technical and further education capital program. The library element of the Commonwealth Schools Commission has been completely eliminated, and it will need to find money for libraries out of the general capital program. Many special purpose programs of the Schools Commission have been cut out. Indeed, there has been a considerable tightening of the eligibility criteria for student assistance under the tertiary education assistance scheme and for other student assistance programs. As we all know, and directly contrary to what Labor members were saying in opposition, there has been an enormous increase in visa fees and charges for overseas students in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will they save money on the student assistance programs? They never made that clear.

—The student assistance programs are still in a fog and the public, including tertiary students, do not know the full extent of these reduced eligibility decisions made in the mini-Budget. Senator Macklin, as a Democrat, will never be in a position of being in government, when a Budget has to be balanced. I disagree with his irresponsible and blanket approach to these matters, because I believe that education should have some share in the Budget reductions in order to cut back the deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: This series of decisions in the Keating mini-Budget this month has drawn back the curtain completely on the hypocrisy of the original promises and the apparent early momentum of education provision by the Labor Government. There are the same restrictions, cuts and lack of fulfilment of promises from this Government that so many students and persons in education circles were accusing the former Government of. This Government's performance is in enormous contrast to the promises which were irresponsibly made to gain votes and electoral support in the last two elections.

The problem is not, as Senator Macklin from the Democrats put it, that there are mini-Budgets, razor gangs or expenditure review committees. From time to time that is a responsible way for governments to make sure that the economy, particularly its own expenditure program, is within the restraints of what the country can afford. I also disagree with Senator Macklin when he said that there was no principled or argued basis for the Fraser Government's amalgamation of higher education institutions or, indeed, for the reforms that we sought at the time for the Curriculum Development Centre. There was an argued basis for those reforms. I am very interested to see in the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission report brought down yesterday for the 1986-87 spending programs recognition that the consolidation that has arisen from those amalgamations of colleges and universities in the Fraser Government period has led to a more rational and efficient use of the money that is available from the public for tertiary education. On the basis of that constructive outcome the Commission is now crying that the only marginal money which has been made available by the present Labor Government is beginning now to be seen as being counterproductive to the overall quality of higher education's provisions for students. My regret about the Curriculum Development Centre decision during the Fraser Government period was that we required 50 per cent of the money for the CDC to come from the States. The States reneged on that offer and I believe that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to go home on Friday or are you just taking up everybody's time? You are just filibustering.
—You are just filibustering.

—Senator Grimes and Senator Ryan say that I am filibustering. They are not happy that I am criticising the lack of initiative by the Labor Government in regard to education. This Government has no ability to do anything other than cut. It has denied the promises to which it committed itself before the last two elections. Senator Grimes and Senator Ryan are also smarting because the Bills which are before us can be rightly described as indicating that this Government is in a rut on education matters. In the five minutes or so remaining to me I want to say that the Curriculum Development Centre proposal that remains--
—You are the most self-indulgent senator in this place. Everybody else tries to co-operate, but not you.

—Senator Grimes continues to object to my ability to speak in this place on education matters. I say to Senator Grimes that the only speeches I am making in this Parliament this week are on these education matters. We have all forgone the ability to speak on many issues. Some 30 different legislative packages are before the Senate this week. As the final speaker on these Bills-there were only three speakers from the Opposition-I will not be sat down by Senator Grimes. The important point I want to make is that the Curriculum Development Centre would have been reformed in the Fraser Government period along the lines about which I was speaking earlier if the Commonwealth had made a 75 per cent or 80 per cent contribution to the costs of that body. The essential reform which was sought and which Liberal senators still seek is that the Curriculum Development Council be a body made up of State representatives, including people from private schools, so that the actual implementers, the persons who actually operate schools, come together in order to gain from a national view of curriculum development and improvements.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is still wrong that the Commonwealth, which is living in a world of its own and taking a unilateral initiative, chooses the persons who make up the Curriculum Development Council or the Commonwealth Schools Commission. With only some token representatives, as it were, from the State systems-the actual implementers-those bodies manage to develop some quite worthy ideas. But those worthy ideas, in terms of improving education in this country, often remain on a shelf. They are not integrated into the week by week, month by month, year by year programs for which the State departments and the private schools are responsible. That is why I believe that if the Commonwealth injected even some 80 per cent of the cost of that process towards what I would re-call an Australian schools commission and an Australian curriculum development council it would facilitate the coming together of representatives from the States to achieve those programs.

I am not quibbling about whether the Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Council are involved in improving language education. As the initiator of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on a national language policy, I am distressed about the way we are proceeding with the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill when considering the teaching not only of the broad courses of English but also English as a second language; the various community language programs; the needs of Aboriginal schools curriculum; the improved presentation of maths curricula; the best methods of teaching children in primary schools how to read, where there have been recent reports of disquiet amongst educators that we do not have assured, stable foundations for methodology; the many worthy programs in special education developed by the Commonwealth Schools Commission; the country schools program, which takes account of the special needs of country children because they are remote from cities and do not have the same general access to advantages; and even when considering the priority projects. In all of these, in general, worthy matters I am distressed about the way we are proceeding with the Bill. I am concerned about the whole structure and fabric of the Commonwealth's involvement in schools. Often worthy curriculum ideas are left on the shelf and are not implemented because they are developed by an unhinged Commonwealth body, a body which is not sufficiently integrated with the implementers of curriculum and schools programs in the States. It is in this respect that I believe we need to look fundamentally at the structures of the Commonwealth's involvement in schools.

While the Commonwealth Schools Commission has been involved mostly in resources distribution, as well as in these national initiatives, including curriculum development, it also ought to be involved more directly in the interface of teacher education, that is, with teachers in schools, and with staff development programs. This is an area for which the present Government has made less provision and in which it has introduced real cuts. Given the Commonwealth's fundamental responsibility for higher education, including its responsibility for teachers in training, there ought to be a deliberate priority to see how Commonwealth initiatives can assist teacher education and staff development generally to be more applicable to the actual needs of schools.

I put it to the Senate that when debating these Bills every six months, we should not just accept that the mechanism for passing money on for schools assistance through the States should remain in a rut, without initiative, and without considering the problems of duplication and good work remaining unapplied. Rather we should consider what the fundamental approach ought to be. Under the Education Council, which is the council of all State Ministers and in which the Commonwealth Minister has a primary role, there ought to be an Australian schools commission. The curriculum initiatives I have been speaking of would thereby be entirely the responsibility not of the Commonwealth Minister but much more directly of the State Ministers and the implementers of programs in the States. We should not continue year by year to see Bills introduced in this form which only repeat a process that I believe is not serving Australian schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating three cross-supplementation education Bills-the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1985, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1985 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1985. These Bills are presented automatically at this time of the year to fulfil the Government's undertaking to give indexation and cross-supplementation on the full range of Commonwealth education programs.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Government recognises that these Bills provide an opportunity for senators to make general remarks about education, I must place on record some correction to some of the misapprehensions that Senator Teague, the last honourable senator to speak on the Opposition side, seems to be under. Senator Teague asked why there was not anything new, different, original, creative or exciting in the cross-supplementation Bills and seemed to suggest that it was very boring for the Government to introduce supplementation to the full range of its programs. That sort of questioning suggests that Senator Teague really does not understand the process of supplementing expenditures in the area of education. The answer to Senator Teague's question is that the whole range of Commonwealth programs-the ongoing programs, the innovative programs and the creative programs-are all receiving supplementation under this package of Bills. These Bills simply add to the money already allocated for the full gamut of Commonwealth programs.

I do not intend to take up the time of the Senate pointing out what those programs are. The Commonwealth Schools Commission, the Curriculum Development Centre Council, the Tertiary Education Commission and various other areas in my portfolio continually issue reports and accounts of programs that the Commonwealth is engaged in. If Senator Teague addressed himself to those programs he would find that all of the areas he nominated during the course of his remarks-Aboriginal education, mathematics education and education for multicultural societies-are being addressed through a range of programs across the portfolio. Senator Teague would find no lack of innovation, regeneration, new ideas and the continuation of successful old ideas were he to address himself to the program that these funds are devoted to.

Senator Teague also seemed to think that there was some lack of participation by State and school authorities in the work of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. Again, this shows that Senator Teague is not familiar with the way that the Commission operates or with the way that the Curriculum Development Centre Council operates. Rather than give Senator Teague a lesson in these matters, I again suggest that he avail himself of the information coming from these agencies of the Commonwealth or perhaps arrange to speak to some of the very helpful departmental officers here on my left who would be very able to set his mind at rest with regard to the extent of co-operation we have established with State agencies, non-government schools authorities, experts, community and union representatives and the full range of interest groups in the community who concern themselves with the implementation of education.

During the course of his remarks Senator Peter Baume wanted me to admit in reply that there had been a cut to the participation and equity program. I will not say that I am happy to admit it because I think every senator in this place knows that I am far from happy that the Government found it necessary to make such a cut. There has been a cut in the sense that the amount appropriated for 1986 is to be halved. There will be in the vicinity of $40m rather than $80m spent on this program next year. That is half what we originally intended to spend next year. In that sense, if Senator Baume wants me to describe it as a cut, I will not argue with him. However, what needs to be said to give the full picture is that the remainder of the money, the other $40m, will be appropriated in the following year so that over a four- year period the level of funds going into the participation and equity program will be as originally intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to the people in the sector.

—Since Senator Baume sought it, I am making this correction for his benefit. He wants me to use the word 'cut', and if it will satisfy him I will use the word 'cut'. Obviously the program has been cut back from the way we originally intended to fund it. The overall amount of funding going into the program will be as originally intended but the funds will be spread over four years instead of three years. As we will have numerous opportunities to debate this matter further, I will not take up the time of the Senate now.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some points to be made in reply to both Senator Baume and Senator Macklin, who commented last evening about the extent of unmet demand in higher education. Let me be quite clear, there is unmet demand in higher education and the Commonwealth is doing what it can to ease that unmet demand. However, the unmet demand is not at the level claimed by Senator Baume and Senator Macklin in the debate last night. They claimed-I am not quite sure which honourable senator made the specific claim-that the estimate for unmet demand for higher education in 1985 was in the vicinity of 30,000 places. This is not the case. I draw honourable senators' attention to the supplementary report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission tabled in the Senate yesterday. That report, which has the most up to date assessment of the unmet demand, puts it at the level of 10,000 places. Again, I am not happy that we have a shortfall of that extent. Certainly, I would not claim that that is a satisfactory state of affairs and that there is no need for the Commonwealth to take further action. There clearly is. However, if we are to be successful and effective in securing additional funds for tertiary education, our arguments need to be based on facts and not on a very extravagant embroidering of those facts.

It is also the case, of course, that there has been a considerable increase in the number of tertiary places provided since the Hawke Government came to office. For 1985-87 there will be an increase of 15,000 places on 1984 levels. In fact, the Government has provided for an enrolment growth by 1987 of some 23,000 places on 1983 levels. This is a quite dramatic increase in numbers compared to the previous situation and ought to be recognised as such. It will be my intention to seek further funding to meet some of that unmet demand. However, it is only right and fair that the dramatic increase in the number of places available under our Government be acknowledged in the course of these debates.

In regard to academic and non-academic jobs within higher education, obviously, as a result of the increased funding we have been able to make available, there will be increases in employment opportunities for both academics and general staff within institutions. Those increases, which will mean some 2,500 new jobs by 1987, constitute the first significant increase in academic jobs since the Commission was established in 1977. Because of the tenor of the debate last evening, I think I should place on record the fact that during the previous Government's term in office funding for the higher education sector was actually cut by 5 per cent in real terms between 1977 and 1983, despite the fact that enrolments increased over the same period by more than 46,000.

What I can say in summing up is that the funds our Government has been able to devote to higher education and to schools education represent a considerable increase on what had happened under the previous Administration. It is certainly the case that there are unmet demands. It is certainly the case that there are areas, particularly in schools, in which the quality of education is a matter of concern, and it is one which we are addressing. Again I remind Senator Teague, who was interested to know what approach the Government was going to take in regard to this matter, that the Government now has under consideration the report of the Karmel Quality of Education Review Committee. I hope to make that report available in the next couple of weeks. I am sure Senator Teague and other honourable senators who take an interest in education will find that a useful basis for further discussion and debate about ways of ensuring that the Commonwealth's contribution to education is one which achieves improved outcomes in terms of quality and not simply improved resources in terms of greater input.

The Bills are not contentious. As I said, they are merely cost supplementation Bills. There will be further opportunities in this place for more general debates on education matters, so at this point I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: — Clause 6 of the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill amends section 31 of the principal Act to include the Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in those to whom the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) may delegate powers. I ask the Minister: Is this to facilitate directly what no doubt was foreshadowed by the Chairman in yesterday's Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission report, particularly the recommendations regarding technical and further education, that Mr Hudson be appointed to convene an inquiry into the fundamentals of TAFE, and the Commonwealth's contribution to TAFE? The report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission calls for Mr Hudson to look at the effectiveness of existing Commonwealth TAFE grants, the appropriate role of the Commonwealth, the extent of accountability which the States should provide to the Commonwealth and the ability of TAFE to meet strategic national goals. I agree with the need for those four assessments to be made. I am only asking: Does this clause specifically empower, by delegation, Mr Hudson as Chairman to become involved in the participation and equity program aspects of TAFE in regard to that foreshadowed review?

—The answer to Senator Teague's question is no. This provision does not specifically involve Mr Hudson as Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in any particular review. However, what it does is bring this legislation in line with the States grants Acts which enable me, as Minister, to delegate either to a full time commissioner or to a chairman. In respect of the participation and equity program, this situation will now prevail. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has been involved in the participation and equity program all along because about half of the funds go through technical and further education and are distributed on recommendations of the Technical and Further Education Council. Therefore, there has been a role for the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. Although it may well be that what Senator Teague expects will eventuate, that is, that Mr Hudson may become more involved in this program, it would not be specifically as a result of this. This clause simply enables delegations from me to the Chairman as well as a full time commissioner in the same way as the States Grants (Schools Assistance) and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Acts already provide.
—In summary, is this virtually just an oversight; it gives more flexibility in such delegations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill 1985 is a disgraceful Bill. It sets out in stark relief the reality of the Hawke Government's perception of its own accountability. It perceives itself as accountable to the trade union movement, not to the people of Australia. Clearly, the people of Australia have not yet gained a perception of the enormity and disgrace of this piece of legislation. It will be our job today, in the course of this debate, to make it clearer to the Australian people what this Government is trying to perpetrate upon them. It is not simply an attack upon the State of Queensland; it is an attack upon the rights of all Australians. It is that which we will have to face. Central to the debate on this Bill is the issue of accountability. First and foremost, the accountability of the trade unions; secondly, the accountability of employers; and thirdly, the accountability of governments. However, if this Bill is passed it will eliminate accountability in each of those areas within the electricity industry. Unions will no longer be accountable to either State industrial commissions or their State communities. State governments will no longer be accountable for industrial relations within their borders for the operation of their own electricity authorities. This legislation clearly reveals the craven submission of the Hawke socialist Government to the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill clearly reveals that the famous accord between the Hawke socialist Government and the trade union movement is a dual-edged sword. Not only does it purport to enable the Government to check wage growth-the reality of that situation is very questionable as we are seeing every day-but it also enables the union movement to make demands upon the Government in return for support for the accord. The fact that the Hawke Labor Government is prepared to go as far as it has in proposing this legislation clearly illustrates just how beholden it is to the trade union movement, particularly expressed through the Australian Council of Trade Unions. This legislation clearly indicates that this Government has taken the old adage of government of the people, by the people, for the people and rewritten it to mean government of the unions, by the unions, for the unions. The Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill which we are debating today will--

TALK.START.PARA: —Gee, you're good, Tony!

—I am glad that the Minister recognises that at last. This Bill relies on a very liberal interpretation of the Commonwealth's industrial powers as set out in the Constitution. Section 51, placitum (xxxv)-I will read it for the benefit of Senator Ray-states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:--
Conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State:

Clearly, the Queensland industrial dispute does not literally fall within the ambit of that section. It is a State industrial dispute. However, by serving a fictitious, artificial log of claims in another State, the Electrical Trades Union of Australia has created a paper dispute, which has allowed the Hawke Government to take this step today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every dispute under the Act is a paper dispute.

—Senator Childs intervenes, but he knows very well that this is a procedure which is called into play so often-a paper way of creating a dispute across State borders. He knows that. Yet we have Senator Walsh in this place every day claiming that paper taxation agreements should be wiped out and that if they are upheld by the High Court of Australia, the High Court is wrong. If the same point is taken against these types of paper arrangements, no action against them is considered to be inviolate. That is absolutely outrageous. The double standards of this Government are quite plain for all to see these days, and they are growing more and more.

SPEECH.PARA: There is little doubt that section 51, sub-section (XXXV) was not intended by those who drafted the Constitution to cover this kind of manipulation of the legal system. It is deplorable that a Labor government and the unions can conspire to take action which ignores the spirit of the Constitution and seeks to override legitimate State interests. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said in his second reading speech:
From the outset the Government expressed its strong opposition to this industrial campaign.

A study of the Minister's answers to questions in the House of Representatives on that matter does not in any way support that statement. Time and again Mr Willis was asked by the Opposition to state the Government's position on the industrial action and the subsequent blockade in Queensland. Each time he took the opportunity to criticise harshly the Queensland Government, which was acting within its constitutional powers. Never once did he express strong opposition to the outrageous industrial campaign of the ETU. By his lack of condemnation of that action he could be seen to be supporting the campaign, rather than opposing it.

In his second reading speech the Minister provided a background to the Queensland dispute. He did that purportedly to allow judgment to be made of the Queensland Government's handling of the dispute. What followed then was either an attempt to rewrite history, which this Government appears to be doing in the whole area of industrial relations, or merely a substantiation of what Oscar Wilde once said about history-that it was all gossip. Clearly, the one-sided account is favourable to the Hawke Government and unfavourable to the Queensland Government. That is the cheap politics of this Bill.

There are just two points on which the Opposition agrees with the Government in relation to this matter. Those are: First, that the original dispute developed from a long-standing disagreement between the power unions and the South East Queensland Electricity Board over the use of contract labour by the Board; secondly, that late last year the ETU placed a ban upon work performed by contractors employed by SEQEB. Those are the only two points-and they are points of fact-upon which we have agreement with this Government. In the course of his remarks in his second reading speech, the Minister did not state the other facts of this matter. He did not say that the dispute arose over the issue of whether the SEQEB had the right to organise its work force and its work programs so as to achieve the greatest efficiency possible in the provision of electricity for the consumers of Queensland. Obviously that was an objective of great potential benefit to the people of Queensland. The cheaper the electricity in that State, the better the economy of that State. Conveniently, also, the Minister did not state that no job-not one job-was at threat as a result of the proposal put down by the SEQEB. Not one job was at stake. The Queensland Government's action provided extra benefits for all the people of Queensland by way of the provision of electricity. This Bill stands to make electricity in Queensland more expensive. The Commonwealth Government would rather have that, apparently.

In an attempt to gain monopolistic control of the workers in the industry, the Electrical Trades Union took exception to the authority's right to use contract labour. Over the following three months the union rejected no fewer than six recommendations and three orders of the Queensland Industrial Commission to resume work. The union urged its workers to defy the Industrial Commission's rulings and engage in illegal industrial blackmail to threaten the whole electricity generation systems in Queensland. The prolonged power blackouts caused by the union resulted in hundreds of thousands of people being thrown out of work, threatened the continued viability of small businesses throughout the State and caused major disruptions to the whole industrial fabric of the State.

The Minister in his second reading speech in the other place attempted to lay blame on the Queensland Government for this state of affairs, when it clearly resulted directly from the illegal industrial blackmail of the union itself. What was the union trying to do? It was trying to gain undemocratic monopoly control of the workers of the industry. The reverse of the Minister's statement is in fact the real case. Rather than causing the dispute, it was the Queensland Government which solved the dispute. The prevailing industrial anarchy which was then in place as a result of the unions having taken their action was resolved and Queensland's electrical power was restored by the action of the Government of the State of Queensland. Responsible workers from the electricity board returned to work, sacked workers were provided with the opportunity to re-apply for jobs, and many did so. Queensland has had its power supply assured and safeguarded by a government which is prepared to take action and to continue to safeguard that supply.

Following the resolution of the dispute and the restoration of power supplies came the next black phase in this saga. The Australian Council of Trade Unions, in the fastness of Melbourne, decided that it would conduct a blockade against the State of Queensland. It imposed bans on the handling of mail by employees of the Australian Postal Commission. Trans Australia Airlines and other airlines halted their services to Queensland, as did shipping and other transport operators. This action was taken because the ACTU and the unions involved in the blockade were outraged at the action of the Queensland Government which assured power supplies to Queensland and put the trade union in its place. The ACTU did not stop at a blockade, but also drew up a disgraceful hit list of companies which were subjected to special persecution by the union movement. Those companies were being singled out merely because they were operating within the State of Queensland. That is the kind of bully boy tactics which we see and with which Government members are so familiar.

The Queensland Government did not set aside the interests of its 2,500,000 residents and did not back down in the face of that industrial blackmail. It stood firm and truly represented the best interests of the people of Queensland. Thus, so far as the union movement was concerned, the dispute was an absolute stalemate, there was little hope for further action by unions to shift the Queensland Government, and the unions were so locked into an impossible position that they had to be extricated from it. They could seek a general strike or they could simply issue an order to Bob Hawke to fix it for them. Clearly, because the Australian Labor Party is so beholden to the trade union movement, the latter course would have produced an automatic response in favour of the unions. Like a puppet on a string, the Government danced to the tune of the ACTU; hence this legislation today.

This Bill, which seeks to hand over to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission power to deal with industrial matters, relates to the Queensland electrical industry, not the national industry. The real motive behind this legislation is an attack on Queensland. It is an extension of the trade unions' action in blockading the State of Queensland. It is not a way of solving the problems of that State; it is a way of increasing the problems for the people of Queensland. This intervention, which some might describe as divine, certainly was not unexpected by the union movement. The ACTU clearly had a large part to play in both the drafting of the legislation and calling a halt--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your evidence for that?

—I will come to that in a moment. The ACTU also had a part to play in calling a halt to the blockade, which had already proven so worthless and so hopeless. The reason why it was worthless is that the people of Queensland were behind the State Government in taking the action that it did over this dispute. Senator Robert Ray asked me for evidence that the union movement had some part to play in the drafting of the legislation. This was reported in the Australian of 16 May, where it was stated that Ian Court-who I believe is the negotiating head or whatever of the ACTU on this matter-checked the Bill a week before it was presented to Parliament.
—He didn't draw it up, did he?

—Come on! This only further exemplifies the ties that this Government has with the union movement and the fact that it is always willing to place the interests of the trade union movement ahead of the people of Australia. The lead-up to and the style of this Government's handling of the introduction of this legislation are reminiscent of Hawke's pattern when he was President of the ACTU. We all remember how he used to charge in and bludgeon the community into accepting union demands while he was President of the ACTU. He has done it again today by this extension of union power and by using the Parliament in such a disgraceful manner. On this occasion the heavy-handed style of the Government's actions which favour one side will achieve little except more problems in Queensland and more bitterness in Queensland. Yet this comes from the man who was to bring Australia together.
—He can't even bring the Labor Party together.

—As Senator Chaney has said, he cannot even bring the Labor Party together. We know how the Labor Party is split into four parts. The Labor Party continues to parade itself as the Australian Labor Party when it is nothing more than a coalition of four separate parties, all split even within themselves. In presenting this legislation the Minister has also willingly, but wrongly, raised the expectations of the unemployed workers of the South East Queensland Electricity Board. The Ministers, in touting this Bill, suggested that it would be the saviour of the former linesmen.
—Listen to the lobotomy lobby.

—I would like Government senators to listen because they probably have been misled by their Ministers on this. It is simply not the case that Queensland linesmen will have their jobs guaranteed by this legislation. The reason for that is quite simple: The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission simply does not have any power to reinstate workers and this Bill will not give it any power to do so. An absolute fraud is being perpetrated on the poor, unfortunate, unemployed workers in Queensland, who are being told that this Bill somehow will fix their problems. It will not. I understand that the Bill will be passed because the Australian Democrats apparently are supporting this nonsense. It is typical of the Democrats that they have no concern for the real interests of the community but only for those sectional interests from which they are trying to gather together support for the next election.
—You don't seem to like them very much.
—I have noticed that Senator Grimes does not have much feeling for them, either.
—We have got you all worried.

—We are worried? I will now sum up the main points of objection to this legislation. This Bill represents a gross intrusion into the rights of Queensland to secure its own constitutionally sound solutions in the industrial relations area. We can see that quite clearly, and I think I have demonstrated that perfectly well today.
—Hear, hear!

—Thank you very much. This Bill has been conceived by the Government to secure a face-saving solution for the ACTU, which has been pursuing actions with very little grass roots support. That has been evidenced by the overwhelming support for the Queensland Government. I believe a gallup poll showed something like 80 per cent support for the Queensland Government's actions, and that support has been confirmed time and time again by our own personal connections with people in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats will support this legislation because they have received two assurances from the ACTU. The first is that the unions will accept the outcome of arbitration. How often do they ever do that? In the course of arbitration already conducted in Queensland, six times they would not accept the outcome, and they refused to obey a further three orders made by the courts in Queensland. How can we accept their assurances? We cannot. The Democrats, of course, can accept anything that gets them off some kind of hook. The second assurance they have been given is that the arbitration and conciliation will proceed without further industrial action. I suppose we have to accept that the Democrats are naive, but in fact it is absolutely stupid for them to accept that point of view. Obviously they have a very narrow set of views on this whole matter. The Democrats are concerned only, apparently, with winning what they believe to be fringe voters in Queensland. They are prepared to deny the rights of all other Australians by allowing this legislation to pass the Parliament, in order to gather up a few crumbs of votes in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the trade unions? Come on, be realistic.

—Senator Evans knows what I am talking about. The Democrats are prepared to put at risk the affairs of all Australians, and that is something they ought now to contemplate before they vote on this legislation. I hope they will.
—Tell us who the fringe voters are.

—Senator Georges knows all about them; perhaps Senator Childs should discuss it with him. Like the Australian Labor Party, the Democrats are taking the unions' side and, of course, the unions' word on this. It is not just a simple nudge nudge, wink wink type of relationship. They are submitting abjectly to the power of the trade union movement. The Democrats join with Government senators in doing that. Perhaps the Democrats ought to have some regard for the views of one of their senior members, Mr Lance Milne, who is a Democrat member of the Legislative Council in South Australia. He differs from many Democrats. He is not one of your armchair debaters. At least he has had very long and considerable experience in the business world. He is a chartered accountant and, therefore, has a great deal of experience in these matters. The Canberra Times of 27 May reports that he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The continued push towards Federal awards is fine for New South Wales and Victoria but it is gradually dismantling the industrial base of the smaller States.

I believe that is a very sound summary of what this legislation is all about. It is about dismantling the industrial bases of the smaller States. I see that that strikes home amongst Government senators. Senator Elstob, Senator Aulich, Senator Foreman and even Senator McKiernan and Senator Maguire who are from the smaller States know that that is right. They should be on their feet today claiming that there has been an attack on their States' interests. Where are they? They have cravenly submitted to the power of the trade union movement. We do not expect to see them stand up for their States. We do not expect to see him stand up for South Australia, Tasmania or Western Australia, and not at all for Queensland. Senator Colston will not stand up for Queensland. All they are going to do is to fall into line when the trade unions call the tune. That is where they stand. That is what this legislation is about. We commend to all the Democrats Mr Lance Milne's words. Senator Jack Evans is leaving this place on 30 June. Perhaps he does not care any more about what is going to happen to the rest of Australia. Perhaps it is not in his interests even to contemplate that. All he is concerned about is gathering some kind of reputation among some kinds of voters at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you that the honourable senator is attributing disreputable reasons for my stance on this position. I ask you to have him withdraw that allegation.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call Senator Messner.

—I conclude by imploring the Democrats to reconsider their position. I ask them very sincerely to consider the words of their famous leader, Mr Lance Milne, in South Australia, who is well known in the South Australian business community and, indeed, has connections right across the length and breadth of the industrial structure of Australia. He knows what he is talking about.
—Who, John?

—Mr Lance Milne in South Australia, who says that this legislation will destroy the industrial bases of the smaller States. Senator Evans and his Party can do something about that. If they refuse to do something about it today they stand condemned by the people of Australia for their inaction in seeking to preserve the rights of all Australians which this outrageous piece of legislation is seeking to destroy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Does the honourable senator seek leave to make a personal explanation?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dear, oh dear.

—The mouth from the south is at it again. Senator Messner, during his speech, stated quite clearly words to the effect that I would not stand up for Queensland. That is absolute rot. I have been here for as long as has Senator Messner. I have represented the State of Queensland. Like him, I have been re-elected from time to time. I have been re-elected because I represent Queensland. The statement that he made is totally incorrect.
—I call Senator Georges and I trust that he will be heard in the quiet in which Senator Messner was heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not care if I am not so heard because no interjection from the other side is likely to confuse me. Before I commence my remarks in support of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill 1985, I wish to comment on the speech made by Senator Messner. This legislation before us involves a serious matter. It concerns the livelihood of many people. Senator Messner managed to reduce it to a charade, possibly because, in fairness to Senator Messner, he does not properly understand either the purpose of the legislation or the situation existing in Queensland. It would have been better for the Opposition's case if he had not entered into the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been very close to the events that have occurred recently in Queensland and in a way have suffered the penalty of the legislation which has been imposed upon not only the workers in the industrial movement and the electricity industry but also all other Queenslanders. What has occurred in Queensland because of an industrial dispute is a gross over-reaction which will have far-reaching consequences for the industrial and conciliation institutions of Australia. The purpose of this legislation is to take out of the Queensland arena and away from the Queensland legislation those workers who have been seriously disadvantaged. I do not say that the legislation is the best legislation that we could have, but it is the only way in which the situation in Queensland can be met without further confrontation. Once we get out of the-shall I term it-exaggerations that developed during the dispute, once we get past the confrontation of an industrial dispute, we get to the point where the parties have to consider coming together in a conference, to forget the errors on both sides and to come to a solution which is to the benefit not only of the parties concerned but of all of the people of the State concerned. That is not what has happened.

What has happened in Queensland has been the passing through the Queensland Parliament of legislation which on even the scantest scrutiny is horrific. It imposes upon those who work within the electricity industry conditions which no reasonable person would be prepared to accept. It has forced people in the industry to return to work under conditions that can be described only as disgraceful. Many men who have found themselves in intolerable economic conditions have had to go back to work, against their will and against the opposition of their fellow workers, and accept conditions that are considerably worse than the conditions under which they were previously employed. That was a punishment that was inflicted upon them as a condition of their returning to work. I, and many other Queenslanders, in spite of what Senator Messner says, find that very difficult to accept. The legislation was passed through a parliament which, in effect, has become an institution that we recognise as not having a Westminster system but a one-party system inflicted upon the people of Queensland by an electoral system which reinforces the National Party of Australia, which is in government with the support of a couple of renegade Liberals.

Legislation which is at the base of this dispute, this confrontation, which this legislation seeks to solve, was forced through the Queensland Parliament in a few hours. It would not have been necessary to bring down this legislation if the Bjelke-Petersen Government had decided to confer, as recommended by its own Industrial Commission, whose advice it rejected. It set up another tribunal so that it would not have to submit to the determination of that Commission which recommended a return to work. If it were not for the Bjelke-Petersen Government changing the rules, that Commission could have ordered a reinstatement.

I have spoken about the men who found it necessary to go back under those conditions, but let me now talk about the men who have been displaced. There are still 800 men-800 families-who are the victims of the failure of the Queensland Government to--

TALK.START.PARA: —They can go back tomorrow.

—I am sorry; they cannot go back tomorrow, and I will explain why in a moment. If the Government had been prepared to come to the conference table many problems would have been solved. Let us look at the method of dismissal of these men and its consequences to them all. I am not talking about a few of them; I am talking about all the men who suffered as a result of this confrontation in Queensland. They were dismissed and not one of the privileges to which they were entitled flowed to them due to the nature of their dismissal. They were men who had worked in the industry for 19 years; some for longer, and some who were a mere six months away from retirement. They had given all their skills and, if I might say so, all their loyalty to that industry because it was, until this point, a good and well run industry and one equal to any in Australia. But those men lost up to $80,000 or $100,000 and any entitlements were stripped from them without any consideration. The ruthless Premier of Queensland said: 'That is your fault. That is it; finish; no chance; no reconciliation; no consideration and no reinstatement'.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at this dispute we begin to suspect the motives behind it because the Queensland Government, on the advice of one Wayne Gilbert, the Manager of the South East Queensland Electricity Board, reorganised SEQEB's work force at the expense of its employees. The dispute started well before January of this year; it goes back to last year. I am not certain whether the role of the Electrical Trades Union of Australia in this is one that can at all times be supported, nevertheless the arrangement was that some level of contract labour would be acceptable-one per cent of the budget. That was understandable because in an industry such as the electricity industry, and some other industries, certain peaks are reached momentarily and have to be dealt with but as they are not permanent arrangements some level of contract labour is acceptable, and I believe the agreement in this case was one per cent. It is fairly obvious that Mr Gilbert had other arrangements. He had in mind the restructuring of the whole industry based on a substantial level of contract labour. This is an industry that needs extreme skill and care, because it is a dangerous industry. Care and consideration are needed in maintaining it. Mr Gilbert therefore seized upon the first opportunity, as did the Government, to thrash the ETU and to reorganise the work force.

I return to Senator Walters's interjection that the workers could go back if they wished to. One of the first things I did when I became involved, well after the dispute, was to go to see the Electricity Commissioner in Queensland. I made an appointment on behalf of Queensland senators. He said that he was not prepared to see a delegation-that it would have to go to the Minister-but that he was prepared to see me, a person who had been employed in the electricity industry before becoming a member of parliament. I knew many of the men who worked in the Commission. I spent half an hour with Mr Galway and we discussed all these matters concerning reinstatement. He said: 'There is no longer any place for any more men. We have sufficient. It has been the policy of the SEQEB for some time to increase the level of contract labour'. He said: 'One hundred and sixty seven men have returned of their own volition and have been employed under the conditions that we have set'. They signed a statutory declaration and did a number of other things and accepted less favourable conditions. He said that there were 160 new employees, that some 200 contractors had been employed by the Commission and that some 400 workers had not been originally affected by the dispute. So in effect the Commission had virtually 1,000 employees, 400 below what I considered to be the work force necessary to maintain the system effectively and safely in Queensland. I asked whether there was any chance of reinstating the men and he said that he could not see it. I asked: 'How about the contractors?'. It was at that stage that he told me that the SEQEB had for some time had a policy of increasing the number of contractors and that he could not see how that could be changed. So, in effect, there were no jobs left for the 800 men still affected.

Let me get back to the fact that the SEQEB this year will be able to balance its books using the $15m to $20m of superannuation payments made by the employer which should have flowed to the employees but did not. When we consider the enormity of that we see that it was time for some conference, some conciliation, but the answer from the Premier's Department was: 'Not on'. I spoke to Mr Lester, the Minister who is responsible for this area. Let me talk to honourable senators about Mr Lester. I have had experience with Mr Lester before. His electorate includes Moranbah. The coal miners had a dispute in Moranbah concerning rental subsidies. It was a major dispute. The coal miners were out for 11 weeks and Mr Lester was on their side. I was asked to go to Moranbah to address a meeting and to take part in a march at Moranbah when marches of that sort were prohibited in Queensland. As I marched down the street in Moranbah I looked around and saw a person about my size, with hair the same length as mine and wearing a hat, which I do not. I asked: 'Who is that?'. I was told that it was Mr Lester. Mr Lester, the Minister who is taking such a harsh position against these workers, at that time was prepared to march in an illegal march in Moranbah in support of the coal miners. I asked him how he could reconcile the two positions. He said: 'It's different'. But the circumstances are not different; they are exactly the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had a permit.

—There was no permit; I know. There was no permit at the time. One did not have to have a permit in Moranbah. The only place in which one had to have a permit to march, to breathe or to amplify one's voice, was Brisbane. If one did not have a permit to do those things there, one was arrested-as people were arrested recently in Brisbane for amplifying their voices. This is the situation that exists in Queensland. For amplifying one's voice, one is arrested and put in a watch-house. Under the system of justice in Queensland, the bail money exacted for that offence was $600. By comparison, the person next in line for bail and release was on a drunk and disorderly charge, and he got away with bail of 10c. One starts thinking that one is dealing with cuckoo-land. Perhaps that is how it should be described.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get back to the draconian legislation which this Bill seeks to avoid. I know that serious objection will be taken to this Bill. But it is the only way in which trade unionists in Queensland can escape the consequences of the Acts that were imposed by the National Party Government in Queensland. This Bill will bring all workers in the electricity industry throughout Queensland under Federal awards and allow them to escape the draconian provisions of the State legislation. That is what it is about. Senator Messner is correct. It does not reinstate the workers. That injustice will persist. Unless there is consultation, reasonable advice and reasonable recommendation coming from a source outside Queensland, we will have continuing disputation.

My view is that the men concerned ought to be reinstated. If they are not reinstated, they should receive some equity-not be destroyed in a machiavellian way by the ruthless Premier of Queensland. That is what he has done. He has crushed these people completely and ruthlessly, and it appears they may not have any escape unless the whole of the trade union movement in Australia comes to their defence. That is what the blockade was all about. It was to expose the iniquities of the Queensland Act. It was to try to get justice for 800 workers-no matter who is considered to have been at fault originally.

I found it reprehensible that in Queensland I could not go into a depot leading a delegation without being under the threat of arrest. I said that the first person I spoke to was the Electricity Commissioner. The next person I spoke to was the area engineer on the Gold Coast. I went there; there was a picket outside; I went into the depot and the engineer and I talked for some time. He expressed the opinion that his best men were out and said that the policy was that he had to do without them. While I was there the police came in and said: 'Look, there are picketers outside. Now, provided that they just stand there with their placards and say nothing, do nothing aggressively, we are prepared to allow them to stand'. I went out and I spoke to those picketers and said: 'The police recognise your right to picket but do not do anything like obstructing traffic in and out of the depot. Just express your opinion by way of placards and the police will just stand by'. They did that.

The next day the Premier of Queensland matted the Commissioner of Police and his deputy and said: 'You have got to impose the conditions of the Act'-which says that people cannot gather anywhere or stand anywhere in such a way that it could be considered or calculated to harass a SEQEB worker.
