From that point the arrests started. It was after the Premier said to the Commissioner 'Impose the Act' that the police reluctantly imposed it and the arrests began.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hitler started in the same way.

—Yes. When one considers how fascism emerged, one could say that it emerged in the same manner. It is not properly realised that defending certain decisions can eventually lead to extreme positions. That is what we have to be very careful about and that is why we have very considerable concern about what is happening in Queensland. I was arrested on three occasions. I consider those arrests to have caused a breach of my responsibilities as a member of parliament. I searched various Acts to find out whether my actions were covered. Strangely enough, they were not covered federally; they were covered by State law. Section 45 of the Queensland Criminal Code provides:

SPEECH.PARA: It is lawful for any person to act in good faith to call for the removal of matters which are producing or have a tendency to produce feelings of ill-will or enmity between different classes of Her Majesty's subjects.

That is a section of Bjelke's criminal code. The only time I was not arrested for taking a delegation or being on a picket was when the police were informed of that section. Wayne Gilbert, the General Manager of SEQEB, objected to my seeing the depot engineer, Mr Argent, whom I had known for some time, and who was the area engineer for the northern section. I took a delegation to see him. He saw only me and not the rest of the delegation. What did I discuss with him? We discussed the reinstatement of former employees of the South East Queensland Electricity Board and the reimbursement of those employees' superannuation contributions. I reminded him of some other matters. I was not harassing him, though under the Queensland Act it could be termed harassment. I said to him: 'Some of the men who are out of work are sons of men whom you have worked with; in fact, men who trained you as a young engineer'. Some of the sons of the men who had entered the industry were affected and had no chance of getting their jobs back. They have less chance if they attend a picket, are part of a picket or do anything else against the Queensland Act because a security officer goes around taking the numbers of the cars belonging to everyone on a picket. He takes photographs of people on pickets. The intention is that those people will never be employed again. I mentioned to Mr Argent that a couple of the people on the pickets were sons of former employees with whom he had worked. What did Mr Gilbert have to say to me? He said:

You are hereby advised, in the clearest terms that any matter of inquiry by any person relating to any former employee of THE SOUTH EAST QUEENSLAND ELECTRICITY BOARD can only be made directly to the General Manager of THE SOUTH EAST QUEENSLAND ELECTRICITY BOARD or a person nominated by him, at the Head Office . . .
Accordingly, such an inquiry cannot be made to, or, through, any person attached to any depot or any other establishment of THE SOUTH EAST QUEENSLAND ELECTRICITY BOARD.

Because of your declared responsibilities to your constituents as a Senator of the State of Queensland I require you, in accordance with such responsibilities, to suitably advise all of your constituents in the terms of the advices contained in this communication.

That letter came from the man who is responsible for the management of SEQEB. I lay at his feet the blame for the situation in Queensland because he thinks he is smart enough to run the system in Queensland on the cheap. That system cannot be run on the cheap, by contract labour. It cannot expose itself to all the weaknesses of contract labour, which in the short term may be cheaper but in the long term is highly dangerous.

Mr Gilbert has exposed the present workers of SEQEB to highly dangerous situations. I give an example. A linesman takes at least a year to train. As well he takes associated correspondence courses and is gradually introduced into dangerous situations. Mr Gilbert expects to train people in a crash course of three weeks for this highly dangerous work and to expose to this highly dangerous work contractors who have not the experience. The system will run down. Unfortunately, that will not happen immediately. It takes maybe two or three years for the lines to become slack because they were not properly prepared, for houses to become dangerous because periodic inspections are not carried out and the earthings inspected. The errors of the Wayne Gilbert approach will not be evident for another five or six years. In the meantime, all these errors have been imposed and the people who are suffering most are the people who are still out of work.

This legislation will ensure that conferences take place. There is no doubt that it will lead parties to the conference table. The Queensland Government will not be able to avoid going to the conference table. It may not be possible for the Commission to order reinstatement but it can provide the environment for reinstatement. As to support for the Bjelke-Petersen Government, the path that those honourable senators who are members of the National Party in Queensland are following will be to their electoral disadvantage, no matter how gerrymandered the State may be. The Labor Party has the answers and deserves to be elected.

One thing is certain; the Liberal Party has much to gain. I am surprised at Senator Messner and Senator Chaney from the Liberal Party, who will no doubt give great support to what Bjelke-Petersen is doing. Talk about support and popularity polls! The raids on those health clinics were an abomination-an invasion of privacy. The mind that made the decision to carry out those raids is the mind that created the Queensland legislation that has led to the legislation before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stick to the legislation before you.
—We will see what the honourable senator has to say in defence of the sacked workers. If I know him well, he will come out in their support.
—You are talking about the raid on abortion clinics, which is not associated with this legislation.
—I merely said that the mind--
—That is your view.

—That is right. That is the mind that led to those raids, the method of those raids and the invasion of privacy. I am not talking about the basic issue with which the honourable senator is concerned. I am talking about the method-and the method came from those who were responsible for the legislation which has made it necessary for us to support and pass this legislation in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put this matter into context because it is quite apparent that we will have a very emotional debate today. It is an emotional issue because many people's lives and livelihoods are at stake, not just in Queensland but also, potentially, around Australia. This matter stems initially from the irresponsible action of trade union leaders in Queensland, people responsible for the provision of essential services, people who reneged on that responsibility to ensure the continuous supply of electricity-an essential service-and people who took industrial action which ran counter not only to all the things the Australian Democrats stand for but also, I believe, to the principles of the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party. Their action and, in part, one of the steps they took to reject a decision by the Queensland Industrial Court, gave the opportunity for the South East Queensland Electricity Board to provoke a dispute at a local level into a State-wide dispute and, subsequently, into a dispute which has become national in its impact.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the classic situation where two organisations and their representatives-wilful people who are willing to put the public at risk, to put people's jobs in jeopardy, to put people's livelihoods at risk-confronted each other head on and ignored the likely consequences and, as it has transpired, the real consequences of this disputation. The situation had the potential for disaster. For many people it has gone from disaster to tragedy. I suspect that the 850 people who have been sacked will never be re-employed by SEQEB and will find it very difficult, because of their specific skills, to find employment anywhere in their home State. As a result, those people may have to move to other States, leave their families, or disrupt their children's education.

I do not think this is a pretty scene. I happened to be in Queensland when much of this sequence of events took place. I was able to talk with many people living in Queensland who were not directly involved with the dispute but who were suffering from the consequences. Small business people who owned delicatessens found food was being destroyed. People with ice-cream parlours had to shut their shops. Small manufacturers, small factories and some service organisations which rely on a continuous supply of electricity were either set back or, in some cases, put out of business because they were already in a hazardous position due to the declined Queensland economy.

In this situation there was scope for a statesman to enter the fray, to bring the parties together, and to find a resolution. Instead, what happened? We saw a State government introduce the most draconian industrial legislation this country has ever seen. It was not an Act designed to bring about conciliation or peace in the industrial movement in Queensland but an Act which, on the Premier's admission, was designed to destroy the trade union movement in his State and, if possible, in this country. Because I have had representations from people, including some from South Australia, I am aware that there is nothing these people would like better than to have the trade union movement in this country destroyed. They live in some sort of wonderland which allows them to believe that the destruction of the trade union movement will create an economic paradise. It allows them to continue blithely along that path without ever suggesting an alternative, without ever suggesting what would take the place of the trade union movement in this country and without indicating how workers' rights would be protected. By workers' rights I mean safety issues, the protection of young people, of women and of all workers who receive a degree of protection through the existence of the trade union movement. I ask those people, whether they be politically motivated or motivated for any other reason, to think very carefully about the consequences that would arise in this country if Premier Bjelke-Petersen were successful and destroyed not only the trade union movement but also the industrial relations system, which is the path he has set for himself.

I talked of the loss of industrial rights. However, the legislation introduced by Premier Bjelke-Petersen goes further than that. It attacks the basic human rights of the people of Queensland. That is not just a personal opinion. I quote from report No. 14 of the Human Rights Commission on the Queensland Electricity Supply and Related Industrial Legislation. I remind honourable senators that the Human Rights Commission was created by the Fraser Liberal Government to examine and report to this Parliament on issues such as this. I read into Hansard each of the Commission's recommendations:

The Human Rights Commission having found that a number of provisions in the package of Queensland industrial legislation examined in this report are inconsistent with Articles 14 (2), 19 and 22 of the ICCPR accordingly recommends-

(a) that the inconsistencies be brought to the attention of the Queensland Government with the object of persuading that Government to repeal the offending provisions or at least amend them to limit their operation in a manner consistent with the observance of human rights; and
(b) that if the Queensland Government does not repeal these provisions or bring them into line with Australia's obligations under the ICCPR, the Commonwealth Government--
we are talking about this Government, this Parliament-

should take whatever action is necessary to ensure that any application the relevant unions may decide to make for registration under the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act is able to be heard without delay by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

Unless the provisions in the industrial legislation identified in this report and the Commission's Report No. 12 are repealed or suitably amended, Queensland's industrial relations system will continue to be subject to restrictions which infringe human rights. The Commission therefore further recommends-
(c) that if at the end of 1985 the situation remains unsatisfactory in human rights terms, the Government--
the Federal Government-
consider referring appropriate issues to the Commission for further inquiry and report.

The Human Rights Commission, appointed by legislation of the Fraser Government, has reported to this Parliament in those terms. The Queensland Government in the first instance responded by vigorously attacking the Commission. A ploy well known to people in this Parliament is that if one does not have an argument one attacks the individual. If one cannot get any reason or logic into one's defence, one attacks the person making the criticism. That is what happened in Queensland. The Queensland Government attacked the chairperson of that Commission and the Commission as well as its recommendations. I will not give credence in this Parliament to some of the words that were used to denigrate the Commission, but they have been seen by the people of Queensland in their newspapers. I think it is worth recapping one of those recommendations because it is the genesis of this legislation. It says:

. . . the Commonwealth Government should take whatever action is necessary to ensure that any application the relevant unions may decide to make for registration under the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act is able to be heard without delay by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

We all know that the normal processes of application for registration under the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission are long and tedious, and in fact can be spread out through the appeals process not just by months but potentially by years. If the Government was going to take cognisance of that report, its only option was to introduce the Bill before us today. This Bill does one thing only. It speeds up the processes by which the Electrical Trades Union of Australia can obtain access to the Federal arbitration system. It does not create an access which is not already there. It does not make it possible for the ETU to do something which it would be otherwise prohibited from doing. All that the Bill does is to speed up the process. This obviously runs counter to the wishes of those who want a continuing conflagration in Queensland. If one wants chaos and disruption in Queensland, one will keep this dispute going for months-for years, if possible. On the other hand, if one wants some industrial harmony in Queensland, this Bill will at least speed the day when the matter can get into the industrial arena and out of the political arena.

As a politician, I am willing to admit that politicians handle industrial matters very poorly. No matter what political party they come from, politicians are not interested primarily in the subject of the industrial dispute; they are concerned with getting as much political capital out of the dispute as they possibly can. That applies across the board. I admit that it probably applies to the Australian Democrats. It certainly applies to the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party. Above all it applies to the party in government in Queensland at this moment.

We have an opportunity to get this dispute off the political agenda and into the hands of industrial commissioners, where it should have been all along. It was taken out of the hands of the commissioners by the Queensland Government. When the dispute was on the Australian Democrats deliberately refrained from provoking and exacerbating the dispute. We stayed right out of it because there were already too many politicians involved. We did not take sides. We hoped, vain hope though it was, that somebody would be able to see reason in Queensland or apply a bit of reason to what was going on in Queensland and get the whole dispute before the Industrial Commission and thus minimise the dislocation that was apparent there.

If it is possible to resolve this dispute-I believe it is-by getting it before the Federal Arbitration Commission, I just cannot understand why any honourable senator would talk against this Bill or vote against this Bill today because the only effect of the loss of this Bill would be to ensure that Queensland goes through industrial chaos for at least the next six months. The Democrats were faced with the challenge. The Federal Government, acting on the Human Rights Commission report, introduced the Bill and we were brought into the debate. The Federal Government claimed that it had introduced the Bill as a result of an agreement it had reached with the Australian Council of Trade Unions to stop the blockade imposed on Queensland aimed at putting pressure on the Queensland Government to get the matter before the Queensland Industrial Commission again. When the accord was reached between the Federal Government and the ACTU to call off the blockade, the Federal Government introduced the Bill.

The Australian Democrats studied the Bill and felt that whilst it was heading in the right direction there were several areas of great concern. One of them was the potential for the blockade to be reimposed immediately after this legislation was passed. Another area of concern was the potential for the ETU to gain access to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and then conduct itself in the manner that it did at the start of this dispute, in other words, prevent people from getting their essential services, their electricity, in Queensland. So then we would be back to square one. Instead of dealing with a State industrial commission we would be dealing with a Federal arbitration commission while essential services would still be denied to the people of Queensland.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats I indicated to the ACTU and through it to the Queensland Trades and Labor Council and the ETU in Queensland that we would not allow the passage of this Bill unless we got watertight guarantees that there would be no resumption of the blockade. Further, we wanted an agreement that the ETU would agree to and accept the insertion of a no strike clause in the proposed new Federal award.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you get that guarantee?
—I have that guarantee. I intend to table the telex which contains that guarantee.
—What about the Latrobe Valley?

—I will come to the Latrobe Valley in a moment. Those guarantees are acceptable to the Australian Democrats. I believe those guarantees will be acceptable to all honourable senators when they have had the opportunity to read them.
—Is that the same guarantee you got from the coal unions yesterday?

—So far Senator Messner has not had the opportunity to read them. I intend to table those guarantees in a moment. The Australian Democrats, having accepted that there would be no prevention of the supply of electricity by the ETU in the future and that there would be no blockade of Queensland by the ACTU on this issue, had their attention drawn by Mr Vince Lester, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Affairs in the Queensland Government, to a possible breaking away from this assurance. He sent a telegram to the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Urgent . . .Before the Senate votes on industrial legislation draw your attention to todays meeting between combined coal mining unions and coal employers.
The coal mining unions have declared they want the coal companies to publicly denounce the Queensland Government's legislation re: continuity of electricity supply.
If employers refuse the union will commence 48 hour rolling stoppages. This would lead to shortage of coal at Queensland's power stations and subsequent rationing of power.
Urge Democrats be made aware of this latest situation re: union demands before voting on todays important Bill, and do not support the Federal Government's legislation.

Having received that telegram I recognised that there was a possibility of a union not directly involved with this dispute breaking ranks with the ACTU and breaking the promise that I had received from the ACTU.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—Senator Messner has a mocking sneer. While he was sitting contemplating his navel-he came in here this morning and accused me of not being interested, of not doing anything-for the past three weeks I have spent at least five hours a day endeavouring to resolve this dispute and its ramifications. And we have resolved it.
—While he has been scoring political points.

—While the honourable senator has been scoring political points. I can understand Senator Messner's disappointment because this matter might go off the agenda in Queensland and around Australia. Opposition senators will not be able to score those political points after today. I then sought from the ACTU-
—Just read us the telegram again.

—The honourable senator is not going to get much wiser if he opens his mouth when somebody is giving him information which he has sought. I sought from the ETU through the ACTU an unconditional guarantee that the coal mining unions would cancel their proposed meeting with the coal mine owners-this was the threat meeting to which Vince Lester referred-and, further, they would not precipitate any industrial action against the coal industry or any other employer on this issue. That guarantee confirms what I believed was a valid promise by the ACTU and it confirms that the ACTU can maintain that promise because it put pressure on the Queensland coal mining unions and made them toe the line. Within two hours of my request I had that promise. I believe that that shows the bona fides and the ability to keep the promise made to me by the ACTU.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not the slightest doubt that today and over the next few days, perhaps the next few weeks if Opposition senators can string it on that long, some honourable senators in this place will be able to introduce red herrings, total and absolute irrelevancies such as the one that was introduced last night by Senator Boswell. He made a plea for some union contributions to help the 850 sacked workers in Queensland. He said: 'There you are. Your ACTU promise has been broken already'. What crass nonsense! What absolute garbage! That has no relevance to this dispute. I put it to Senator Boswell that he is dragging in a red herring already before this matter has even gone to the Federal arbitration system. I suggest that the industrial disputation in Queensland has gone far enough. Every industrial dispute in this land, thank God, has finished around the table-every single one. This dispute will finish around the table. It will finish before an arbitrator who is neutral, not somebody who has been appointed at the direction of the Queensland Premier. Somebody who is absolutely and totally neutral will look at all the sides of this dispute. As a result, there is the potential for a resolution for the first time in several months.

We have a choice and this Parliament has a choice today. We can relight the fuse, and that fuse is attached to potentially the biggest industrial explosion that this country has ever seen. Alternatively, we can move the politicians out of the dispute-I think we have seen a pretty good sample of politicians' behaviour in the last two or three minutes-because they look like having to move out of it. They are starting to get all upset. They enjoy it. As we heard from Senator Boswell, he wants a war. He wants the fight to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Messner.

—Senator Messner is disappointed because this matter will disappear off the political agenda. I remind the Senate that we are not talking about just the heavies in this dispute; we are talking about the people of Queensland who will suffer and have already suffered as a consequence of it. The people of Queensland will be well served by the Australian Democrats today because, as a result of our vote, the people of Queensland will have industrial peace. I know that industrial peace suits the aspirations of neither Senator Messner nor Senator Boswell; nor does it suit the aspirations of the Queensland Premier. They are an interesting and very harmonious trio on this issue. They want industrial confrontation and they do not care a damn who suffers. They want the dispute to go beyond Queensland; they want it to spread across Australia. Amendments to this legislation which will be moved later today will make it quite clear that they want it to be a national dispute, not just a Queensland dispute. They want it spread far and wide across this land. They want small businesses in Queensland destroyed.

SPEECH.PARA: They want industrial chaos because that is the way they think they can win votes. They want not just 850 SEQEB workers' jobs destroyed; they want more workers sacked. Let us lay it on the line. That is what this Queensland legislation is about, because the more workers who are retrenched, the more industrial disputation there is in Queensland, the greater-this is the incredible thing-the rampant support from a few people in Queensland for the Queensland Premier.

In exactly the same way Maggie Thatcher rallied some troops around her by declaring war. As a result of declaring war on the worker in Queensland and small business in Queensland, families in Queensland and all the people who rely on the essential services in Queensland, the Queensland Government will not just destroy and disrupt its economy; it will destroy and disrupt the Australian economy, and all of us will suffer as a result.

I make one final rhetorical point. Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen is obviously not convinced that industrial matters should remain in industrial courts. She is obviously not convinced that the sooner we get this dispute into the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the sooner the matter will be put to bed and the people of Queensland will be able to resume their normal lives. If Senator Bjelke-Petersen believes that the path this Government should take-having received the report from the Human Rights Commission-is to allow the matter to grow and get back to the situation we had in Queensland a month or so back, I suspect that we now have demonstrated to us the reason for the uproar coming from the Queensland senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, you indicated during your speech that you would seek leave to table certain telexes. Do you still wish to do that?

—I seek leave to table a telex from Bill Kelty, the Secretary of the ACTU; from Vince Lester, the Queensland Minister for Employment and Industrial Affairs; and from Mr Vickers, the Secretary of the State Council of Combined Mining Unions, Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard half an hour of the most sanctimonious humbug from some of the greatest political hypocrites who have ever sat in this chamber. Senator Jack Evans took half an hour to give a reason why the Australian Democrats are copping out of this dispute. Yet despite that, no reason was given. After all the guarantees the Democrats asked for but did not get beforehand, they have spent the last half an hour copping out and leaving the power users in Queensland to the mercy-or it would be to the mercy but for the fact that we have a strong government in Queensland-of these unions. I might add that the reason politicians ultimately get involved in these disputes is that politicians are elected to govern. The Electrical Trades Union of Australia is not elected to govern, nor is any other union. It is all very well for the ETU, or any other union, to defy the courts, but apparently it is not all right for the politicians to buy in and guarantee a supply of power to the people who elected them. So we have this cop-out from the political camp followers of the Australian political scene-the Australian Democrats. They are the people who were going to 'keep the bastards honest'. At least Jo Vallentine might keep the bastards honest who are going to keep the bastards honest. At least after 30 June we will not have to listen to the sort of sanctimonious humbuggery that we have just been subjected to.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill 1985, one of the most obnoxious pieces of legislation ever brought into this chamber. It is obnoxious not because of any strength that might be in it-in fact it is a rather wishy-washy piece of legislation-but because of what it is trying to do. Here we have a government seeking to subvert the sovereign rights of a State government. It might come as no surprise to a lot of people who are interested, but it will probably come as a surprise to the Australian Democrats, to hear that there is already an application by the ETU for Federal registration before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The whole thing has been a fraud because the unions have tried to make an interstate dispute out of this so that it could become a Federal matter. We see a situation in which officials of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the unelected government of this nation, are the puppeteers hiding behind the screen, pulling strings so that Mr Hawke and his Government will jump and go clickety-clack as they give the performance that is required of them.

The history of this matter has been gone over a few times so I shall state it only very briefly. We have the story of a maverick organiser of a militant union getting out of his depth. I have said on other occasions in this chamber that if the Queensland Trades and Labour Council had bought into this a lot sooner perhaps we would not have got to this stage because there is a lot of accumulated wisdom there.

TALK.START.PARA: —People like Georgie.

—Yes, with due respect to Senator Georges, I believe that if he had come into the situation a bit earlier we possibly would not be going down this track today. We have a maverick organiser and a militant union and the whole thing got out of hand.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot of things about the Queensland Government not obeying recommendations. Nothing has been said about the ETU not obeying directions from the Queensland Industrial Commission. It started in mid-January after the disastrous storm. Employees were ordered back for two weeks, and within the two weeks, on Thursday, 17 January, they were on strike-all over the fact that contract labour was being used on three transmission lines and in one sub-station. They were then directed back to work on the Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday until, ultimately, the Queensland Government said: 'Enough is enough; you are now unemployed'. I reiterate that the ETU started the battle and chose the battlefield. The fact that the unionists picked a battle and a battlefield on which they could not win is now history. They have paid an awful price.

TALK.START.PARA: —They lost.

—Yes, they lost completely. The Government elected to govern that State reacted to that given situation. The ETU is not elected by anybody in Australia, let alone in Queensland. Much has been said about the 1,500 people who are out of work. There were originally in the work force 1,552-these figures are at 3 April 1985. What people do not realise is that 483 members of the work force would not go on strike. There were 146 who were away normally, on sick leave, holidays and all the rest of it, who have returned. That makes a total of 629 Queensland employees in the organisation now at work. New recruits not previously employed by the South East Queensland Electricity Board numbering 141, former SEQEB employees who returned after signing on as new employees on the new terms number 192. From the original 1,552, that gives a total of 962. On top of that, some 250 previous employees are now being employed by about 60 contractors. That takes the figure up to 1,212 for previous employees who are working in one way or another. Currently 80 ex-employees have their names on the books seeking employment at SEQEB. So let us forget about the 800 or 900 people supposedly still out of work. They have voted with their feet against all that has gone on.
—You are forgetting about their families, too.

—Their families are obviously well off. I probably know more about the travails of families in such situations than the honourable senator ever would. I wish to quote a few excerpts from the second reading speech of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis):

SPEECH.PARA: The independent processes of conciliation and arbitration have been rejected in favour of a policy of unilateral legislative action to change terms and conditions of employment which were previously agreed by the Queensland Government and to impose sanctions on those who breach the provisions of this legislation.

What utter rubbish! As I have just explained, we know who rejected the processes of conciliation and arbitration, who rejected directions from the Commission, but the Minister still tries to justify this ridiculous legislation. The Minister continued in his speech:
An essential part of that process of negotiations was that the ACTU, and all its affiliates, would call off all industrial action against Queensland.
Later in that speech he admitted:
The Queensland trade union movement and the ACTU imposed a prolonged transport blockade--

That was against Queensland. In that passage the Minister in regard to the ACTU-the puppeteers, the people who pull strings when he jumps clickety-clack in front of the screen-admits what was being done against a sovereign State of this nation.

I remind the Senate once again that this Prime Minister got into power because of his 'special relationship' with the union movement. My word, he has a special relationship! As soon as it pulls the strings he jumps, and we can hear his bones going clickety-clack every day now. One of the things most people do not realise is that not only were jobs lost because of the power dispute-jobs are just not there now because small businesses went under-but they were also lost because of the blockade. These were the jobs of the people-the people whom this Labor Government says it supports, the people whom the Government says it represents better than anybody else. The whole sorry story of this episode is lost jobs, lost jobs and more lost jobs. So we have this awful scenario, and we also have the threat of further problems. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, a member of the Government that admits it has a special relationship with the unions, also stated in his second reading speech:
Industrial action was taken or threatened in the building, brewing, communications and mining industries . . .

He said also that this 'threatened serious damage both to national economic recovery and to our international trading situation'. Go on! He could have fooled me. It is about time the Government woke up to the ramification of what it has been doing. There will be further action and we will be driven deeper into the mire in which we find ourselves in the international community. This is reflected, even as late as today, in the value of the Australian dollar, in how the international community sees us and our performance. We have this sorry state of affairs, and we have an impotent Government and an impotent Prime Minister going clickety-clack as the ACTU puppeteers pull the strings.

We find also in the Minister's second reading speech the story about people's democratic right to strike. If ever there were a misused or abused idea in the few months in particular, it is the idea of a democratic right to strike. When the ancient Greeks talked about democracy they really talked about the rule of the people in their own self-interest. That hardly comes under this idea of a democratic right to strike. The second point I raise is that rights to do not exist independently of the society in which we exist, yet we hide behind this idea of a democratic right to strike. In other words, we can go off at a tangent irrespective of the harm, hardship, travail or turmoil that might bring upon our fellows. The third point I make is that most Queenslanders, and indeed most Australians, would agree that no one group should abuse the power it holds by virtue of its position to the detriment of the society in which it finds itself. Other people have rights. The people of Queensland, small businesses, those who lost their jobs, all have a right to a continuous power supply. People have a right to be able to obtain foodstuffs. An elderly couple have a right to believe that a lift will work if they live on the sixth floor of a retirement unit block.

Many other rights have been forgotten in this so-called democratic right to strike. The main right is the right of everybody else to work. Nobody is saying that those people who are dissatisfied with their work conditions cannot pick up their bundles and go and find another job. That is their democratic right. It is certainly not their democratic right, particularly when we understand their wages and the conditions under which they are employed, to go off at a tangent to the detriment of the rest of society.

With all the talk we have heard and all the sanctimonious attitudes we have had from the Australian Democrats, it is very interesting to note what the Minister said a couple of times in his second reading speech:
Since there is no constitutional power for the Commonwealth to do so, this Bill does not seek to directly provide for reinstatement of the dismissed SEQEB employees.

There it is. The Government accepts what a lot of rot this whole piece of legislation is, because it accepts the fact that it cannot do a thing. Of course, this is the tragedy. All the way through, these dismissed employees who have not yet got a job have been led up the garden path; first of all by their own union--

TALK.START.PARA: —Now by Hawke.

—Now by Mr Hawke. I say to any of those dismissed employees who are listening to this debate that they have no chance of getting back their jobs under the conditions which previously existed, so they had better start looking around for something else. They have been given a bum steer by the very people who should know better and who should be telling them the truth. Now we come to the political camp followers of the Australian political system-the Australian Democrats. To illustrate their cop-out, I quote from the Age of 23 May:

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats' industrial spokesman, Senator Jack Evans, said his party wanted the ACTU to guarantee that if the legislation was passed, the Electrical Trades Union would have a 'no strike' clause inserted in a new federal award, and a promise of no further blockades against Queensland.
That is quite clear and unequivocal; there would be a no strike clause inserted in a new Federal award and a promise of no further blockades against Queensland. The very next sentence states:
The Queensland branch of the ETU last night rejected the 'no strike' proposal.
The next day, on 24 May, an article in the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

The Democrats' spokesman on industrial relations, Senator Jack Evans, said it was his understanding that the ACTU would not engage in further blockades of Queensland if the bill is passed and is allowed to come into effect.

He also said the ACTU and the unions involved, in agreeing to abide by decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, had in effect agreed to accept a no-strike clause, if the commission decides such a clause is necessary.

Is that a watertight guarantee? Who believes it? Of course, it has already been mentioned-Senator Jack Evans tried to make something of the fact-that the combined mining unions were ready to go on strike, but so that they do not upset the Democrats, they will withdraw the strike because the Bill is coming up in the Senate. Is that a guarantee that it will not happen in the future? Can anybody believe it? If ever a group of people should understand that their jobs are on the line, it should be the members of the combined mining unions. Heaven knows, our name for high prices and unreliability on world markets is bad enough as it is, yet here we have the combined mining unions sending out signals to all the world that as soon as this legislation is passed they will try to get something out of the bosses. The bosses will have to sign an agreement that the legislation is awful, otherwise we will have 48-hour rolling strikes. If ever a group of people should be knuckling down and protecting their jobs, it should be the combined mining unions.

It might come as news to a lot of people, particularly honourable senators opposite, that no-strike agreements, or continuous supply of power agreements, have been discussed already with the power generating unions in Queensland. Arrangements were made that they would have special conditions. There was to be a loading on their salaries, help with their superannuation and rent, a shorter working week and a nine-day fortnight. I might say that most unions agreed to that provision. Some of them broke it, but the ETU took the conditions and did not agree to a continuous supply of power. Where does that now put Senator Jack Evans and the Australian Democrats, who see themselves as the protectors of the underdog in this country and who have copped out and gone to water? Obviously, one would believe that the tooth fairy is still alive and well in Australia if one followed the political philosophies of the Australian Democrats.

The Queensland Government reached the stage where there was nothing left for it to do but to introduce legislation. Bearing in mind all the talk that we have had, it gets down to one thing: We had an elected government, a government elected by legislative processes, seeking to guarantee to the people who elected it a continuous supply of power-nothing more and nothing less. Queensland is not the only place in which such a situation has arisen. It has happened in other countries. It was brought to my attention just before this debate began that President Reagan found himself having to do something similar so that the airlines system in America could operate. President Reagan took similar action. Is it not the right, indeed the duty, of an elected government to guarantee that its citizens, the people who elected it, should have a continuous supply of power? That is what the Queensland legislation is all about.

This Government, the puppet whose strings are being pulled by the unelected government of Australia, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which is hiding behind the screen, has found itself in the position where, as its strings are pulled and it jumps, it has had to bring in this legislation. We can hear the clickety-clacking as we go through this legislation. Clauses 7, 8 and 9 really mean nothing. The legislation is a sop to the ACTU movement. We have a threat hanging over us all the time. The Democrats have vacated the chamber, but I hope that they are listening to the debate. Once again I quote from the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 May:

An ACTU industrial officer, Mr Ian Court, said the assurance of no further industrial action was conditional upon the legislation becoming law quickly and would not hold if there was a drawn-out High Court challenge.

That is blackmail. What else would one call it? In other words, the ACTU, the unelected government of this country, is saying to Queensland: 'Once this legislation is passed you have to accept it. The due processes of law cannot take place. We are the masters. We are the people who tell Mr Hawke what to do. We are the people who pull the strings. Once it is passed it has to be accepted and you cannot use the due processes of law to challenge that legislation'. The legislation is questionable constitutionally anyhow. Today we find ourselves in a situation in which the Democrats, the tooth fairy party, are going to water and using any excuse to cop out. It is copping out on the most flimsy of guarantees.

It is very interesting that today's Bulletin published the results of an opinion poll which was taken in Queensland when the blockade was running regarding the stand of the Australian Labor Party on the whole question. The poll indicates that during the blockade the ALP dropped five points. I reiterate that the Queensland Government is doing nothing more and nothing less than guaranteeing its citizens, the people who elected it, a continuous supply of power. Yet we have this sham of legislation being brought in by the puppets because the puppeteers have demanded it. As the debate proceeds we can hear the puppets clickety-clack as they shimmer and shake across the stage when the unelected government pulls the strings.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.44 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It concerns the value of the Australian dollar and action which the Government might take to increase confidence in the currency. Does the Minister agree that national and international financial markets are not satisfied with the Government's refusal to state a definite position on discounting wages for the effects of depreciation and that this continues to be a major factor affecting the dollar? Notwithstanding the Minister's remarks yesterday about hypothetical situations, will he give an assurance that, if there is a measurable impact on the consumer price index by the time of the next national wage case, the Government will argue for discounting of wages?

—Many factors have been suggested as to why international and local financial markets may have a view about the dollar. Some which were suggested a month or two ago have been abandoned now in the lexicon of wild suggestions about this matter. Others are still being pursued, like the one that Senator MacGibbon is pursuing in this question. I cannot speak for what people who may be influential in these matters feel about a wide variety of issues. Apart from that, I have nothing to add to the answers I have given on previous occasions.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it then that the matter of the status of the Australian economy is of no concern to the Government?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: STAR WARS PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in today's Age in which the chief scientist for the United States of America's Star Wars program indicated that ground based lasers designed to knock out Soviet ballistic missiles would be so vulnerable to atmospheric interference that they could not be used on a cloudy day? Can the Minister tell me how many cloudy days per year the United States averages?
—I call the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs or the chief meteorologist, Senator Gareth Evans.

—I did see the article to which Senator Ray refers, although I have no briefing before me which will enable me to comment on either the scientific validity of the points made or for that matter the meteorology of the United States. However, I make the point that has been made on a number of occasions previously in this chamber that that sort of report, if indeed it does prove to be accurate, coming from a person of that status, does reinforce the kinds of doubts that have been expressed by Australia and so many other countries about the technological viability of the absolute defence Star Wars or strategic defence initiative concept. One of the major doubts about SDI remains, as it always has been, that defensive technology ever could move fast enough to comprehensively outstrip offensive technology in a way that is required if the strategic defence initiative or mutually assured defence concept is ever to make any sense.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to comments by the head of Western Mining Corporation Ltd, Sir Arvi Parbo, that Australia is in danger of becoming the latest banana republic of the Southern Hemisphere unless the wage indexation system is abandoned. Does the Minister agree with Sir Arvi that the present wage fixation system is unrealistic in that it is not related to the ability of the economy to pay? I ask whether he further agrees with Sir Arvi when he says:

QUESTION.PARA: There is no logic in saying rewards can only go up when everyone knows the economy goes up and down. Wages must go up and down as they have done in the United States.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the reports published over the signature or under the name of Sir Arvi Parbo relating to the matters to which Senator Knowles referred. I find it extraordinary that when the standard of living in this country, relative to those of other countries, has been going down for 25 years, Sir Arvi Parbo has now locked himself into the banana republic syndrome. That decline has been happening under previous governments and various wage systems and many factors have contributed to it. Those honourable senators who think seriously about this question will recognise that some of the factors relate to the competitiveness of Australian industry, in respect of which the wage fixation system over a period has had some influence. I do not think the position is served by people such as Sir Arvi Parbo-who has himself put these views to me; I did not have to read them in the newspapers-making these dramatic analogies with banana republics. It is clear that as chairman of a substantial mining company Sir Arvi Parbo has very strong and quite legitimate views about the wage fixation system, particularly insofar as it applies to the companies of which he is chairman or a senior executive--
—You are not suggesting self-interest, are you?

—I am not suggesting anything to the honourable senator; I am answering Senator Knowles's question. The point I simply make is that this Government has made a judgment about the question of the centralised wage fixation system. We believe that in the two and a half years we have been in government it has served this country very well by comparison with the so-called wage system which operated under our predecessors. If honourable senators look at the wage pattern of the early 1980s under the Fraser Government they will see a dramatic difference with the pattern of wage fixation and wage levels under the present Government.

ANSWER.PARA: If Senator Knowles is asking me the more serious question as to whether I believe greater flexibility should be introduced over time into the Australian wage fixation system, my answer is yes, but the present Government is committed to the centralised wage fixation system because of the history and structure of wage fixation over a long period. The theory which emanates from some of these people is that if we allow complete deregulation of the wage fixation system labour resources will flow to growth industries. That is not entirely true and I think it is very likely to be quite untrue. The sad fact of the matter is that without a centralised wage fixing system industries which are perhaps less able to support wage claims in the international community in terms of international competitiveness may be those most exposed to heavy wage claims, as happened in 1981 and 1982 under the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations inform this House of the attitude of the Government to the industrial dispute at the Renison mine in Tasmania, where the workers are not being allowed to return to work until they sign a no-strike agreement? Further, will the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's attitude to this proliferation of such measures by the captains of industry and this flagrant abuse of the rights of workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the origins of the dispute to which Senator Devlin has referred can be traced to the proposed installation of a ventilation fan in the mine by contract labour. Consequently, there has been a series of 24-hour stoppages beginning on 1 May. I am told by Mr Willis that there have been meetings of the parties this week and that further meetings are scheduled for next week. The Government is closely monitoring the developments.

ANSWER.PARA: In a more general sense, the type of confrontation which is apparently currently occurring at Renison is, of course, not in accordance with either the policy or the record of this Government. The policies of this Government, which seek as far as possible to avoid that sort of confrontation, have produced the lowest level of strikes for some 17 years, a level-this has particular relevance to the previous question-which is 71 per cent lower than the peak or worst level of industrial disruption and confrontation under the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs clarify the Government's position towards the review conference on the Treaty on the Non- Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons to be held in September in Geneva, in which most of the 127 parties to the Treaty are expected to participate? Specifically, will Australia stand with other non-nuclear countries at the review conference when demands are made on the nuclear weapons states for an immediate negotiation of a comprehensive test ban treaty, or will Australia side with its nuclear ally, the United States of America, if the latter refuses to enter into such negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position, which I am asked to clarify, is pretty straightforward. We attach great importance to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. We have taken the view that for 15 years it has made a major contribution to regional and international stability and security. It has become the centrepiece of efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons to additional countries and provides the essential framework for international co-operation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. The Treaty is certainly a major element in Australia's nuclear arms control policy and it is also the basis of our stringent bilateral safeguards policy applied to exports of uranium.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treaty is reviewed every five years and the third review conference will take place, as Senator Mason has indicated, in Geneva from 27 August to 24 September this year. We have been working very actively around the diplomatic traps to try to ensure a constructive outcome. We will seek to defend the Treaty and work to maintain and strengthen its effectiveness. We are giving particular attention to nuclear disarmament issues which arise under Article 6 of the Treaty and to an Australian initiative to require, under Article 3 of the Treaty, the application of International Atomic Energy Agency full-scope safeguards to all nuclear exports to non-nuclear weapon states.

At the third preparatory committee meeting for the conference, held in Geneva in April, Australia circulated two papers setting out our views on safeguards, including this question of full-scope safeguards, and international co-operation in the peaceful use of nuclear energy under Article 4 of the Treaty. We have also been actively encouraging additional states to adhere to the Treaty. When I was Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs I sent on the Government's behalf messages to three regional countries which have just joined the Treaty-Brunei, the Seychelles and Kiribati. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, as is well known, also raised the NPT issue during his recent visits to Pakistan and India, two all-too prominent non-NPT states.

As to the last part of Senator Mason's question, we will be making clear at the conference, as we have in so many other forums, our unequivocal support for the immediate negotiation of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. We do not see this as a question of taking sides, although it is an issue on which we have had differences of opinion or emphases of opinion with both the super-powers in recent times. We do not wish to see the conference split, even on an issue as important as a CTB. We will be working to ensure that our views and those of others on the urgency of a CTB are nonetheless registered at the conference. We shall be doing everything that we can in the run-up to the conference to ensure the operation of a wider non-proliferation regime consistent with that aspiration.

That is about as much as I can usefully say. The rest of my brief is in the nature of rhetoric. The main point that needs to be made is that our commitment is absolute and total, and there is no question of our backing away from that, in the context of the CTB or anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer aware of yesterday's statement by a Tasmanian Liberal senator accusing Tasmania's Labor members of parliament of lacking backbone in pressing Tasmania's case to the Federal Government prior to this week's Premiers Conference? Is it not a fact that the Tasmanian Leader of the Opposition, Ken Wriedt, has consistently put Tasmania's case to the Federal Government with the intention of protecting Tasmania's interests? Will the Minister confirm that the Government will take notice of Mr Wriedt's representations? Is it not also a fact that the Tasmanian Premier has deliberately distorted every effort by the Federal Government to assist Tasmania? Finally, has the Minister's attention been drawn to any alternative proposals affecting Commonwealth grants to Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a fact that the Tasmanian Premier tries to distort not only proposals put up by the Commonwealth Government but just about any issue that one can think of. It is the case that Mr Wriedt has presented Tasmanian views and has argued for Tasmanian interests to me personally on a number of occasions, and to the Prime Minister and other members of the Government. It is something that he does extremely well-as, of course, he discharged his duties when he was a member of this Senate and of the former Labor Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen some drivel which apparently was published in the Launceston Examiner and which originated from Senator Archer. From what he was saying a while ago, I gather that he is not trying to deny that he is the source of this drivel. In it he referred, among other things, to the Federal Government having cancelled an irrigation agreement. I am not aware of what irrigation agreement. There never was any such irrigation agreement.

I suppose what he was referring to was the outrageous attempt by the Tasmanian Government to spend an initial $5m and, ultimately, $56m, on the Craigbourne irrigation area, the original justification being that when asked what sort of crops it was intended to grow, those concerned said 'Principally oats' because sometimes they have a dry spring. But the beneficiaries of that would have been about 36 farmers in that valley, the largest of whom, of course, is Mr Casimaty, who is very well connected in the Tasmanian Liberal Party.

So what Senator Archer was defending there was the sort of little in-house, in-club, sweetheart deal by which taxpayers' funds, be they State or Federal taxpayers' funds, are transferred to enrich certain favoured sons or favoured daughters of the Liberal Party-the procedures which are actually being implemented in Queensland, where the Premier has arranged to have his son's 20,000-acre farm irrigated at taxpayers' expense.

Senator Coates referred to the level of funding to the States in general. I suppose that one could extend that very easily to the levels of Commonwealth expenditure in general. If Opposition senators, Senator Archer in particular, are concerned about any of the States being harshly treated at the Premiers Conference, I remind them of the comments made by senior Federal Liberals in Sydney at the weekend, and in particular, the report of the address by Mr Howard to the Liberal Party's northern Sydney area conference, which states:
The Liberal Party should offer nothing by way of new spending proposals at the next election.
Mr Julian Beale, who I understand is regarded as one of the rising stars in the parliamentary Liberal Party, told the same conference:
. . . the next Liberal Party Government should cut $3 billion from the deficit and take $3 billion from other programs in its first budget.

Among Mr Beale's proposals were cuts of $1 billion in Commonwealth grants to the States. So if Senator Archer thinks that Tasmania will face some financial difficulties because of decisions made at the Premiers Conference later this week, he and other Tasmanians should count themselves lucky that they are not dealing with a Liberal government, which, according to one of its rising stars, would immediately cut $1 billion off Commonwealth payments to the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the paper from which he has quoted.
—I table the paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RECALL OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to varying reports about the cost of recalling the House of Representatives for approximately a one-hour sitting on Friday. Some reports place the cost at $100,000, while others suggest it will be only half of that amount. Can the Minister give a reasonably accurate figure of the cost of the recall? Further, what is the estimated saving to the Government in having its amended repatriation legislation operating between now and the Budget?

—I was rather hoping that I might get a question on this subject from a Queensland senator, particularly a Queensland Opposition senator; nevertheless, the question has been asked. I am not able to give a precise figure on the cost of recalling the House of Representatives, but I understand that the figure of $100,000 which has been thrown around-some figures are even higher-is higher than the cost is likely to be. It is necessary to recall the House of Representatives because of the obstructionism of the Opposition. I refer to the meddling in policy changes by the Liberal Party of Australia, which has the fond hope that one day it will be back in government and realises that it is essential that the veterans' legislation be passed. Therefore, the Liberal Party has had sufficient sense of responsibility, or has had some discipline imposed upon it, not to reject the legislation outright. But, at the same time, it wanted to dissociate itself from any fairly narrow sectional political odium that might be attached to supporting the policy. No such constraints apply to the Australian Democrats, who, in their typically dilettantish way were--
—Order! The Minister is clearly debating the matter. I suggest that he get back to the question. If he is not debating it, he is certainly reflecting on a vote of the Senate.

—It is a well known fact that no such discipline ever applies to the Democrats. Were the House of Representatives not to be brought back, the estimated cost in additional outlays would be $10m or quite a bit more. More importantly, in the longer term, the chances of actually achieving on an ongoing basis the policy change which is proposed, which I certainly know the Liberal Party supports privately and which, I expect, it will ultimately support in a permanent and enduring form, would also be jeopardised.

—I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy, in his capacity either as Minister representing the Attorney-General or as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, to a Press headline stating that the Federal Government is to consult with the States on measures to protect nuclear material and facilities from theft or sabotage. Will the Federal Government also consult with the States to protect the rights and safety of people in the event of a nuclear accident? Who would be responsible for this protection? In the event of an accident to a nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed United States ship in an Australian port, would the Pentagon's nuclear accident response procedure manual recommendations apply and, if not, what procedure would?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a combination of Defence and Resources and Energy involved in this answer. Let the record so disclose.
—Have you got a few notes there?
—They say that in the United States Senate, and I thought it sounded rather nice.
—Why don't you go there?
—I am working on it. If I could get away from you for half a day I would be delighted.

ANSWER.PARA: I assume that the reference to consultation with the States refers to the Prime Minister's statement of 23 May responding to the Australian Science and Technology Council report on Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle in which the Prime Minister announced the Government's intention of ratifying the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material and also indicated that, in accordance with established procedures for the ratification of treaties, the States would be consulted.

Concerning Federal-State consultation on issues of nuclear safety, there are quite well established procedures in place between the Federal Government and the relevant States. Only one State has a nuclear facility. That is New South Wales, with the Lucas Heights Atomic Energy Commission's research establishment. An emergency plan is in place there between Federal and State authorities in order to protect the public in the highly unlikely event of a serious accident. The only other context in which this matter arises is the visit of nuclear-powered warships, which are permitted to visit Australia only in accordance with conditions of entry which I outlined in the Senate, on behalf of the Minister for Defence, on 15 December 1983. The authorities responsible for implementing emergency plans vary with local conditions. In the case of nuclear warships, responsibility rests in the first instance with port authorities integrated into and supported by State or Territory emergency services, with Federal support as necessary.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to Senator Walsh's comments in the Senate a week ago. I quote from page 2366 of Hansard:

QUESTION.PARA: I serve notice on the wimps and wankers on the other side that the Government will not accept their ill informed meddling and grandstanding. They will have to accept the responsibility, if they persist with this attitude, for there being no Australian Wheat Board as from 1 October.

Now that the Senate has voted to amend the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, will Senator Button say whether Senator Walsh's position on disbanding the Australian Wheat Board has the backing of the Cabinet and Caucus?

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Senator Walsh's comments. I did not think they were quite as colourful as the quotation suggested. There are opportunities for the Government to reintroduce this legislation and time alone will tell whether there will be an Australian Wheat Board after the date in question. The Government will announce its position before that date.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is he aware of the extension of the dispute in the Mount Thorley coal mine to all open-cut coal mines in the Hunter Valley? Have coal shipments from Newcastle been affected by the dispute? What are the prospects for a quick settlement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dispute between the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia and management at the Mount Thorley coal mine originally concerned a specific issue of manning an International 580 front-end loader as well as a broader issue of the introduction of new technology. These issues appear to have been largely resolved. Regrettably, however, this seems not to be the end of the dispute. At a meeting on 27 May FEDFA members decided on a general stoppage at all Hunter Valley open-cut mines until 30 May. We understand that this is in protest at the action by R. W. Miller and Co. Pty Ltd in employing 21 additional plant operators at Mount Thorley outside what the FEDFA regards as normal channels. The worsening in relations resulting from the loader dispute has been translated into a wider dispute which has stopped production at all Hunter Valley open-cuts.

ANSWER.PARA: It is certainly to be hoped that the parties concerned in the Mount Thorley dispute do not lose sight of the co-operative efforts that have been made by governments, State and Federal, the coal companies and the unions, through the Australian Coal Consultative Council, to strengthen our reputation as a reliable international supplier. Our past achievements in this regard have been considerable in recent times but they will undoubtedly be seriously jeopardised if this sort of dispute is allowed to drag on or escalate. Regarding the last part of Senator Richardson's question, coal shipments from Newcastle, fortunately, have not been affected so far and, I understand, are not likely to be in the foreseeable future. Obviously it is crucial that all parties to the dispute seek an early solution. Certainly the Commonwealth Government is encouraging that outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Ryan, who I think is representing the Minister for Territories in the absence of Senator Gietzelt, who seems to have disappeared totally from the face of the earth. I refer to recent announcements on the restructuring of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, the National Capital Development Commission and the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and also to the Government's decision to impose self-government on the Australian Capital Territory next year. Why are Government Ministers pre-empting the future Australian Capital Territory government by locking it into these new structures at this late stage? Why will Ministers not allow members of the local House of Assembly to have any input at all into the structure or membership of these bodies?

—It is certainly not the case that members of the House of Assembly are not able to have input into various restructurings which are under consideration. That is certainly not the case in relation to the matters for which I have ministerial responsibility-the restructuring of the Schools Authority and co-ordination of higher education in the Australian Capital Territory. On both of those matters extensive public consultation has taken place. Submissions have been invited from every interested party including, of course, the House of Assembly. So if members of the House of Assembly, either collectively or individually, want to make views known to me on any of those issues they are perfectly at liberty to do so and have been for some time.
—They might as well be ordinary citizens.

—With regard to the restructuring of the Health Authority, I am not absolutely sure what procedures for consultation were laid down. But I am sure that there would have been ample opportunity for any House of Assembly member to make his or her views known.
—Why don't you let them nominate somebody to the bodies?
—The question as to why some restructuring is under consideration prior to a form of territorial government-
—Some? Total!
—Order, Senator Lewis!
—I do not know whether Senator Lewis wants me to answer the question or allow him to grunt and groan. Perhaps I can sit down and he can just continue to make a noise.
—Order! Will the Minister answer the question and ignore the interjections.

—In the case of both the Health Authority and the Schools Authority it is necessary to carry out some restructuring because there have been substantial public pressures in that direction. In the case of the Schools Authority, for example, the Authority has already had its legal life extended for six months to the end of June. I do not intend to extend it any further because I think it is unsatisfactory to have such an important body under a temporary governance. I hope to be announcing fairly soon some arrangements for the restructuring of that body. I can only emphasise that there has been ample opportunity for any interested members of the community or of the House of Assembly to make a contribution to that decision. With regard to self-government, a Cabinet submission making proposals for self-government will shortly be considered by the Government. When the Government has made up its mind we will let the Senate know.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware of Press reports concerning a leaked Queensland Treasury document which shows that the Queensland Government is planning to lift fees, charges and fines in July, a mere nine months after increases of between 8 and 100 per cent in fees and charges, despite the fact that the Queensland Premier continues to claim that his is a low tax State? Is the Minister aware of reports that the Queensland Government intends to blame this premature rise in State charges on the Federal Government? Is he concerned that this early increase in State charges will have an adverse effect on the already fragile Queensland economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact which has been known for some considerable time, of course, that the Queensland economy is the sickest economy in Australia and that Queensland is a debt ridden State. Under the Petersen Government Queensland has been going down the Argentinian road and has accumulated a very much higher per capita debt than any other State. After a long period of proceeding down the Argentinian road, ultimately there comes a day of reckoning. I suppose that day of reckoning for Queensland is coming. I am aware of the reports to which Senator Black referred. In yesterday's Australian Financial Review there is a reasonably comprehensive coverage of them. I am not sure whether the article repeats the actual percentage increases to which Senator Black referred, that is, percentage increases of between 8 per cent and 100 per cent in fees, fines and charges which were increased substantially only eight months previously. I do not think they are in the Financial Review. However, I understand that the documents which have been acquired by the Opposition in Queensland show the Queensland Government's firm plans to increase charges, fees and fines.

ANSWER.PARA: Given the understandable desire of the Queensland Government to conceal from its electors the fact that Queensland is in desperate financial trouble because of mismanagement and past profligacy, one can take it for granted that the Queensland Premier will be desperately trying to do everything he can to blame the outcome of this week's Premiers Conference for the increased taxes and charges which he had planned many weeks, if not months, ago. It is very important to note that these increases in taxes and charges were planned by the Queensland Government weeks, if not months, ago. However, they will, of course, be attributed by the Queensland Premier to the outcome of this week's Premiers Conference.

I might make a helpful suggestion in passing. Even at this late stage the people of Queensland could be spared some of the consequences of the mismanagement of their State by the Government if there were a sufficiently strong political campaign to prevent the Premier from squandering $5m of taxpayers' funds on building a dam on the Mackenzie River to irrigate his son's 20,000-acre farm in order to line his son's pockets before his son inherits his seat in Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I ask the Minister to withdraw his last comment. We have allowed the Minister for Finance a fair amount of latitude. The suggestion that the Premier is lining his son's pockets is, I am sure, offensive and contravenes the Standing Orders. It should be withdrawn.

—I did not quite hear the Minister's remarks. I was distracted at the time. However, if those remarks were made by the Minister, there is a clear imputation in them and I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—Very well, Mr President. I understand that the test of acceptability is the Standing Orders and not truth, so I withdraw.
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—Bloody two-faced Chaney.
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr President.
—Mr President, I also ask the Minister for Community Services to withdraw.
—I ask Senator Grimes to withdraw.
—I withdraw, for the benefit of the poor little sensitive souls opposite.
—I can understand the Government's panic, given the state of the opinion polls--
—Order! I ask the Leader of the Opposition to ask his question.

—I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce: Is it a fact that the current Telecom Australia monopoly on PABX systems excludes many small Australian producers from supplying consumers using the telephone system? Does the Minister agree that the monopoly on PABX systems does not fit in with the Minister's views on encouraging competitive Australian industry? If the Minister agrees with that, what action, if any, is he taking to remedy the situation and to end the Telecom monopoly?

—This matter is essentially one for the Minister for Communications. My understanding of the matter is that Telecom no longer has a monopoly in respect of PABX systems and that the monopoly in respect of attachments to the telephone network has been significantly broken down. I believe my understanding to be correct. I hope that it is because it is a position I always supported as Opposition spokesman on telecommunications and have continued to support since. It is the position which obtains in most other countries where the networks, as in Australia, are in public sector hands-something which I also think is highly desirable in the interests of telephone subscribers in a country of this size and geography. In order to check the position, I will consult the Minister for Communications, who I believe shares my view of the matter. I would like to check on the facts.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VIP AIRCRAFT: USE BY MR SIMON CREAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of allegations by the Premier of Queensland that Mr Simon Crean of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has been junketing around Australia at taxpayers' expense and with the approval of the Federal Government? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the facts behind the Premier's latest allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts of the matter as set out by the Minister for Defence yesterday are very straightforward.
