Simon Crean was present on a VIP flight from Canberra to Melbourne on 17 April, as were two leading industry representatives, Mr David Asimus from the Australian Wool Corporation and Mr Leach from the Myer corporation. Members of the Economic Planning Advisory Council who are requested to attend meetings-on an unpaid basis, I add-have their fares paid by the Federal Government. The particular meeting in question was to enable Hu Yaobang to meet with some EPAC members. It was therefore obviously an extremely important meeting in terms of Australia's future economic relations with a major trading partner. The aircraft home was to enable the three men to meet commitments in Melbourne which they would otherwise have been unable to meet.

ANSWER.PARA: The flight was approved by the Prime Minister under exactly the same guidelines as those used in 1982 by a former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, to approve a similar flight on which Mr Crean flew. The Government has not been secretive about this flight in any way at all. As a further demonstration of that, I table a copy of the manifest for this occasion on which four names are listed. Only three names are ticked off as only three gentlemen flew.

Details of VIP flights are tabled in the House of Representatives every six months, in stark contrast with information on the Queensland Premier's VIP flights, which are not tabled at all. It should be said that no aircraft in Australia operate on public funds in a more secretive way than do those of the Premier of Queensland. Not even the Queensland Parliament is told where that aircraft flies, when it flies, why it flies or who flies in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This has nothing to do with the question that was asked. It is yet another gratuitous attack on the Queensland Government. It is another pathetic effort by the most discredited Minister in this place, who used the Royal Australian Air Force against a State of this Commonwealth. It ill sits in his mouth to be talking about the use of aircraft by any government in Australia.
—Order! The question clearly involved comments made by the Premier of Queensland and I think the Minister is in order.
—Thank you, Mr President. Senator Chaney will have to do a damn sight more than take off his glasses-
—Order!
—And grow his eyebrows to ever establish any credibility in this Parliament.
—Order! Will the Minister answer the question.

—The only information given in the Queensland Parliament comes in the Auditor-General's report which gives basic costs and total flying hours only. This usually shows that it averages only seven or eight hours flying time a week at astronomical cost. In 1973 more detailed information was provided for the first and only time in Queensland. That was discontinued after it was identified that about 70 per cent of flights were between Brisbane and Kingaroy with Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen being the only passenger.

ANSWER.PARA: That is not all. Worse is to follow. The Queensland Premier has a long history of not even allowing to be recorded, let alone publicly disclosed, the names of his passengers. In January this year there were reports, which I understand to be reliable reports, that five pilots were sacked from the Government air wing in Queensland because those pilots insisted on logging the names of their passengers in accordance with what they believed to be their obligations under the air navigation regulations. They refused to break the law as they understood it to be and they were sacked after reportedly having reported the matter to the Commonwealth Department of Aviation and expressing their distaste for the administrative procedures involved. And this is the man who is criticising the Federal Government for this particular flight. This is the man whose unctuous preoccupation with law and order creates so much havoc in the affairs of his State and this nation. This is the man whose unctuous, oozing hypocrisy must be unrivalled in the history of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Under standing order 418 I ask the Minister to withdraw those remarks.

—Mr President, I withdraw in deference to your ruling. I conclude by saying that it is a fascinating contrast. The Commonwealth VIP passengers lists are open for the world to see; they are tabled regularly in Parliament and are available for anyone to see at any time employing properly the procedures of the Freedom of Information Act. If the Premier of Queensland is so preoccupied with the use of VIP flights why does he not have a freedom of information Act in Queensland or the kind of procedures in Queensland which would enable us, or anyone else, to see who flies on his particular planes-when, where and why?
—I ask the Minister to table the papers from which he has extensively quoted, including the prepared insults.
—Will the Minister table the papers?
—I do not claim confidentiality in respect of them. I am very happy for the world to see them.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It will put paid to some of the arguments we have listened to here today. I refer the Minister to figures released yesterday by the Commonwealth Statistician which reveal that Australians are moving out of the south-eastern States and heading in their thousands for Queensland. I ask--

—I ask the Minister-if I get a chance-whether he can forward an explanation as to why New South Wales and Victoria both suffered a net loss of 13,580 people and 6,739 people respectively, as opposed to Queensland, which experienced a net gain of 14,203 people from internal migration-that is not including the people who have come from all the other places-in the 18 months to the end of last year. Will the Minister concede that, regardless of the criticism which is levelled by his Government against Queensland in the chamber-we have heard a lot of it today-Australians apparently are content to vote with their feet, so to speak, in their own commendation of the Queensland style of life and politics?

—I have not seen any Australian Bureau of Statistics figures on these matters but I naturally assume that the figures cited by Senator Bjelke-Petersen are correct. I am no interpreter of people's motives. Certainly I would recognise many of the things which appear in Queensland tourist brochures. It is a beautiful State. The sunshine is beautiful and the spaces are nice. Queensland has a lot to commend it. It is a place where-I do not know who it was, although probably it was Tennyson, who said this-'every prospect pleases, and only man is vile'.

—My question, addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, relates to the administration of the Sex Discrimination Act and the Human Rights Commission. I refer the Minister to the mass media debate on sex education conducted by wives of Queensland Government Ministers. Is it a fact there is a wide division between these people in influential positions in the Queensland Government? Is it a fact that the Premier's wife is reported as holding the view that there is no room for sex education and that she has taught her children all she thought they needed to know about it, whilst the wife of the pretender to the Premiership, Mrs Ahern, recognises an urgent need for sex education in schools? In order that Queensland children can get proper education in this area and not have to resort to the processes adopted by the Minister for Racing and Main Roads, who has claimed--
—Order! I ask Senator Bolkus to relate his question to a Federal responsibility.

—Mr President, I will get straight to the guts of my question. In order that the children of Queensland do not have to resort to the processes adopted by the Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Racing, who has claimed to have received his sex education on canvas cinema seats--
—Order! The honourable senator will ask his question or I will ask him to resume his seat.

—Can the Minister say whether there is any facility or avenue under the Sex Discrimination Act or through the Human Rights Commission which could be available to people in Queensland seeking sex education?

—Mr President, I make it clear that this question is certainly not a dorothy dixer. I have seen reports of various opinions on sex education by wives of Queensland Ministers. I make the point, as far as my former Federal responsibilities are concerned, that the Sex Discrimination Act does not require sex education. Whether it will do any good in that environment is a question on which opinions may differ, in any event. There is an office of the Human Rights Commission in Brisbane which has very good publications. I believe there is one on sexism which may give some guidance. Unfortunately, I believe there are no how-to-do-it manuals in the stock of that particular organisation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. I refer to the recent fire in the ceiling of the National Library of Australia. I ask: Firstly, why was fire retardant asbestos material in the ceiling of the Library removed by the Government against the recommendations of Messrs Gersh Majors and Alan Rogers, both experts in occupational health? Their report to the National Capital Development Commission in 1983 stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Removal of the asbestos-containing material, which at present presents no health hazard, does not appear to be a rational decision. . .

Secondly, why was the removal of the material begun when it was placed there in order to avoid the very disaster which recently occurred? Thirdly, why was the material not immediately replaced by new fire retardant material upon removal? Fourthly, is it true that the plastic sheeting which was placed in areas after the removal of asbestos constituted a highly dangerous fire risk, which produced dense smoke which severely hampered the efforts of firemen? Finally, how does the Government justify the expenditure of $850,000 of taxpayers' money for removal of the material which produced no advantage and which arguably resulted in $3.5m to $4m worth of damage?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen's question appears to be based on an article in the Bulletin of 14 May 1985 which refers to conflicting technical reports on the potential benefits of removing the fire retardant asbestos from the roof structure of the National Library building and attempts to relate them to fire damage caused to the roof of the building on 8 March this year. I am advised that after considering all of the available reports on this issue the Government accepted the recommendations of Purse and Furness in 1983 and agreed to remove the asbestos from the National Library building. I believe that as the asbestos was being removed it was being progressively replaced with a new fire retardant material. The cause and effect of the fire at the National Library are still the subjects of a coronial inquiry and report. In these circumstances, it would be improper for me to comment on how the fire occurred. Senator Missen in his question cited an amount of money as the cost of the removal of the asbestos. I will have to seek confirmation and explanation of that figure from the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer the Minister to several media reports in recent days relating to amendments to the Repatriation Act arising from the Treasurer's May economic statement. Can the Minister comment on the accuracy of allegations in some of those reports that war widows will be hit hard by the changes; pension claimants will now have to prove their claims instead of the onus of proof falling on the authorities; and many pensioners will lose their pension entitlements, contrary to the Prime Minister's assurances in his 1984 election policy speech?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably there have been a number of reports regarding amendments to the Repatriation Act arising from the Treasurer's economic statement. I say 'regrettably' because many of those reports, such as the ones alluded to in Senator Foreman's question, contain wildly inaccurate claims regarding these changes, resulting in unnecessary confusion and distress among the veteran community. It must be stressed that no existing repatriation pensioner will lose any of his or her current pension entitlements as a result of these changes. This includes war widows, the totally and permanently incapacitated and other disability pensioners, orphans and dependants. This is totally in accord with the assurance given by the Prime Minister in his 1984 election policy speech.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also important to stress that under no circumstances will any onus of proof be placed on a claimant. Section 25 of the Act guarantees this and this section is not being amended. Also the Department will continue to be responsible for placing before the Authorities any evidence available to it which is relevant to the claim. Where the veteran served overseas, or engaged in direct combat with the enemy in Australia, any future claim for war widow's pension by his widow will be determined under the criminal standard of proof as is the case at present except where the veteran's death occurred 40 years or more after eligible service. In these circumstances a claim will be accepted whenever the authorities are reasonably satisfied that there is a link between service and death. Widows of TPI pensioners will still be granted pensions automatically. Hence, the wives and widows of Vietnam veterans in particular have no cause for concern regarding these changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to the Commonwealth Grants Commission recommendation of a severe funding cut to Tasmania and the visit of the Leader of the Opposition in the Tasmanian Parliament, Ken Wriedt, to his colleagues in Canberra-the Treasurer and Minister for Finance. Was the Tasmanian Leader of the Opposition, Ken Wriedt, successful in his discussions with the Minister for Finance in avoiding cuts to Tasmania. If so, to what extent?
—Wait and see.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to the recent escalation of fighting in Beirut, particularly in the southern suburbs and the Palestinian refuge camps of Sabra, Chatila and Bourj al-Brajneh? In particular, has his attention been drawn to reports of horrifying losses of life and suffering caused to the civilian populations? Is he aware of reports that 25 patients in one hospital have been shot and that doctors and nurses in that hospital have come under attack? Is he aware of the Australian Associated Press reports that four Palestinian registered nurses, who recently trained in Australia, are feared dead in that attack? What action has the Government undertaken in order to assist with the restoration of peace and order in Lebanon? Will the Government protest the outrage against humanity of attacking patients, nurses and doctors in hospitals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am all too aware of the disturbing reports to which the honourable senator refers. The Government is gravely concerned about this most recent escalation of violence in Lebanon and, in particular, the appalling loss of life and suffering amongst the civilian population, both within the Palestinian camps and the surrounding suburbs. The Government repeats its appeal to all sides involved to exercise restraint to ensure the protection of innocent civilians and to look for a peaceful settlement of the problems confronting the country.

ANSWER.PARA: On 23 May I informed the Senate that the United Nations Security Council was expected to consider the situation in Lebanon following the Israeli withdrawal in early June and that Australia would participate actively in that consideration. In response to the current violence in Beirut, Australia, as a member of the Security Council, was party to the statement issued by the Council on 24 May. That statement took note of and fully supported the Secretary-General's statement of a couple of days earlier which appealed to all concerned to make every possible effort to put an end to the violence involving civilians in Lebanon.

While Australia is not a party principal to efforts to promote a solution to the problems of Lebanon, the Government remains very willing to contribute to the greatest possible extent toward the objective of securing peace and reconciliation in that very tragic country. However, it requires all parties directly involved to show a willingness to cease hostilities, to lay down their arms and to come together to negotiate in a spirit of compromise with the aim of re-establishing the peace, independence, sovereignty and unity of Lebanon.

As to the last part of Senator Crowley's question, I am also aware of concerns being expressed about the safety of Palestinian nurses trained in Australia who are believed to have been working in hospitals located in the area of the present fighting. Because of the enormous difficulty in obtaining information on civilians within this area it has not been possible to learn of their welfare. However, I understand that the International Committee of the Red Cross has been asked to make inquiries about their safety and I will keep Senator Crowley as best informed as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to comments made a few days ago by Mr Hugh Morgan, of Western Mining Corporation, when he stated that bureaucratic red tape, overregulation and interdepartmental rivalries were strangling the mining industry? Is it a fact that the Olympic Dam mining project has to disentangle the red tape of no fewer than 20 Federal and 24 State departments, which is costing the company an incredible amount of money, in order to make progress with that development? Is the Minister aware of the Confederation of Australian Industry report which shows that the Federal Government spent $304m between 1978 and 1979 on business regulation and also that the direct cost to the private sector of complying with the regulations was $720m and secondary costs amounted to $360m? Is the Minister concerned about this and what does the Government propose to do to alleviate this horrendous economic disincentive to developing Australian resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to Senator Jessop if I do not accurately answer the last part of his question because I missed some of the figures that he gave. I was not aware of Mr Hugh Morgan's comments about bureaucratic overregulation strangling the mining industry. As is the case with most of these comments, I think that he has probably expressed himself in a colourful way. However, Mr Morgan has made a serious point about the extent of regulation on Australian industry and on the mining industry in particular, and I think there is a lot of substance to what he has said about that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Late last year the Government sought from a wide variety of business organisations some expression of views about the matters which were of most concern to them in terms of the regulatory environment. In the last few weeks we have had contributions on these questions from the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Chamber of Commerce-I think-and various other bodies. There is no doubt that these concerns channel into some particular areas. I recall from my perusal of these papers that one area of express concern was the number of bureaucratic steps that the mining industry had to go through in obtaining mining leases. I use that example by way of illustration.

In response to the discussions which have been going on on this matter, today I announced the establishment within my Department of what is called a business regulation review unit which will be small and will have a watchdog role, working in conjunction with other departments on the question of the removal of unnecessary and outmoded regulations. I know that the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, is addressing this question already in relation to his own portfolio and other Ministers are doing the same. There is a need for some co-ordination of that activity and particularly there is a need for co-ordination of deregulatory activities with State governments. That unit will also serve that function of co-ordinating and liaising with State governments, most of which have now established their own review procedures in respect of industry and business regulation. That unit will serve that purpose. I am not aware of the particular case of the Olympic Dam about which Senator Jessop and I do not know whether the figures he quoted, which I believe to be illustrative of the point he was making, are necessarily relevant or require any response from me.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QUEENSLAND: AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF STATISTICS FIGURES

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today I answered a question from Senator Bjelke-Petersen in which I used a quotation that I said was from Alfred, Lord Tennyson. I do not wish to mislead the Senate. I believe that it is probably correct to say that the quotation was from Reginald Heber.

-by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation concerning an answer given by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who imputed improper motives to my family. He inferred that a dam to provide irrigation on the Mackenzie River at taxpayers' expense was being built especially for my son's property. I would point out that the proposed dam is 45 kilometres away from John's property. He has plenty of water in a branch of the Mackenzie River, which is why he bought the property in the first place. I ask that the Minister retract his statements as they are completely untrue.
—Order! The Minister for Finance has been asked by the Chair to withdraw the statement, and he has done so.

—by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation in case there has been any confusion, because I have been contacted by certain sections of the media on this matter. I want to make clear that last year when a reference was given by this chamber to the Privileges Committee, two of the Liberal members of the Committee were overseas. I refer to Senator Jessop and Senator Missen. It was therefore sought to have two people replace them so that the matter could proceed. The two people were Senator Withers and myself. We replaced those members temporarily for the purposes of one inquiry only, and as soon as that inquiry was over we resigned. They have now been restored to the Committee and there is nothing to it other than that. That is the simple and total fact in relation to it. There is nothing more mysterious than that. While the Committee has reported, a fact which has been noted by the Fairfax Press, the reason for our being on the Committee has been completed, and that was simply to replace Senator Jessop and Senator Missen, who were overseas. They have now been restored to their rightful positions on the Committee.

—by leave-In view of what Senator Peter Rae has said, it is possibly necessary for me to make a personal explanation. I make the explanation for a slightly different reason. I was put on the Privileges Committee instead of Senator Bolkus, for the purpose of this particular inquiry, because he was a member of the Committee inquiring into the matter that led to the reference to the Privileges Committee. Merely because that issue has now been finished, I have resigned from the Committee and Senator Bolkus has returned to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present report 233 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the reports of the Auditor-General for 1982-83 and September 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Report 233 examines the reports of the Auditor-General for 1982-83 and September 1983. Honourable senators will be aware that each year the Committee examines recently published reports of the Auditor-General. Following the tabling of the reports of the Auditor-General for 1982-83 and September 1983, the Committee sought written submissions from 13 departments and authorities in respect of 16 items. This report analyses the responses by departments and authorities to the Public Accounts Committee, explaining the criticisms raised by the Auditor-General in his report. The Auditor-General's Office undertook a review of the fraudulent negotiation of cheques in March to April 1983. The Department of Finance, the Australian Federal Police and departments incurring major expenditure by way of recurring payments-Education and Youth Affairs, Social Security, and Veterans' Affairs-provided advice.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1982-83, the Commonwealth issued in excess of 89 million cheques of which 14,414, a value of at least $2m, are known or suspected to have been fraudulently negotiated. In that year the amount the Department of Social Security recovered was nearly $1.3m and $286,203 was written off. The total amount written off by all departments on fraudulently negotiated cheques was $292,131.

Many of the issues discussed in this report were also raised in the Committee's 232nd report, on the report of the Auditor-General for May 1983, tabled yesterday, dealing with the 'recovery of overpayments' and in the Committee's 213th report, on income maintenance programs.

Approximately 90 per cent of all cheques fraudulently negotiated were issued by the Department of Social Security. However, the Committee found a general lack of case statistics in both the Department of Social Security and the Australian Federal Police. For instance, the Department of Social Security did not classify the dual negotiation of cheques by the payee, that is, the original and a replacement cheque, as fraud. Rather this situation is called an 'improper payment' and is treated as an overpayment. The Department advised that its overpayment records do not differentiate between those for which prosecution action has been taken and those for which it has not. However, in 1982-83, 132,000 overpayments were raised to the value of $46.8m. During the same year, $8.2m was recovered by cash refund and $14.6m was recovered by withholdings from continuing entitlement.

The Committee is of the opinion that the Department of Social Security should take further measures to draw its clients' attention to the obligation to return either the original or the replacement cheque if both are received. The Committee noted that draft guidelines were being prepared by the Department of Finance, for departments, providing an assessment of the likely outcomes of cases referred to the Australian Federal Police of cheques suspected of fraudulent negotiation.

The Committee draws attention to the Bills of Exchange Act, which provides that a person accepting a 'not negotiable' cheque-bank and/or trader-has no better title than the previous holder. As drawer the Department of Social Security claims reimbursement from the person to whose account such a fraudulently negotiated cheque is credited. The Committee is most concerned that, in the majority of cases, recovery of the value of a fraudulently negotiated cheque is obtained from the trader or bank which accepted the cheque.

As was stressed yesterday when Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle tabled the Committee's 232nd report, the Committee firmly believes that the adoption of the direct credit method of payment of benefits and allowances removes the opportunity for fraudulent negotiation of cheques and again recommends that the direct credit method of payment be the principal means of payment of all benefits, with only exceptional cases being paid by other means.

The Committee notes that the Department of Social Security has conducted and implemented a national review on the correct identification of applicants prior to receiving payments from the Commonwealth. The Committee is most concerned that beneficiaries are properly identified prior to becoming entitled to, or receiving, benefits. The Committee also did not accept the arguments put forward by the Department of Education on the use of the direct credit mode and believes that the Department has not addressed itself fully to the identification and recovery of overpayments of student assistance.

The Committee has noted the Auditor-General's continuing interest in the adequacy of departmental procedures for the recovery of outstanding revenue, debts and overpayments. The Committee is concerned at the frequency with which this matter occurs in individual departmental audits and will be looking for evidence that the revised debt management framework cited by the Department of Finance is effective in minimising the problem. There are many other issues covered in this report which I have not raised here. I therefore commend this report to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table and incorporate in Hansard some brief observations in response to the comments by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment (Tribunal's Powers) Bill which I introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
EIGHTH REPORT OF THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS COMMITTEE
Comments by the Committee on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment (Tribunal's Powers) Bill 1985 (Senator Vigor's Bill).
Observations by Senator Vigor

The Committee expresses the fear that the new sub-section 16 (1A) proposed to be inserted in the Broadcasting and Television Act by the Bill might be interpreted as giving the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal a power to censor television programs without any criteria to govern the exercise of that power.
The Committee has not had regard to the following factors.

(1) The Tribunal already possesses an unlimited power of censorship over all radio and television material under section 101 of the Act. If the Tribunal wished to censor programs in the manner envisaged by the Committee it would use that section.

(2) The Bill would merely clarify the powers of the Tribunal under section 16 of the Act to make it clear that the Tribunal can continue to exercise the control over programs under that section which it has been exercising for many years.

(3) Clause 8 of the Bill, which continues in force the standards and conditions already determined by the Tribunal, makes it clear that the purpose of the Bill is to allow the Tribunal to determine standards and conditions of the type which it has already determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on this important piece of legislation today, particularly because a number of my Queensland colleagues withdrew from the list of speakers so that this legislation can be expedited and we can start to get some sanity into the industrial debate in Queensland. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the 800 or more sacked South East Queensland Electricity Board workers who have extremely disadvantaged themselves by taking what I would argue is a principled stand in order to defend the rights of all Australian workers. I say 'all Australian workers' because, although one might say that this is a Queensland dispute, this dispute has far-reaching ramifications. If Australians are prepared to accept the kind of draconian legislation that has been passed by what passes for a Westminster parliament in Queensland, we can be sure that this type of legislation will be adopted by conservative governments in other States in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Georges has outlined already the extreme hardship experienced by SEQEB workers and their families. I am afraid I cannot understand how the so-called Christian Premier of Queensland can use SEQEB workers and their families in a political anti-union strategy. I also place on the record my appreciation, and certainly that of the workers in Queensland, of the extensive financial and moral support of trade unionists and citizens throughout Australia who have been absolutely appalled at the treatment of workers and the trampling of unionists' and citizens' rights by the Queensland minority Government. All those workers have been recognised as being victimised, and this has been supported by many prominent people throughout the country, including eminent churchmen. In particular I mention the Archbishop of Canterbury, who mentioned his surprise-he did it diplomatically, of course-at the way trade unions and workers were treated in the State of Queensland.

I believe that all fair-minded Australians have condemned the industrial legislation introduced by a militant Premier. He is very keen on calling all trade unionists militant, but he has a very dictatorial attitude. If militancy is to be used to describe anyone, I would say it can just as easily be used to describe the Queensland Premier as trade unionists who, after all, are only trying to maintain the hard won rights that they have battled to achieve over a number of years. The Queensland Premier is determined to crush trade unions and he has said that on a number of occasions in the past. It really comes as no surprise that he has manipulated the events of the past three months to his own end. The situation in Queensland has now become a matter of grave concern for all Australians. The Queensland Government, by its actions, has created a potentially very dangerous state of affairs, not just in Queensland but throughout Australia-the implications will spread right around the nation. By rejecting every opportunity to achieve a rational and reasonable resolution to this matter, the Queensland minority Government is placing at risk the successful economic and industrial situation which my Government has worked so hard to achieve-with outstanding results, I might say-over the past two years. In these circumstances the Federal Government has had no option but to act and to act decisively in introducing this legislation to bring this matter to a resolution.

This morning we heard from Opposition speakers, with the exception, of course, of Senator Jack Evans, who said that this legislation is unnecessary. Senator Collard even went so far as to say that the legislation is ridiculous. I could almost agree with Senator Collard and I could almost agree with people who have said that this legislation is unnecessary. Of course it is unnecessary. If we did not have the kind of approach that Queenslanders have to put up with in terms of the approach of their minority Government to industrial relations then, of course, the Federal Government would not have to introduce legislation of this kind. But the Queensland Government has a jack-boot mentality when it comes to industrial relations and to civil liberties. It has provoked confrontation. It has deliberately perpetuated this conflict. It is all very well for members on the other side and for the Queensland minority Premier to cry 'What about State rights? What about our sovereignty?', as was mentioned here this morning. The National Party of Australia and, I am sorry to say, the Liberal Party have had three months in which to deal with this dispute in Queensland. The Federal Government has other things that it would prefer to be doing rather than having to tell Queensland how to manage its industrial relations, but when there is a tyrant like the Queensland Premier who would rather trample-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. It is not correct to describe the Premier as a tyrant. I do not believe that is consistent with standing order 418 and with the general meaning of the word 'tyrant'.
—The Standing Orders protect State members of parliament and members of this chamber. The word 'tyrant' should be withdrawn.
—Mr Deputy President, can I call him a tyrant-like Premier? Would that be better?
—I am not in the negotiating stages of what you may or may not say, Senator Reynolds. I will tell you if you go wrong. You may proceed. Will you withdraw your earlier remark?

—I withdraw the statement that the Premier is a tyrant, but I would say that the Premier of Queensland reminds me of a tyrant. The Queensland minority Premier, who acts like a tyrant, has had three months in which to resolve this dispute of the Queensland Government's own making. There have been numerous opportunities for the Queensland Government to initiate a resolution of this conflict. Of course, the Queensland Government does not want a resolution of this conflict because it finds it convenient for the media to be preoccupied with industrial confrontation in Queensland instead of focusing on some of the Queensland minority Government's problems. The Queensland Government has shown itself to be totally unwilling to seek a rational basis for satisfactory resolution of this dispute. It has been left to the Federal Government to act to restore some sanity into this matter and to take measures which will both address, in a reasonable way, the issues at the heart of the dispute and help to achieve the principal objective of a guaranteed, stable supply of electricity to Queensland. The Queensland Government has abrogated its responsibilities in this area. I believe it has done so for short term political gains.

SPEECH.PARA: The original matters in the dispute in the Queensland power industry have long since been lost sight of, as the Queensland Government has eagerly seized on the dispute as a means of mounting a savage attack on the trade union movement and, of course, on the Federal Government. The Queensland Government's handling of this dispute, its attitude to the State Industrial Commission, its use of legislative powers to override basic industrial and democratic rights and its total refusal to enter into any discussions are, taken together, quite unprecedented in Australia's industrial relations history.

These actions have sought to overthrow all the established and respected industrial relations practices of which we are so proud in this country. It is because of this that the Federal Government has been obliged to introduce this legislation. Conciliation and arbitration have been rejected in favour of a policy of unilateral legislative action to change terms and conditions of employment which were previously agreed by the Queensland Government and to impose sanctions on those who breach the provisions of that legislation. These actions have gone way beyond what was necessary to ensure what we are supposed to be concerned about-the fundamental stable electricity supplies of the State of Queensland.

As I have said, the Queensland Government has repeatedly rejected calls by the Federal Government to enter into discussions with it, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the other parties involved in the dispute. Several weeks ago on television we saw Simon Crean very responsibly almost pleading for a resolution, a coming to terms and the possibility of discussion about the dispute. This Government has offered to convene such discussions in an attempt to resolve the dispute through negotiation of the central issues involved. One essential part of the process of negotiation was that the ACTU and all its affiliates would call off all industrial action against Queensland. In addition, the ACTU was to ensure that dispute settlement procedures were put in place which would effectively guarantee a stable and continuous supply of electricity to Queensland consumers. But still, again and again, the Queensland Government refused to negotiate. Even Mr Ken Williams of the Confederation of Australian Industry stated publicly that the only end possible in the dispute in Queensland was for negotiations to take place. But all these initiatives, whether they have come from the Federal Government, the ACTU or the Confederation of Australian Industry, have been rejected out of hand.

As the Queensland Premier has admitted, he is more interested in prolonging this dispute as a means of attacking the Hawke Government than in achieving a resolution of the issues involved. He is intent on pursuing this absurd course regardless of the cost to Queensland, to Queensland individuals, to the sacked SEQEB workers and their families or to the nation as a whole. Queensland people have every reason to demand an explanation from the Premier of his real motives in this dispute. At this point I take the opportunity to bring to the attention of honourable senators the text of an AM interview conducted on 8 May. The interviewer asked the Queensland Premier:
Will the Government negotiate at any time . . .
The Queensland Premier said:

No, we won't negotiate on it. You know that. I've said it so many times. No way. They can go to doomsday. But there's one or two other things-you know, we've got one or two other things that would be very interesting for them if this proceeds.
The interviewer said:
I suppose there's some feeling that perhaps your interest in bringing the Hawke Government down might be above your interest in resolving this dispute.
The Premier of Queensland, who is so concerned about his State and about the rights of Queenslanders in having their electricity guaranteed, said:
Well my main objective is to get rid of the Hawke Government. That's the main, prime objective.

The following day, on a talk-back radio program on 4BC in Brisbane, what have become known as the Joh tapes were played. They were recorded by a very reputable journalist from the Sydney Morning Herald. That interview spelt out precisely what the Queensland Premier's motives have been all along in precipitating and prolonging this industrial dispute. Although the Queensland Premier was on record as boasting that he had dreamt up this whole charade for the purpose of attacking the Federal Labor Government, that morning he said in an interview that the idea of using the power dispute to bring down the Hawke Government had never entered his thoughts during the confrontation between the Government and the unions. He said:
I never thought of it at all. I want to find out if there was someone who impersonated me on that tape. We have so many people who can take me off these days you never know.

It has since been found that of course that tape was genuine and of course the Queensland Premier had in fact boasted that he was using the power dispute to attack the Federal Government. That is the sort of person and the sort of government we are dealing with in trying to get a resolution. The Queensland Premier is intent on pursuing this absurd course regardless of the cost to Queensland or the nation. Not surprisingly, the union movement has reacted strongly to these moves. I for one am certainly not going to apologise for that. The Queensland trade union movement and the ACTU have been deliberately provoked. Of course they will respond accordingly to protect their rights and the rights of thousands of Australian workers, both now and in the future.

The ACTU, as we know, imposed a prolonged blockade affecting road, rail, sea and air transport to and from Queensland, and we then had the absurdity of the Queensland Government daring to scream that it was being discriminated against. What did the National Party expect from the trade union movement? Queensland had declared war on trade unionism; of course the ACTU would have to respond. Initially the ACTU tried every reasonable course to negotiate, but all realistic overtures were rejected. The Queensland Government did not want a truce; it wanted war with the trade union movement in Queensland, it wanted war with the ACTU and it still wants war with the Federal Government. I wonder what the Queensland National Party would do if draconian Federal legislation were introduced to negate the rights of members of the National Party. Just imagine if I were to introduce a private members' Bill outlawing the National Party in Queensland. It is a lovely idea, but of course it would be a gross infringement of human rights. This is precisely the nub of what has happened in Queensland-just because people disagree with the Government they can be blatantly discriminated against.

This dispute has been deliberately engineered to distract attention from the State's ailing economy and record unemployment. The Queensland Premier knew that a conflict with the Electrical Trades Union and the disruption of power supplies in Queensland would precipitate an uproar in the trade union movement in Queensland and in the ACTU, but of course his motives went so much further. What can the reasonable people of Queensland-and there are thousands and thousands and thousands of them-do to try to deal with the type of draconian legislation that has been introduced in their State? They cannot deal with their minority Government and apparently they cannot even appeal to their Queensland Governor. I now quote from a letter written to the Queensland Governor, Sir James Ramsey, on behalf of those many, many thousands of Queenslanders who are so frustrated about their situation:
We are most disappointed that you have twice refused to meet a delegation of Queensland's five Labor Senators.
This is of particular concern when the Human Rights Commission has found that the Queensland Government is in breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
We draw your attention to its conclusions-

The Human Rights Commission has found that the Queensland Act is in breach of Article 8 of the international Covenant in that it provides for a power in Queensland Electricity Commissioner to direct any person whom he considers capable of carrying out the necessary work, to perform work to provide, maintain or restore a supply of electricity.
Article 8 of the Covenant prohibits forced or compulsory labour except in limited circumstances such as emergency situations, but the Queensland Act is not confined to such situations.

The Commission has also found a breach of Article 22 of the Covenant which deals with freedom of association which includes the right of workers to form and join trade unions for the protection of their interests. Its concern was that the terms and conditions of employment appear to have been unilaterally fixed by the Queensland Government without negotiations between unions and management.

We enclose this report for your urgent scrutiny and trust that, through reading it, you will be made aware of the gravity of the situation in Queensland if this legislation is not repealed or suitably amended.

We do not seek to embarrass you in your present position, but would remind you that, in continuing to deny us an opportunity to discuss our serious concerns about Queensland industrial relations, you are ignoring the opinion of over 550,000 Queenslanders who elected us as Senators.
Furthermore, it is pertinent to remind you that, as ALP Senators we represent some 50,000 more Queenslanders than the entire minority government presently responsible for the current impasse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you represent all Queenslanders or only those who vote Labor?

—Many Liberals are complaining too. Many Liberals are complaining to me about how disgusted they are with the stance that their leader, the puppet Peacock, has taken in this regard. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: It is most depressing for this number of Queenslanders--
including Liberal Queenslanders-

to have been neglected by your high office. This is especially frustrating when we now have full documentation by the Human Rights Commission illustrating that the Queensland Government is out of step with fundamental international democratic standards.

We therefore again seek your reconsideration of our request. We believe that once you have read the report of the Human Rights Commission, you will understand why we have persisted with our request to meet you.

Unfortunately, the Queensland Governor, whose term is about to expire, did not see fit even to comment on the report and he felt that a meeting with us was not required. However, I am sure that his successor, on taking up his duties, will have different views if he has to deal with the sort of agitation and confrontation that are going on in Queensland. Therefore I anticipate that in the near future we will have the opportunity to take our concerns to the new Queensland Governor.

I wish now to quote from the second report of the Human Rights Commission. There seems to be a view on the other side of the chamber that we can just disregard what the Human Rights Commission says. I suppose that nobody on the other side has even bothered to read the Human Rights Commission's report on the industrial legislation package in Queensland; that is, no one except Senator Missen who supports what has been said by the Commission and who said that in the Senate last week. The report states:

An overview of the New Queensland Industrial Legislation The overall effect of the industrial legislation package is to remove electricity supply workers from the jurisdiction of the State Industrial Commission, prohibit strikes and picketing in that industry and set up a separate industrial tribunal for that industry. In addition, the legislation makes it more difficult for unions in Queensland to resort to certain forms of industrial action, e.g. certain types of strikes, which are generally accepted in other States as legitimate union activities; reverses the onus of proof in cases of offences under these Acts; and removes discrimination against non-unionists. The consequence of these changes is that the Queensland unions would come under a less favourable system of industrial relations than obtains in other States or under the Commonwealth industrial relations system.

In the recommendations, as outlined by Senator Jack Evans this morning, it becomes clear that the Human Rights Commission, in regard to a number of provisions in the package of Queensland industrial legislation, recommends that the inconsistencies be brought to the Queensland Government's attention-although while we have the present Queensland Government, that is a waste of time; it is not concerned about human rights-and furthermore, that if the Queensland Government does not repeal these provisions or bring them into line with Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Commonwealth Government should take whatever action is necessary to ensure that any application which the relevant unions may decide to make for registration under the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act is able to be heard without delay by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Furthermore, the Human Rights Commission recommends that, if at the end of 1985 the situation remains unsatisfactory in human rights terms, the Government consider referring appropriate issues to the Commission for further inquiry and report.

I suppose that one of the most depressing parts of the debate here today is the attitude adopted by Liberal senators. I would not expect National Party senators to agree with the intent of this legislation. But I must say that very many people, particularly in Queensland, expect more of Liberal senators and they expect a much more enlightened outlook than the one we have heard this morning from Liberal spokesmen.

In conclusion, I should like to quote from a document given to me by the President of the Queensland Council of Civil Liberties, who is visiting Canberra today. It is titled 'Loss of Liberty-Continuing Breaches of International Human Rights Law in Queensland after the Introduction of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Act'. It is pertinent for us to remember that by passing this legislation-thanks to the Democrats, for their enlightened stand, it will pass-we cannot assume that all problems are over for Queenslanders. I quote from the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties paper:

The new Commonwealth legislation will not however overcome a number of fundamental breaches of human rights caused by the spate of recent Queensland industrial legislation. Australia will continue to be in breach of its obligations under international human rights law in the following areas: Civil conscription; Restrictions on freedom of expression; Alteration of rules of evidence; Restrictions on freedom to associate; Extended definition of 'strike'.

Therefore, even after the passage into law of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill, Queensland citizens will continue to experience a loss of civil liberties of sufficient gravity to amount to breaches of Australia's obligations under international law. Therefore, it is argued that a national Bill of Rights is long overdue to entrench into Australia's domestic law those fundamental human rights which we have promised to uphold under international law. I certainly look forward to the time when we will introduce a Bill of Rights, because such a Bill is long overdue, particularly in a State such as Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —History is replete with governors and governments who were unable to see the real issues that confronted them. From Roman times, with Nero, who fiddled while Rome burnt, through to the French Revolution and Marie Antoinette talking about giving the poor and the needy cake, we have had governors and governments who were unable to see the issues that were staring them right in the face. To that long list we now add the Australian Labor Government in the Federal Parliament today. It cannot see that Australia is in crisis, that we have a dollar that is worth 66c and is falling fast. It cannot analyse the relationship between the price of the dollar, the judgment the world puts on it, and its own incompetence in governing this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) chose not to answer a question of mine on what future action the Government would take as the crisis deepened-cowardly, he ran; would not face the issue. Yet he is one of the few people in the whole of the Labor Government who have the intelligence to realise that there is a crisis facing this country. Like his colleagues, he is running away from the issue. We cannot run away from such problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. About a minute ago Senator MacGibbon referred to Senator Button and used the word 'cowardly'. I think that that word should be expunged from the record.
—Order! I ask Senator MacGibbon to withdraw the word 'cowardly'.

—Pusillanimous, then. I withdraw. I was saying that the Government did not have the intelligence to realise that a crisis is now facing Australia. The reason for the 66c dollar we have relates to what this Government is doing. It relates to the defence cuts it is making in this country, to the way it is breaching our alliances with our tried and trusted friends, to the financial practices it is following, and, above all, to the industrial relations practices it is following. The judgment of its peers is that this is an incompetent Government. That is why the Australian dollar is not worth $US1 on world markets; it is worth US66c.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the last item I mentioned-industrial relations practices-and I want to relate those practices to the lack of confidence of our peers overseas in the way this country is being governed. The biggest reform we face today is in our archaic industrial relations. Tax reform is important, but it is not in the same league as fixing the industrial relations problems of this country. We have a falling standard of living. We have a crippling debt burden. We have a crippling overseas debt that has to be serviced overseas. We have very high unemployment. We have declining production. All these problems are avoidable and unnecessary. We have a great work force in Australia-a work force in which I have every confidence, a work force that can compete on a productivity basis with any other work force in the world, provided it is given the chance to work. What is more important, we do not have any shortage of people in this country who want to work. They are happy to do a full day's work for a full day's pay. They want the opportunity to get out and work and to improve themselves and the economic lot of this country.

What is happening? We are being tied up by rules and regulations. People who want to work and people who want to employ them and use their productivity for the benefit of themselves and the community are denied that chance by the overregulation of the Australian community, and most importantly, by the archaic union system in this country, which imposes a monopoly power on the supply of labour through the union movement. It is a totally discredited system. It is totally outdated and irrelevant. The Australian community recognises that it is outdated. The Australian community now recognises that the basic right of a person is to work on terms which are mutually acceptable to both the employer and the employee. The Australian work force no longer wants the intervention of an impersonal third party, in the form of a union, to regulate the conditions under which it works. We have moved to a condition of voluntary unionism in this country, and the sooner governments, at both State and Federal level, recognise this the better our industrial relations will be.

All governments, whether of the Liberal-National Party or of the Australian Labor Party, while they have given lip service in bygone times to voluntary unionism, have in effect practised de facto compulsory unionism. Those days are gone. It always amazes me that the Labor Party, with its equal opportunity legislation, gender equivalence or whatever is the buzz of the time, has never dealt with the problem of human rights in relation to unionism-whether one wants to be a member of a union or not. I speak with some personal experience on this because I am one of the few in this chamber who were unionists at one time in their working careers. I have seen the operation of the union movement from the inside, and at some time I will enlighten the community on some of the sharp practices that are so much the stock in trade of a minority of officials who control the union movement.

There is a feeling in this country that we will no longer support compulsory unionism, but the right to withhold labour is not at challenge. The community has matured to the point of view that, while the right to withhold labour on a permanent or temporary basis should not be restricted, someone who has the qualifications should be allowed to do the job that the person on strike refuses to do. There are two consequences of that: Primary boycotts are no longer tenable, and nor is the secondary boycott concept. The primary boycott, the picket line, as shown in Queensland over the last few months, is not acceptable to the community. The licence for thuggery and bullying that the picket line gives those on strike to stand over their colleagues who are prepared to work under the employer's terms is no longer acceptable. Secondary boycotts, strikes by people who are not involved in the actual industrial dispute and who say 'You cannot work for the persons at the centre of the dispute' or 'You cannot supply goods or services to them', are also no longer tenable. Almost 10 years ago the Fraser Government passed section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. That has had the support of the majority community for the time it has been on the statute books. If we need any further confirmation of the untenable position of secondary boycotts we have only to look at the failure of the blockade of Queensland in recent months that the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Federal Labor Government tried to impose on the people of Queensland. It has not worked and it will not work because community values and hopes have moved away from that sort of nonsense.

Another change in the community is the belief that essential industries are entitled to strike-free performance from their employees. Society today is far too complex and interdependent for some small minority group, usually a very well paid group earning two or three times the average weekly wage, to hold society to ransom. Society expects that basic services such as electrical supply, water supply and transport will be available on demand irrespective of any circumstances, as it is in most civilised countries in the Western world. Above all, there is recognition that we all live under the rule of law and that unions are not an exception to that rule.

At present we live under the practice that unions are outside any legislation on the statute books. They can do what they like. They can damage society in any way at all without being held accountable for their actions. Society is no longer prepared to tolerate that. It is against this background of changed community attitudes that the Labor Party in 1985 brings in this antediluvian legislation. It is redolent of the worst excesses of union power. It is myopic and sectional. It will be opposed clause by clause by the Opposition because it is totally irrelevant and dangerous to Australia in 1985. This legislation is unconstitutional, it does not have a national purpose and it does not have anything ethical or honest about it. It is dangerous and irrelevant. It stems from a government that is beholden to the union movement, a union movement which is not elected. It puts up its officials, usually through rigged ballots within its own body, but it is answerable in no sense at all to the people of Australia.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions saw this Bill a week before it was presented to the House of Representatives. The ACTU was the arbiter of what sort of legislation came into this place. It looked at the legislation a week before the elected representatives of this country. The ACTU approved it clause by clause. The legislation was what it wanted, so that is what the people of Australia will get. There is nothing unusual about a Labor government being beholden to the union movement. Of course the ACTU sees the Budget Papers. Of course it is included in the preparatory work for the Budget. It is included in the summit conferences. The biggest group represented in the summit conference on tax reform will be the ACTU. This Bill sets out to reinforce the monopoly power of unions to control the work force.

This legislation is unconstitutional because it deals only with Queensland. Section 51 of the Constitution states that the Commonwealth has power to legislate on conciliation and arbitration matters that go beyond the boundaries of the State. But this matter does not go beyond the bounds of Queensland. It started in Queensland, it was fought in Queensland, it was resolved in Queensland and it is now a dead issue in Queensland. It does not involve any other part of Australia, except in the sense that the Labor Government was prepared to support the blockade and the hit list by the unions which belong to the ACTU. It is unconstitutional for the Government now to legislate on matters over which it does not have power.

I said that it was an unethical Bill. It is an unethical Bill, it is a face-saving Bill and it is a dishonest Bill. It is face-saving because, as I have told this chamber on repeated occasions, it was Mr Kelty, acting on orders from Mr Dolan, from the ACTU and from the Federal Cabinet, who stabbed the strikers in Queensland in the back. He pulled the plug on them and pulled off the strike in February this year. Now the Government is trying to cover up that and save face by bringing in some sort of protective legislation.

This legislation is dishonest because this Government has created the impression for those Electrical Trades Union of Australia members in Queensland and for unionists generally in Australia that they will get their jobs back. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission does not have any powers of reinstatement. These people will not get their jobs back regardless of how much the Australian Democrats get into bed with the Labor Party in order to pass this iniquitous legislation. There is no sympathy for those people who do not have jobs in Queensland because they were given the opportunity to go back and work for the electrical authority. They chose not to do so. That was their decision: We are quite happy to let them live with it.

This matter points up the hypocrisy of the ACTU. It is carrying on about a couple of hundred people who refused to go back to work, but it is not one bit concerned about the tens or hundreds of thousands of unemployed people in the whole of Australia. It is not interested in that at all. Let me now deal with some of the mythology about the strike. One of the very few correct statements that have been made by people on the other side of politics can be found in the second reading speech of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in the other place when he introduced this legislation. I will quote two sentences from the speech in which he said:

The unions involved in the initial dispute have not been beyond blame. Indeed, by rejecting an order from the Queensland State Industrial Commission directed at resolving the dispute, the unions involved helped lay the groundwork for subsequent moves by the Queensland Government.

Quite simply, the unions failed to obey the law. That is the situation in a nutshell. All the mythology we have heard from many people in an attempt to cover up for the union disobedience will not wash at all with the public at large. The Queensland Government took the appropriate action at the time and it exercised powers which are properly constituted in it as a State government. The Queensland Government legislated to protect the community and it did that very well. It started with the basic tenet that it is the right of an elected government to govern on behalf of all the people. There is nothing in the legislation that was put down in Queensland that any law abiding unionist or union leader has to fear. The legislation simply protects the public against an arrogant misuse of union power. It protects the rights of taxpayers who contribute to the electricity generation services which employ these workers and provides a reliable and continuous electricity supply.

Other pieces of legislation relate to the guaranteeing of that supply. It is quite wrong for people to talk about the rights set down by the Human Rights Commission or the International Labor Organisation being infringed by this legislation. When the Government was on a money saving spree a couple of weeks ago it should have disbanded the Human Rights Commission. It comprises an opportunistic group of people who support the extreme left of Australian politics. The fact that the Human Rights Commission could react within a matter of days to the request by the Labor Party that it look at the legislation in Queensland, given the work load it has, demonstrates its political bias and who its lords and masters are. It serves no purpose at all for the Australian community and ought to be disbanded. Its opinions need not be considered in this place.

A few specific clauses need to be referred to. Clause 4 and clause 6 relate specifically to Queensland. They propose that the State authorities and departments come under the power of this legislation and the Federal Parliament. That is wrong and unconstitutional. Clause 8 removes the discretionary power from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in respect of determining that a dispute would be better handled at a State level or that it should not be handled at all because of the public interest. Clause 9 compels reference of a dispute to the Full Bench and denies the right of a hearing before a single commissioner or an appeal from an award. Both clauses 8 and 9 again act specifically against State powers and State legislative processes and are therefore wrong.

Finally, what is the view of the people we represent? What does the Australian public think of all of this? It is old history now. It is over five months since the trouble started with irresponsible union activity in Queensland. That is long enough for the people of Australia to have taken a sober, considered view on what has happened. The overwhelming feeling of the people of Australia is support for the actions of the Queensland Government. The new mood in Australia to which I referred previously has no truck at all with irresponsible unionists. The Australian people believe that irresponsible union leaders have gone too far, not only on this issue but also on a whole variety of other issues. The Federal Government, the Labor Party, cannot recognise this fact. The Queensland Government can and did.

We are witnessing today an historical turning point in industrial relations in Australia. We have been on a one-way street. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has been used and abused, intimidated and suborned by reckless union leaders screwing the Australian community more and more over the years, causing suffering, a loss of money and a loss of jobs, buying peace by always upping the ante until the community gave in to the selfish, sectional demands of the union leaders. Today we see a change. We saw one State government, out of the seven governments in Australia, stand up to this gross abuse of power, recognising that Australia needs a reasonable and fair approach to its industrial relations. We want to live in a just and humane society and not be governed by a bunch of selfish bullies. For those reasons, the Opposition will fight this Bill clause by clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened very carefully to this debate. This matter would not have come before this Parliament were it not for a series of historic mistakes. Although not historic, the comments of Senator MacGibbon, who spoke previously, are mistaken in almost every respect. In his attack on the principles of preference for unionists, on the conditional principles of the right to strike and on the principle of the right to work with freedom, Senator MacGibbon has been in error.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out with some 20 years of experience in the trade union movement that there are certain principles which are important to orderly industrial progress. Firstly, orderly industrial progress and good industrial relations are best served by encouraging-not smashing-effective, responsible trade unions to work in the best interests of their members and by encouraging members to participate fully in union affairs. If the Electrical Trades Union of Australia members have learnt nothing else from this dispute in Queensland, they know that in the future it is in their best interests to become actively involved in the affairs of their union and not to leave things to their leaders. Industrial relations are best served by that type of approach to unionism, including preference for unionists under those circumstances. Secondly, the power of trade unions to contribute effectively and responsibly to orderly industrial progress depends on the co-ordinated and self-disciplined action of union members. Thirdly, the rules of individual trade unions registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act contain self-disciplinary provisions.

I do not want to go into the aspect of whether we are dealing with a State registered industrial union or a federally registered industrial union. The Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill 1985 deals with a federally registered industrial union. Likewise, a central trade union organisation, such as the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the State labour councils, has rules for the conduct and control of industrial disputes, with its own internal disciplinary procedures. These procedures although disregarded and ignored initially in this case, are designed and are necessary to achieve the objects of the unions in a united and co-ordinated manner with the least possible disruption. In the initial stages the problem was that those rules for the conduct and control of industrial disputes were not observed. The Government was moved in this official document, in this second reading speech, to castigate the ETU for its failure to observe the proper procedures in the early part of the dispute. Much of the blame for the mess that the members of the union have got into rests with the leaders of the ETU and their ignorance and failure to observe the proper procedures at the beginning of the dispute. That is well known among the whole of the trade union movement. As I said, the Government has seen fit to include a comment about that in the second reading speech of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes).

Let us come to the wide-ranging attack Senator MacGibbon launched against the right to strike. I believe everyone would concede that there is not an uninhibited right to strike. Indeed, if we consider the question of rights we have to acknowledge that there are not many fundamental, absolute rights in the world. In fact, rights really are claims which are generally made when the interests of the people concerned are in question or under attack by other people or other interests. Rights are really a manifestation of a more basic principle. Is Senator MacGibbon saying that that manifestation or claim is not proper when the key interests of employees-that is, people who are trying to make a living for themselves and their families-are under attack? That is the situation we have reached in this dispute.

As I read the laws passed through the Queensland Parliament, they embody very cohesively and coherently the common law and the old master and servant relationship that preceded the introduction of conciliation and arbitration systems in the States and in the Commonwealth. Is it fair to say, as Senator MacGibbon said, that nothing in those laws should give any concern to a law-abiding citizen. On my analysis of what is being said in these laws, it is not fair to say that. As I said, the laws incorporate the old master and servant approach, which predates the system of conciliation and arbitration. They override rights under existing awards. They were consent awards. They were not awards arbitrated by the President of the Queensland Industrial Commission, but awards relating to wages and working conditions, which in fact were agreed to by the South East Queensland Electricity Board and approved of by the Queensland Government. The Queensland Government said, when it introduced its legislation: 'Irrespective of those rights which you have under those awards, you will return to work now under conditions passed by this Parliament, under legislation introduced by this Government'.

The legislation required those persons to go back to work; imposed increased hours of work; required them to sign away their right to strike-I will come to that question when I deal with essential services shortly-inserted a no strike contract; abolished union preference and required the declaration of the names of work mates who supposedly instigated industrial action. I ask the Senate whether that truly gave to the men concerned a freedom of choice, as was suggested by Senator MacGibbon. When the old master and servant legislation was tested in the United Kingdom the courts then overrode the legislation and indicated that it was biased towards the master. The classic statement of the court was that necessitous men are not free. It is unfair to say to the workers concerned that they have a choice of servile impotence or of not eating.

I believe that this legislation is important. It is in the interests of not only the employees and the sacked workers of the SEQEB but also society as a whole to ensure that we do not go back to the dark ages in which there was an enormous imbalance in favour of the master.

It would have been much better had the union at that stage agreed to the recommendation of the President of the Queensland State Industrial Commission. The Government has said that it is certainly not to blame, but we cannot bury our heads in the sand. An application was made by the ETU. From memory, a log of claims was served by the ETU on 19 February, at the request of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. One of the less well known ironies of all of this was that it was not received by the SEQEB for another three weeks because of the postal union bans in support of the claims. The log of claims was ultimately received by the SEQEB and a hearing was scheduled by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The other party to be served was an electricity authority in the Northern Territory. The hearing was held before Commissioner Brown. After quite a lengthy hearing and substantial documentation-the transcript runs into many pages-Commissioner Brown found that a dispute existed. Senator MacGibbon volunteered that, in his opinion, the finding of the dispute was unconstitutional. I assume that will be tested before the High Court of Australia. I understand there is a challenge to the High Court by the Queensland Government. The finding was challenged by the Queensland parties before the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

One basis of the challenge was the question of whether the claim-motivated, as it was alleged to have been, to extract employees from the State jurisdiction and place them under Federal jurisdiction-was sufficient to create an industrial dispute. If one goes back to the Cohen case that argument on its own would not be sufficient. Clearly there was a purpose, it was expressed by the ETU's Federal decision. The workers desired to pursue their log of claims and achieve aspects of it in the form of an award by the Commission. Included in that updated log of claims were such matters as questions relating to the termination of employment, technological change and the like. The Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission upheld Mr Commissioner Brown's findings of a dispute.

This legislation attempts to speed up the process of conciliation and arbitration or, more directly, to speed up the process of arbitration. To be quite frank, I do not like this measure but at this stage I cannot see any other way of handling a situation which goes to the very heart of industrial relationships in Australia. I recognise that it is a matter which has been dealt with by the State tribunals and the Federal tribunal; it is a matter with which this Parliament has previously dealt and with which it is entitled to deal. I am quite confident that the presidential members and other members of the Commission do not particularly like the legislature putting them on a fast rail track, as this legislation does. However, I am sure that that will not interfere with their judgment. I believe that the Full Bench that hears the dispute after this legislation goes through the Parliament will not be influenced in its integrity by expressions in this chamber.

What is the other way of dealing with the matter? The other way of dealing with it was suggested by the Human Rights Commission.
