I am glad to say that even the Government rejected that approach because it would have encouraged this industrial matter being launched well and truly into the political arena and it would have necessitated the Government invoking its foreign affairs power to deal with what was essentially an industrial dispute. I am pleased to note that the Government has rejected that approach because it could backfire on not only the States and the Commonwealth but, more particularly, ordinary rank and file unionists throughout the length and breadth of this country, depending upon what conservative governments of the future may do when coming to agreements with foreign powers. It would have established an enormous precedent which would have backfired against the ordinary workers of this country. I do not blame the Human Rights Commission for its major recommendation. That recommendation was really to enhance its powers and presumably to give it more staff to get going and to deal with these matters. The Commission is entitled to do that, but I am happy to see that the Government has not gone along that path.

The Government had a very difficult decision to make and it has made that decision. I believe that there is no certainty that what is proposed in this legislation and what emerges from it-an early hearing by a Full Bench of the issues involved, depending on what happens in the High Court-will overcome the individual problem. I believe that people in Queensland, from the Premier down, should look at other ways of solving this problem. Any system of conciliation and arbitration depends on the desire of those who are parties to the system to see that it works. Unless that desire is there it will not work. A number of suggestions have been made over a period as to ways and means of overcoming the problem. I do not know much about it, but there was one suggestion made by someone called Russell, I think, to have a co-operative of various electrical tradesmen formed to do some work for the South East Queensland Electricity Board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Non-union and sub-contract labour.

—It would not necessarily be non-union labour. There are many co-operatives in the world, some of them very effective, which have 100 per cent union labour. I raise this as a simple suggestion. One must think of other ways in conjunction with this way, because there is no guarantee that this way will work, or that it will provide the workers concerned with the true freedom of choice which is their right and which has been taken away by the measures adopted in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I have deliberately gone out of my way not to castigate anyone in Queensland. One can understand the feelings of people who have had their power cut off. That is another question. People do have the right to manifest a claim in respect of power supplies because of their particular circumstances-whether it be old ladies going up in lifts, hospitals or workers in the other industries which have been closed down. A lot of ordinary workers found themselves out of work because of the power cuts. That was because the fundamental union principle was not observed, the principle that if a person goes out on strike and puts me out of work, he has the responsibility first to consult me through the general trade union movement. The ACTU came into the dispute, and it has extracted a number of guarantees from the individual union. One of those guarantees relates to this important aspect of the continuity of supply of electricity to Queensland consumers.

I remember giving a speech on this subject way back in 1961. I tried to find the speech in my files, but my files being what they are I could not find it. One thing that concerns me is that many people, particularly in the electricity industry, are no better off-in fact they are worse off-when they go under Federal awards. The conditions under State awards in electricity authorities are better by and large than under Federal awards. That is one problem that is now emerging. But the real essence of the problem is to restore this whole issue to where it belongs-in the hands of independent arbitral authorities, out of politics, where the issues can be addressed and where justice can be ensured, always, as the Full Bench is required to do, having regard to the common good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill and the defeat that looms for this Bill, given the expressed voting intentions of those who have spoken, represents a clear blow to the hopes of those Australians who wish to see industrial relations change. I do not think there is very much doubt that the great bulk of the Australian people are sick to the back teeth of the industrial relations system in Australia. I have no doubt at all that they do not support the intervention of trade unions to disrupt essential services. I think there is no doubt that they would see the move by the Queensland Government to prevent that disruption as being in the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The essential division between those who will vote for this legislation and those who will vote against it is that those who will vote for it, in particular the Labor members in this place, believe that the present system is a good one and should be preserved notwithstanding its faults. That is to be taken against the view of the Liberal and National parties that there are many features in the present system that are not in the national interest. In between us of course are the Australian Democrats, whose votes on this occasion unfortunately will decide this issue. I can only say that they appear to be expressing in-principle agreement with the Opposition, but to be casting their votes in the opposite direction.

This is an important debate with considerable implications for the industrial relations system. For that reason there has been a great deal of pressure for people to have the opportunity to speak on this subject. I acknowledge the fact that in particular Opposition Queensland senators who are not speaking in this second reading debate are taking that course because of the pressure of time and in deference to the need to deal with this and other legislation before the Parliament rises. Senator Sheil, Senator Parer, Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Boswell all expressed a desire to speak in this debate. There has not been the opportunity for them all to speak, and I acknowledge the fact that they made room for me to make some contribution to the debate.

What this Bill is about is essentially to take from the hands of the Queensland Government its ability to control some quite important events in that State. The Bill's aim will be to reduce the power of the Queensland Government to control its own authorities which are supplying electricity. The Bill will do that by removing what influence and control the Queensland Government might have over the industrial relations system to which that industry is subject. The Bill will accelerate the transmission of the relevant trade unions and relevant awards into the Federal area to make them solely the subject of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and will make quite clear in the legislation itself that the State arbitral authorities are to have no jurisdiction. That essential feature of the Bill-its buttressing of the present moves by the trade union movement to reduce the influence of the Queensland Government in these matters-does not have the support of the Opposition. We do not believe that it is in the national interest.

This legislation is part of a determined effort by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and its servant, the Hawke Government, to retain the old ways of doing things in the industrial relations area. I think it ought to be acknowledged by every honourable senator in this place that that is not the will of the Australian people. In many important respects people do not wish to retain the old ways of doing things. Most people are sick of it and want change. They want an end to the abuse of trade union power which has bedevilled us far too often.

To relate that quite general statement to the issues which face us in Queensland and the issues which are touched on by this legislation, I would say that it is without dispute that the people want an end to trade union control over whether sub-contractors are employed by an authority or any other employer. They want an end to the disruption of essential services. This has been particularly marked in Queensland but other consumers around Australia have felt the burden too from time to time. I do not think there is any doubt that the Australian people want an end not just to the illegal blockading of businesses and individual industrial operations but to the blockading of a State, which is what we saw quite recently.

I have absolutely no doubt that the people of Australia want an end to the concept of a hit list whereby the ACTU can draw up a list of 50 or more companies which are lawfully going about their business in Australia and say that those companies will be subject to trade union sanctions-sanctions which are illegal, but that illegality stands for nothing. The companies cannot bring action because they would be subject to further abuse and the Government will not act on their behalf. So we have a tolerance of illegal activity. I do not believe that the Australian people support that for a moment. Perhaps most importantly the Australian people generally would support an end to an arbitration system which too often provides for one-sided obligations. It permits the employers to be bound by awards and makes those awards enforceable against employers but leaves individuals and trade unions free to flout awards when it suits their convenience.

I mention those as just some of the aspects of the present system which I believe need change and which the Australian people would want to see changed. This legislation represents a barrier in the way of some changes being effected. It is quite clear that the Hawke Government wants to retain the old way of doing things in the industrial relations area. I have enormous respect for many people who are engaged in the field of industrial relations. I listened to what Senator Harradine had to say as he has been active in that field. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), who has returned to the chamber, carried on a legal practice which largely touched on that field. I can understand that many people would see many features of the system that they want preserved.

I would like to see some acknowledgment on the part of the Government, the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine that some very major features of the old way of doing things need to be changed. The Queensland Government wants change and it has set about seeking it. I believe that there is absolutely no doubt that public opinion and time are on the side of change in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —We want to go forward, not backwards.

—I do not wish to be distracted by the bleating of Senator Jack Evans who, throughout this session, his final session in the Senate, has said that his principles say one thing but his vote will say another. We have had it again in this debate. I really do not appreciate any intervention by Senator Evans in a debate which is of some national importance.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not peculiarly the view of the Liberal Party of Australia or the National Party of Australia that the time has come for change. I was somewhat surprised when the Canberra Times printed a lengthy leading article on 16 April in favour of change in these areas. I would like to quote from the Canberra Times because we have had talk of civil liberties in this area and we have had to listen on two occasions to one honourable senator from Queensland talking about civil liberties in this area. I do not refer to Senator Georges, to whom I listened with more respect. Let me quote from the Canberra Times, because I think the quote is apposite and I do not think it comes from a newspaper which has a reputation for being right wing or reactionary. The article states:

Prominent churchmen who have spoken out in favour of the right to strike and the threat to civil liberties posed by Queensland's five new Acts would do well to contemplate the extent to which existing industrial law and practice have eroded civil liberties in Australia. Both the Queensland Government and the trade-union movement are authoritarian: that, however, should not be allowed to conceal the fact that in this instance the Government is curtailing some liberties of a minority of its populace to protect some liberties of the majority-including the right to work. The positive, protective aspects of the new laws have not been acknowledged.
A little later the leading article said:
In practice, the unions have exploited their privileges, and the Queensland Government is now withdrawing them.
On the day before, the Australian Financial Review made similar comments in a leading article. I quote a few words of that leading article:

At present, however, the unlimited right to strike or other industrial action while unions are given special legal privilege and while no sanctions can be enforced for the breach of an award gives disproportionate power in the community to unions.
A little later, it said:

The status and privilege of unions as at present exists, is not a fundamental aspect of democracy, nor need limitations upon strike action to protect the community be treated as tantamount to an attack on political liberty and free speech. Non-unionists have their rights, too.

We have a situation where what is fundamentally at issue is that the Government is insisting that industrial relations in Queensland be cast back along the old ways; that we go back to a system where we will get all sorts of fancy undertakings, all sorts of fancy conferences and all sorts of fancy decisions, but we will not get a binding commitment from the trade unions concerned to perform their part of the bargain. I will come later to Senator Jack Evans's extraordinary reliance on a telex from the ACTU. I am very glad that Senator Evans is not a lawyer, because I would not rely upon him as a lawyer if his interpretation of that telex is that he has binding commitments.

Senator Reynolds, the Queensland senator to whom I referred earlier, sent a quite one-sided reference to the Human Rights Commission. Senator Reynolds did not ask the Human Rights Commission to advise on whether the rights of the people of Queensland, her constituents, have been breached by the Electrical Trades Union. Senator Reynolds seems to have been strangely silent about the human rights of Queenslanders, until the Bjelke-Petersen Government acted to require the trade unions to act in a different way. Senator Reynolds sent a completely one-sided reference to the Human Rights Commission. The Human Rights Commission seems to have acted on her reference, and I can only say that it is a great pity for the reputation of that body that it was not able to encompass the wider issues of this debate in its reports which have been referred to in this place.

Senator Reynolds did us one service in her speech; she referred to a debate between Mr Vince Lester, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Affairs in Queensland, and the putative leader of the trade union movement in this country, Simon Crean. I wish that everyone in Australia had seen that debate. If someone had told me that the new Minister for Employment and Industrial Affairs in Queensland, Mr Lester, would do Simon Crean like a dinner on a television debate, I think I would have disputed him, but Mr Lester asked Mr Crean the unanswerable question. Mr Lester said: 'How can you deliver? Mr Crean, I cannot take any notice of you because you have said these things in the past and you cannot deliver'. The reality is that, just as Senator Reynolds said, Simon Crean was left on his knees begging for talks. That was the position which Simon Crean had to adopt in that debate. It was a pathetic performance from the person whom we are told will be the next leader of the trade union movement in Australia. The reality is that Vince Lester had Simon Crean against the wall because Simon Crean knew that he could not deliver. That is the sad fact of the matter. What we are asked for is lots of talk; there is no suggestion of binding commitments on the ACTU or, indeed, on the trade union movement. Mr Lester, I believe, made a signal contribution to the debate on that subject on that particular television segment, because he brought out the impotence of the ACTU to deliver on promises which in fact have been repeated today by its agent for the day, Senator Jack Evans, Democrat, Western Australia.

I refer to what Senator Georges said. I say to Senator Georges that undoubtedly he put his body where his mouth is. He has been prepared to undergo very considerable personal inconvenience and travail in support of the views which he put. I pay respect to the sincerity of Senator Georges in this matter, even though I believe him to be grievously wrong in his approach to it. He talked about what has occurred being a gross overreaction with serious consequences for industrial relations. I can only say to him that what has happened in Queensland is the inevitable reaction to far too long a period of trade union lawlessness, blackmail and behaviour of a type which most Australian people find repugnant.

I listened very carefully to Senator Georges when he expressed concern about the possible emergence of fascism in Australia. I, like him, have looked at the history of the emergence of fascism and he, I think, is at one with every other senator in his repugnance for that doctrine. I say to Senator Georges that, on my reading of history in Germany in the 1930s, there is far more in the behaviour of the Builders Labourers Federation from time to time and in the behaviour of some of the less savoury elements of the trade union movement which is akin to the behaviour of the brown shirts than one will find in the behaviour of the Queensland police or other Queensland authorities. I think that there are very serious problems for Australia in those ratbag elements of the trade union movement which inflame the populace against the genuine rights of trade unions and which I think have been a very nasty feature of Australian society for the whole of my political life. One can talk endlessly to builders, to small businessmen running transport businesses and to many people who are the subject of intimidation, victimisation and unsavoury behaviour and find that they have no legal remedy of which they can avail themselves. It is in that sort of behaviour, which I think has been a very unhappy feature of so much trade union activity, that we see the real threat to Australia.

It may be true that this legislation will, as Senator Georges said, lead to the conference table and provide an environment for reinstatement. My own view is that that is unlikely to happen. It seems to me to be something which is almost impossible at this stage. Unfortunately, the whole of Senator Georges's speech was really predicated on the idea that doing it the old way is good enough. With the greatest of respect to Senator Georges, doing it the old way is no longer good enough and is no longer acceptable to the Australian people.

Senator Jack Evans made a speech which told us what will happen to this legislation. This legislation will be passed and so we will, in time, know whether what Senator Evans has told us is true or false. Senator Evans will not be here to extract a reckoning, but no doubt he will watch the future of this matter with very great interest, as we will. Senator Evans said that the Democrats would not allow the passage of the Bill unless there was no resumption of the blockade and a no strike clause in the award. He tabled a telex which he said gave a watertight guarantee of the situation. I must say that if Senator Evans thinks he has a watertight guarantee from the ACTU he accepts words as having a very strange meaning indeed. The telex from the ACTU which he tabled simply sets out:
The immediate issues of priority for the ACTU in settling the current Queensland disputes are as follows:
The telex then sets out the priorities, the first of which reads:
The re-instatement of the sacked SEQEB workers who are the real victims of this dispute.

It is common ground that that will not be settled; that will not be achieved by this legislation. So that priority issue is obviously not dealt with by this legislation. It then states that the restoration of a workable industrial relations environment is one of its priority issues. Then there are other matters which are dealt with. It states:
The ACTU decision to suspend industrial action arises from the initiative of the Federal Government. The ACTU will have to review its position if this initiative is thwarted.

I am not quite sure what initiative might be regarded as being thwarted in the future by the ACTU. Obviously, we will not have the reinstatement of the sacked workers, so that would appear to be one point at which the initiative will be thwarted. It seems that what we have here are more of those words from the ACTU on which the ACTU has never been able to deliver in the past. What we have here is a very leaky raft. What the Australian Democrats have decided to do is to shove the Australian people out on this leaky raft. They had better hope that it floats.

The second telex which was tabled came from the combined mining unions and that contains a nice unequivocal assurance again to the Australian Democrats. It says that the combined mining unions will cancel their conference. It continues:
However, if actions are precipitated against coal mining workers by either the Government or industry employers, the C.M.U. would be left with no alternative but to defend ourselves.

I do not know just what sort of action might be precipitated against coal mining workers by the Government or industry employers in the future. All I can say is that, if that is an assurance on which the Australian Democrats are prepared to rely, that is not an assurance on which the Opposition is prepared to rely. The best thing that can be said about the Australian Democrats is that their stance on this Bill represents the triumph of hope over experience. I just hope that the Democrats will be more ready next time we are faced with legislation of this sort, as I am sure we will be, to act on the realities which are demonstrated by the past than they have been on this occasion.

Senator Boswell has just drawn to my attention a report of 29 May in which the Electrical Trades Union warned that it would call for major industrial action next week if Federal legislation failed to secure the re-employment of 800 sacked SEQEB workers. Of course, that is a more recent update on the threat which was reported in the Australian Financial Review just a few days ago in exactly the same terms.

What we have is a situation in which the Democrats have chosen to support this legislation, not on the basis of anything that can be described as a watertight guarantee, but rather on some broad expressions of intention by the trade union movement which are not of a binding nature, which are not enforceable and which will leave the Australian people and the people of Queensland with no remedies when those undertakings are broken, as inevitably they will be.

It is important to go back to the origins of this dispute. Various honourable senators have drawn attention to the fact that the Government has conceded that there was wilful industrial action on the part of trade unions in Queensland which could not be condoned or supported. The reality is that the trade unions in Queensland set out to prevent the SEQEB from employing sub-contract labour. They had no right to do that. They were not entitled to do that, yet they sought to do it. They imposed industrial action on the Board, trying to pursue that end-an end which they had no right to pursue in the first place.

The fact is that the Queensland Government has moved to guarantee the supply of essential services in Queensland. The fact is that the strike which was undertaken is at an end. It has been brought to an end by resolute government action; the dispute is at an end. It is the trade union movement which is prolonging this dispute. This legislation represents a step in removing the power of the Queensland Government to deal with its own affairs. It is a retrograde step and a step which is thoroughly opposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to speak at great length on the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill because the issues have been very widely canvassed. All sorts of mock morality and so on have intruded into the debate.
—By Senator Reynolds, do you mean?
—I did not say who intruded it, Senator, and I am being even-handed about it, if you like.
—Spread it across the whole chamber.
—That is right.
—He included me, of course.

—Yes, Senator, I included you. The fact is that the national Government was faced with an enormously difficult situation in Queensland which was damaging not only to the Queensland economy but also to the national economy. The national Government made numerous endeavours to consult with the Premier of Queensland about this dispute but all those attempts were rejected. The Government sought to facilitate negotiations between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Queensland Government but those attempts were also rejected. I think it is worth while pointing out, for us to understand the history of the dispute, that there was one quite dramatic point where this dispute could have been settled by the Queensland State Industrial Commission. A proposal put forward by the Commission was accepted by the unions but rejected outright by the Premier of Queensland. As a result the President of the Queensland Commission felt it incumbent upon him to call a special session of the Commission to point out that a number of things which had been said by the Premier about that Commission were totally erroneous. One of the things he did point out was that a lot of the terms and conditions which the Premier complained about had actually been negotiated between his Government and the unions and agreed to between his Government and the unions. The President of the Commission had to take those steps to point those matters out. They are relevant factors in the history of the dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney, in his speech, followed down that meandering road of philosophising aloud, which the Liberal Party of Australia does at the moment in respect of various matters, particularly on industrial relations issues. If I may characterise Senator Chaney's speech, it was half emotional ire about trade unions, a bit of old-fashioned union bashing and things like that, and half suggesting how all these problems might be solved. He floated a few ideas; for example, the arbitration system was in many respects outmoded, it ought to be got rid of and a whole range of other possibilities could be considered. I do not agree with the substance of all of those but I think they are perfectly legitimate subjects for debate in the Senate. I do not for the life of me see what they have to do with what happened in Queensland. Senator Chaney, in his speech, connected a whole lot of examples of bad past industrial relations practices with some vague views about how these things might be tackled in the future, and suggested that the Queensland dispute was somehow in the middle of all that. I do not see the connection between all those things.

I think ultimately one of the tests we have to apply to an industrial relations system is the result. These philosophical concerns in the Liberal Party date back some years now. They first surfaced in 1976 when the new Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, gave what was sometimes said to be a major speech on Liberal Party philosophy in respect of industrial relations. There were two elements in that speech. One element was that there were always two sides to the case in industrial relations, and I agree with him on that. He went on to say that these things were best handled by consultation, negotiation and discussion. That was the prime view which the former Prime Minister articulated. He then went on to say that if negotiations, discussion and such things did not produce results there would be consequences, as he put it. It is those two streams of thought-the one which is involved with consequences and the one which is involved with conciliation, discussion and so on-which lie at the heart of the industrial relations debate and which, with respect, the Liberal Party in this country has never really straddled. It is not quite sure where it stands on those two issues.

One of the tests or criteria of any industrial relations system must be the results it produces. I do not regard our industrial relations system as perfect. It has served this country pretty badly in years gone by, but the figures for industrial disputes in Australia in the last couple of years, since this Government was elected, have been the best in 17 years. The wage fixation system in place under this Government has produced unit labour costs which are back to the level of 1969 and 1970. A whole range of benefits have flowed from the use, as it were, of the first Malcolm Fraser principle, if I might call it that; that is, deriving benefits and consulting on and discussing particular issues in industrial relations as a means of providing solutions to problems.

We have all sorts of historical difficulties in our industrial relations systems which have grown up as a result of bad practices in industry and by unions, just as we have an historical legacy of bad practices in industry and in management in this country-luxuries which we cannot afford any more. Consideration in debate about all those sorts of things is very important but we have before us a piece of legislation to deal with a particular situation which was becoming immensely damaging to this country. A few weeks ago there was really no light at the end of the tunnel in respect of this dispute and this blockade of Queensland-no light at all. The gung ho senators on the other side of the chamber started to yell 'Give them more stick', 'All the way with the Premier of Queensland' and 'All the way with Margaret Thatcher'. Those solutions do not commend themselves to this Government. It is not an approach which we are prepared to adopt. So much for the general parameters of the debate which has taken place.

I wish to refer briefly to a number of specific things said by Opposition senators. Generally, there was support for the Queensland Government position-whatever it might be. I remind honourable senators opposite of contributions to this debate which clearly prove that the position of the Queensland Government in respect of an issue which was damaging to the Queensland economy and to the Australian economy was not dictated by social, industrial or economic considerations. The position of the Queensland Government was dictated by blatant political considerations. That is as clear as anything, as would be revealed by a study of the transcripts and so on of what has taken place.

The second position which emerges from the Opposition-I am pleased to hear this-is that there is a general belief on that side of the chamber that somehow a heavy-handed punitive approach will resolve industrial relations problems. I have referred to that in the context of my general remarks. It was also suggested that somehow the Commonwealth Government was in the pocket of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in respect of this issue. I reiterate that the Government's predominant concern is to protect the public interest, both nationally and in Queensland. Let there be no doubt about this. The Government, through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and other spokesmen-through myself in this chamber-when we have been asked about it have roundly condemned the blockade of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a gross exaggeration.
—It is not a gross exaggeration.
—You went nowhere near roundly condemning anything.
—On these issues I do not engage in the sort of emotive public school language which Senator Chaney went on with when he talked about tolerance of illegal activity, lawlessness and standovers.
—That's right. Do you deny those things?

—No, but what I deny is the honourable senator's capacity, with any integrity, to put all those things into the context of the Queensland dispute. Where he got them from was the Builders Labourers Federation, and he lumped them all into his discussion of the Queensland dispute. That is what I deny-his integrity to say those things and his integrity in relation to these things if he lumps them all together in relation to the Queensland dispute.
—You didn't do your duty as a Minister, either. You failed to do your duty to control the Australian public servants.

—That is what I am talking about when I refer to the honourable senator's emotive language. He asks me to do my duty to control, as he puts it, the Australian Public Service. What I put to him a minute ago-he probably was not listening-is that we have done our duty in the last two years a bit better than his Government did in seven years of government in terms of industrial disputation. Look at the record that that Government had. It is the most shocking record of any government.
—Look at the way they handled the Telecom dispute.

—Senator Harradine interjects about the way the Government handled the Telecom strike. That was great. The Liberals did great things with that, did they not? In 1981 and 1982, look what they did in relation to the wages system in this country, and look to what it produced. What Opposition senators cannot stomach is the success of this Government in handling these matters, which reminds them, in turn-and the people of Australia-of abysmal failure when they were in government. They know what the record is. They can look it up for themselves. The record was abysmal in terms of industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney is fixing me with all those words which naturally come to him. When he addresses the subject of the Australian trade union movement, he talks about lawlessness, tolerance of illegal activity, and standover tactics. When he addressed me, he talked about me doing my duty. They come from the same lexicon of moral righteousness which Senator Chaney thrives upon in relation to other groups and people in this community. The test of whether people are doing their duty-to adopt his terminology-is to look at the results. The results in respect of this Government have been so much better than anything that Senator Chaney and his colleague did when, for example, the Fraser Government stopped the telephone system in this country because of the silly attitudes of Ministers such as Mr Sinclair.

TALK.START.PARA: —You give in to your bosses in the ACTU, that's why. They don't need to strike; you give it all to them.

—The latest interjection was a gem. I should like it recorded. Perhaps I may repeat it. Senator Chaney says: 'They don't need to strike, the ACTU; you give it all to them'. That is Senator Chaney's view of the world.
—That's right; you gave the public servants 2 per cent.

—Whatever we have given them in the last two years, we certainly did not give them a 22 per cent increase in wages-which is what Senator Chaney's Government gave them in 1982. Perhaps that was just out of generosity on the part of a Liberal government. We certainly did not give them a 22 per cent increase in wages. That is the sort of thing that sticks in the craw, I suppose, because it is the sort of thing that Senator Chaney must confront when he comes in here and plays verbal tootsies with me.

SPEECH.PARA: There were one or two other points raised by Liberal senators which I think I should refer to in passing. One honourable senator asserted that the Bill was unconstitutional. If that is so, I guess that the Premier of Queensland, who has spent so much money on this matter and cost the Queensland community so much to date, will spend a few more bob in showing that the Bill is unconstitutional. That is a matter for the High Court to decide and not honourable senators in this place.

One honourable senator referred to the Government having no head of power under which to deal with this legislation. That is bunkum. Another claim made by an honourable senator from the other side of the chamber, which was a little extraordinary, was that the Government had misled the workers who were dismissed because it had been presented to them that the passing of this Bill would result in their getting their jobs back. That is not true. I invite honourable senators to read the second reading speech. That representation has not been made to the workers concerned. What has been said right from the beginning is that, if the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission follows this course, logically an award will be made. It will have a disputes settlement procedure and a preference clause. That is likely to happen, but it is a matter for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission ultimately to determine. The fact is that no member of the Government has made any such claim in respect of this Bill.

It was said that the Bill represents an attack on States rights. As has been pointed out in another context in this chamber, there are all sorts of rights which have to be balanced-the rights of people who had their electricity cut off, the rights of people who were sacked, the rights of Queenslanders, the rights of people trying to do business in this country, the rights of people who want to travel to Queensland. A whole range of rights has to be considered in these matters.

Let me make it clear that three or four weeks ago when the blockade was in place, the rights of all sorts of people were being affected and no solution was forthcoming to that problem. It was not just the rights of the trade unionists concerned or the rights of the Queensland Premier which were being affected; the rights of a whole range of people were being adversely affected. I refer to the right to travel, the right to make money-the right to do all sorts of things.

I do not approve, as I am sure no honourable senator approves, of those rights being interfered with across the community. There was a log jam. There was only one way to break that log jam, and the Federal Government sought and sought again to provide a constructive solution to this problem in conjunction with the Premier and the parties involved in this dispute in Queensland. The exercise of that right was refused. It was in that context that the Government decided to break the log jam. When Senator Chaney was interjecting earlier, I said that the ultimate test of a system in respect of the sorts of matters we are talking about was whether it produced results for a community. There were all sorts of rights, but the ultimate test was whether a system produced the results for a community.

Senator Chaney, in the early part of his speech, raised many issues which go to the question of whether the system we have in Australia will go on producing good results for the community. I concede that that is a matter of legitimate debate. There are fair points to be made on both sides. If one looks at the Queensland dispute, this question has to be asked: What results can we best produce for the Australian community? No solutions were coming forward from anywhere else until the Government took this course. Those people who were innocent victims of the action of the Queensland Government and the intransigence of the Queensland Government and sections of the trade union movement are entitled to be considered when dealing with this matter. This is an important question of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is no solution.
—Senator Messner has the gift of foresight. For God's sake-
—Ask him what horse is going to win the race tomorrow.

—I will ask him later. Senator Messner has many gifts. I never thought that foresight was one of them. Senator Messner says that this is no solution. If this is no solution those opposite will be back here in the Budget session yelling their heads off that the Federal Government intervened in this matter and it did not provide a solution. Those opposite will have a field day in the Budget session. I will cop it. I recognise that now. I will cop it, in the sense that I will take it. For goodness sake, just because those opposite have an approach, which they have not really sorted out, different from that adopted by the Government, they should not condemn this legislation to failure.

SPEECH.PARA: We will do what we, as a national government, can to see that this matter is resolved in a manner which will produce results for all members of the public who are inconvenienced by these disputes, the employees in Queensland and the customers of the South East Queensland Electricity Board because, as the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has said on a number of occasions, this society cannot allow major public instrumentalities to hold the public to ransom. We agree with that. That is why this legislation has been introduced. I commend this legislation not only to the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine, who has spoken on the matter, but even to thinking Liberals on the other side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has narrowed the field.

—I am sure it has. I commend it to them, too, because in the absence of an alternative approach we believe that it is the best and most viable solution to a very difficult problem for Queensland and this country. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 4, paragraph (1) (d), leave out sub-paragraph (ii).

This amendment seeks to omit sub-paragraph (ii) of paragraph (1) (d). Sub-paragraph (ii) speaks about the situation with regard to contractors employed in the industry in Queensland. The point about this matter is that it touches on a very important issue which has recently been raised in the context of the report of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, and that is that the proposed law we are discussing today will, indeed, require contractors and their employees to become subject to awards and to union membership. This is in spite of the fact that over a great period-this is really the core of the discussion about the whole dispute in Queensland-the South East Queensland Electricity Board has been making substantial efforts to make its system more efficient, effective and productive. It has made good use of contractors to ensure that the consumers of electricity in Queensland get a better service. The Board employs at present some 60 contractors who in turn employ their own employees, some 250 people. We have seen that the right of employers to hire contractors and the right of contractors to work are central to the cause of the original dispute. We spoke about this earlier.

No single job of a member of the Electrical Trades Union is at risk in the present dispute in Queensland. The issue is within the union: It is whether contractors will be employed in the place of employees. It is as simple as that. It is the determination of the Electrical Trades Union to force the Electricity Board to employ non-contract labour that is the cause of this dispute. Whether people are employed as contractors or as employees is irrelevant; they are still employed by the Board and would be so under the arrangements that currently apply. No single job of an employee of the Board, whether employed by contract or otherwise, is at risk at the moment. That is apparently not good enough for those within the trade union movement who seek the monopoly of labour to restrict people's freedom of choice. That is the difference the Liberal and National parties have with the Government on this most important issue.

Under the legislation, contractors and their employees may be brought under any Federal award determined by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That is at the direct bidding of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We believe that that is certainly against the interests of the people of Queensland, but particularly against the interests of individual people who choose to work in whatever way they wish. If honourable senators need any other proof, this clause alone is enough for us to decide that the activity on the part of the union movement within Queensland is designed to destroy the rights of independent businessmen, contractors and others to work in the way in which they choose.

If people are employed as contractors, as has been found out, in conjunction with the operation of the Board in such a way as to create a most efficient electricity generation industry-as has been created in Queensland-for the benefit of consumers, that accords with the fundamental objective of the Board. It is outrageous that the union has seen fit to strike against this system which has produced such economic benefits for the people of Queensland. It strikes against the freedom of choice. Certainly, it will affect the choice many people make about the way in which they conduct their business.

The contract system, which obviously the Government does not believe in, is one in which certainly the Liberal and National parties believe. We believe that it provides people with freedom of choice to do their own thing. For that reason we believe that the direction the Government is moving in is wrong. We have plenty of examples we could throw into the debate to support our belief in the contract system. We could look at the housing industry or at the road transport industry, which are conducted most efficiently, in many cases by contractors. There is much evidence to demonstrate that contractors have kept down the cost of housing because of their efficient method of operation. All the principles I have mentioned are at stake with this legislation. We strongly oppose the intention of the Government and seek the support of the Senate for our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said earlier today that it would be better if Senator Messner did not enter into this debate because he knows very little about industrial matters. If Senator Messner strongly supported subcontractors and subcontracting arrangements he would support this legislation, because what it does is protect the subcontractors. Senator Messner has no understanding at all. If subcontractors are not protected by awards and conditions under which they are paid a subcontractor who wants to get a particular contract by tender will tender low. In other words, he will use short-cuts. That has happened here in Canberra. On one of the Estimates committees we found that the Government had to contribute another million dollars to support subcontractors to carry out their responsibilities under cleaning contracts because they had tendered far too low.
—The law of the jungle.

—It is law of the jungle. What happened was that the cleaners had to bring in members of their families. Several people were engaged to do the work that one person had contracted to do. Instead of opposing this measure, Senator Messner should be supporting it. One subcontractor cannot be played against another. I have said before today that the electricity industry is a very sensitive industry and that we cannot allow it to fall into the hands of subcontractors who tender and who are not under some sort of, shall we term it, award control. That is what this Bill does: It makes certain that those subcontractors who are employed and who employ others will employ them under certain conditions which apply across the whole of the industry.
—They are licensed.

—Does Senator Archer know what is happening in Queensland at present? The Queensland Government has restructured the work force in the South East Queensland Electricity Board. It has given the work out to subcontract. It is offering subcontractors an amount of $40 to put on a house service. At a later stage it will put those contracts out to tender. The subcontractors will compete with each other to get the contracts and they will start to tender $20. If they tender $20 for the service, it means they have to take short cuts in a very important industry.
—What about efficiency?
—It is fairly obvious that Senator Messner has never engaged in--
—Come on, George.

—Possibly Senator Messner has had something to do with local government; I do not know. Local government in Queensland and other places, especially National Party of Australia controlled local councils, are prepared to make the roads in their areas not by contract but by day labour. The reason for that is that when they give it out to subcontract it all looks very well for the first year, but the second year it crumbles, the third year it is not worth a damn and councils have to use day labour. There is no integrity, efficiency or quality in subcontracting work which comes under pressure of tendering without protections under awards for those who work within the system. Senator Messner should be supporting this proposition, not--
—I support those who want to have a go.

—Senator Messner supports deregulation. He is great. Senator Messner has got his touch of socialism. He is well placed. We are all well placed. But honourable senators opposite are the sorts of people who want to deregulate everything so that they can get something on the cheap. If they run out of milk at one in the morning and they have a party somewhere, they can race down the road and buy a carton of milk. Some poor devil has to stay up all night to serve their purposes. That is why we have regulation. That is why we have awards. That is why we have conditions. If we left it to the Opposition, it would destroy all conditions. That is what the Queensland Government has done with the electricity industry.
—Do you reckon Bob Hawke agrees with you?

—Do not remind me of that. That is what the Queensland Government has done by the processes it has employed. By the processes it has employed it has put the whole of the electricity distribution system at the mercy of subcontractors. I return to the subcontracting arrangements. The subcontracting agreement represented one per cent of the budget. However, Wayne Gilbert, the General Manager of the South East Queensland Electricity Board, determined that he could do it on the cheap by subcontract. He knew that eventually he would be able to play contractor against contractor and get the job done on the cheap.

SPEECH.PARA: One cannot run an electricity system-especially a 240-volt system-in this way. If we were looking at a 110-volt system which the United States has, we might be able to say that it is safer to operate that sort of system and therefore safe to run wires wherever we like. We cannot run wires around just anywhere with a 240-volt system. If we do not have proper standards and conditions the whole system runs down. If we do not have proper standards and conditions and if we start to put inspections out to contract-this is what the Queensland Government is trying to do-in that sort of system we will find people starting to wire up their own homes, running a plug along the wall to another outlet; overloading their circuits thus rendering the whole distribution system dangerous. That is what I strongly object to in regard to what is happening in Queensland.

In Queensland a skilled work force has been destroyed; skilled men have been put out to grass. These men are available. As Senator Harradine said, the choice of returning to work has been taken away from these men because the conditions of return were such that they could not accept them. The system has been opened up to cheapskate contracting. The only way we can prevent that contracting from falling below standard is to accept the proposition contained in the Bill that those who work for subcontractors should work to certain awards and conditions. Going back to my original point, such awards and conditions are to protect the subcontractor as much as anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have listened to a most amazing speech from Senator Georges's. There would not be one part of Senator Georges's life that is not touched by someone who has tendered, and won a tender by submitting the lowest price. Tenders have been submitted in regard to the car he drives, the aeroplane he flies in, this building and the new building we will be going to. Either the entire thing or its component parts will have been made by somebody who submitted the lowest price. That is the way this society operates. I think Senator Georges is doing a great injustice to the people he is seeking to represent.
—That is not true. The airlines are subject to control because they have to keep up safety standards.

—I remind the honourable senator that the aircraft he flies in are made up of many parts. Many of the component parts are made in Australia. I think Senator Georges has done a great disservice to the people he seeks to represent, no matter whether they are working for contractors, the South East Queensland Electricity Board or somebody else. They are highly trained and highly skilled people. They have all gone through apprenticeships, tertiary and further education colleges and the rest of it. If a contractor submits a tender obviously he has done his homework properly. He will be able to do the job. Senator Georges is thinking of everybody except the consumer of electricity. Surely they are people who have a right to the lowest possible priced electricity, particularly when the electricity generating authorities are monopolistic. Tendering is a scheme by which this society generally operates. People are allowed to tender. This society operates because people are prepared to get up and have a go. If we close the whole darn thing off where do we end up? We end up with a monopolistic society, in which we pay exorbitant prices, with no efficiencies, no nothing. The people Senator Georges seeks to represent are quite capable of competing and quite capable of doing a good job. They are highly skilled tradesmen in their particular fields. I think Senator Georges is doing them a great disservice by making the speech he made.

—I wonder whether we have gone a bit astray on this particular question. Is it the Government's intention with clause 4 (d) (ii) to ensure that those people with whom the original dispute was partly concerned are enabled to be heard in whatever dispute is now considered by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as a result of this legislation? Am I to understand that this legislation, as it applies specifically to the decision by Commissioner Brown of 18 April, C. No. 5364, applies to a dispute between the Electrical Trades Union of Australia and various electricity authorities in Queensland? Am I to understand that clause 4 (d) (ii) will enable a subsequent dispute to be found between other parties, including the contractors? Would that not enable the contractors to have some say in a matter in which otherwise they would not necessarily have a say? I cannot see the logic of the Opposition seeking to have clause 4 (d) (ii) taken out if it enables the contractors to have a say in a dispute in which they were originally quite a central feature.

—The Government will not accept the amendment. I gather from those who are supporting it that they see this as imposing some impediment to the employment of contract labour or the letting of work to contractors and they see that as a bad thing. Whatever the merits of that may or may not be, the more important point is that the amendment will not close off the possibility of contract employees being brought under the jurisdiction of a Federal award; it will just ensure that it will be done more slowly. If this amendment were to be carried, we would have co-existing a situation in which direct employees of the South East Queensland Electricity Board could be covered by a Commonwealth award and a situation in which the employees of contractors engaged by the electricity authorities would be in the process of being covered by a Federal award-obviously, a pretty untidy situation. I am advised that the provision has effect only where a log of claims has been served on a relevant employer. There has been no service of the Electrical Trades Union log on contractors. If a new dispute involving contractors is created, it can be declared to come within the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Minister says confirms what I have just been saying. The effect of the Opposition's amendment will be to exclude contractors from having their say in this very vital dispute. I do not see that that fits in with what the Opposition was saying at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Messner's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 5 (Modification of Conciliation and Arbitration Act).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will oppose this clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6 (Industrial disputes to which Act applies).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Pages 2 and 3, clause 6, lines 35 and 41-42, leave out 'of Queensland'.
In the interests of time, I will yield to my colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 6 deals with industrial disputes to which the Conciliation and Arbitration Act applies. This provision represents a travesty of inter-governmental relations. It certainly represents interference in the sovereign rights of the State of Queensland. I would point out to Government senators that it is the States in Australia that are sovereign, not the Federal Government. But the Federal Government has been quietly clawing powers to itself using various means. We have been through colonial government and co-operative federalism and are now going through coercive federalism. This is what the present Government is doing. It can use its financial powers to do it, it can use High Court decisions, it can use referenda, it can use overriding legislation, and it can use its treaty powers. This legislation represents more in the same process of the Federal Government's clawing powers to itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6 allows the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to take over the functions of the Queensland State Industrial Commission. The Federal Commission can hear disputes, determine them, and make decisions. There is no appeal from the Federal court. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in his second reading speech said that the Queensland dispute has serious implications not only for Queensland but also for the rest of Australia. He is quite right, I agree with that, but I do not have in mind the same implications that he nominated.

One issue that has not been stressed sufficiently is that the whole dispute was over when all this activity was taking place. The electricity workers who lost their own jobs brought this on themselves. They had been asked by the courts to go back to work, told by the courts, ordered to go back to work, and they did not. They let the time elapse, they sacked themselves and they fouled up all their own terms and conditions. Every moderate voice in Queensland advised them to go back to work and they did not do that. I think it was the militant Electrical Trades Union that realised that it had got on the wrong tram and it started to back-pedal and tried to do something about it. It realised that its cause was not just; it had nothing to fight with. Once it realised that it was losing it had to expand its activities, involve other trade unions and get more blackmail and more intimidation going. The blackouts and blockades and the hit lists that it invented were all part of its expanded activity. It is a very sorry catalogue.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government should have acted a lot earlier than they did. The Government and the Prime Minister shilly-shallied like they always do. They ignored their responsibility-a higher responsibility with Queensland under blockade by militant trade unions. The Prime Minister should have stepped in to defend his trade. I think the matter of peace, order and good government of Australia was mentioned today by the shadow Opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations. That is the one area that this Government has ignored altogether. Throughout this whole dispute the Queensland Government and the Queensland Premier retained massive public support which they still have today. It was mentioned this afternoon that the level of support for the Premier is up right now. I think the other States would do well to emulate the actions of the Queensland Premier and the Queensland Government to take control and to get back some sanity in trade union relations.

This legislation and, in particular, this clause, represent the initial stages of the undermining of State industrial legislation by the Federal Government. For years now the people of Australia have clearly shown that they are fed up with union anarchy and union lawlessness. They are sick and tired of having their essential services disrupted. This disruption always happens at the most inconvenient times, such as holidays. The Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill is designed to undermine the authority that will get rid of the disruptive behaviour, and that is what we are on about here. Disruptive behaviour has increased our costs immeasurably over the years and has caused much unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, with the high fixed minimum wages that have put young people out of work.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the doctors? What about the prices they charge?
—The doctors have not been involved in this dispute. In any case, I wish to say that I whole-heartedly support the amendment that has been moved to this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 6 of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill discriminates against Queensland. This legislation is a pumped-up, artificial paper that allows the Electrical Trades Union to go to every other State and log claims. This clause allows the Government to launch this Bill which is a clear attack on the Queensland Government. In other words, the ETU has gone to the Government and said: 'We want another umpire. We want another ground to play on. We have lost on that ground in Queensland'. Of course, this Government, which receives its instructions from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, has just knuckled under completely and given way to its demands. We see that happening so often. Here, of course, the ACTU could not have done this without the help of the Australian Democrats. The Democrats-the conscience of the Parliament!-called on the unions for certain assurances and they were given these assurances by the ACTU. We have already seen those assurances and clause 6 of the Bill being absolutely disregarded before the Bill has even passed through the Senate. Just today the Telegraph stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Electrical Trades Union today warned it would call for a major industrial action next week if the federal legislation failed to secure the re-employment of 800 sacked workers.

That is the ETU's latest statement as of 12 o'clock today. I do not know where the Democrats stand now. They have sought and been given assurances. The ink is not even dry-it is not even on the paper-yet the ETU has torn up the agreements--

TALK.START.PARA: —Duress.

—It is duress. The 800 people will not get back their jobs because there are no jobs for them there; those jobs have been taken up by other people. One cannot create another 800 jobs for the 800 people who have sacked themselves. The ETU is not only threatening industrial blackmail in Queensland; yesterday I made a speech on the adjournment appealing to the Democrats to take action on the happenings of the ETU in the coal fields of the Latrobe Valley in Victoria. The ETU there is demanding that its members pay $5 a week to a fighting fund for their comrades in Queensland. John McNamara, one of the members of the ETU in the Latrobe Valley, has said that he does not mind paying $5 to a needy strike affected family, but he will not be associated with a political dispute. He does not mind paying for an industrial dispute, but he will not be made a pawn of the ETU. The Democrats have stated quite clearly on a number of occasions that they do not believe in political blackmail, blockades or unionists having to pay compulsory levies. Yet in Victoria levies have been imposed and people have been sacked and black banned. Eleven industrial electricians have lost their jobs and been black banned. Again the Democrats have sought assurances from the ACTU and those assurances are not even worth the paper on which they are written.
—They are the watertight ones!

—Yes. Clause 6 and the rest of the clauses in this Bill are stirring up the dispute, which was settled, in Queensland. There are only 200 people in Queensland at the moment who have not gone back to work.
—That's not right.

—Senator Georges says that is not right. I ask Senator Georges to say how many there are, because I have something here that says there are 250 people who do not have a job. This clause is a reaction to a pumped up, mushroomed dispute. It calls for the ground rules to be changed and it calls for a new umpire. Let it be remembered that the Premier of Queensland called together the unions in the Industrial Commission and said: 'We will have a sitting of the Full Bench and we will accept the decision of the Full Bench'. That was not agreed to by the ETU and the other unions.
—No, you're wrong.

—That is correct. After three recommendations, the ETU was called back nine times and it refused to accept the Commissioner's recommendations. The Democrats must stand condemned. They have asked for assurances. Before the Bill even came before the Senate there were three disputes running. There is one in Victoria. There is the threat of the Electrical Trades Union in Brisbane that if it does not get its members back in the job there will be industrial disputes. Mr Ian Court said that the assurance of no further industrial action was conditional upon the legislation becoming law quickly and would not hold if there were any drawn out challenges in the High Court of Australia. That is another threat by the ETU, yet the Democrats sit here and say: 'We have the assurances of the unions'. That is a complete laugh. The unions are laughing in the face of the Democrats and making a fool of the Democrats and their policies on peace at any price. It wrecked Chamberlain and it will wreck the Democrats. When they go to the people in Queensland they will be completely wiped out at the polls for accepting assurances from the unions that are not worth the paper on which they are written.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment that is before the Committee this evening. Clause 6 of the Bill talks about industrial disputes to which the Conciliation and Arbitration Act applies. We have heard from many honourable senators about the series of disputes that have taken place in Queensland. In fact, I spoke about them in this chamber not so long ago when we discussed a matter of public importance. We all know that the industrial dispute about which we are talking and to which the amendment refers is the dispute in Queensland between the Electrical Trades Union and the South East Queensland Electricity Board. The Bill has been brought into this Parliament because the Federal Labor Government is completely dominated by the unions. The Australian Council of Trade Unions cocked its little finger and the Labor Government rushed to do its bidding. I consider that that is a scandalous misuse of government power. I am sure that eventually the legislation will be seen to be constitutionally incorrect. Of course, the Australian Labor Party is not worried about that, so the Queensland Government will have to go to the High Court of Australia to test the legislation constitutionally. I think that is reasonable enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it very hard to believe that the Australian Democrats support the Bill. They indicated at the second reading stage that they would support it. Senator Boswell explained the way in which the Democrats have been tricked. Already the unions are saying that if the Queensland Government does not immediately re-employ all the ETU workers they will go on strike again. What I want to know is: Where will they find the jobs? All the jobs have been filled. Everybody in Queensland is able to get power and a fewer number of workers are employed by SEQEB. Therefore, it stands to reason that the people of Queensland ought to be getting cheaper electricity. That is how it is and it is very important.

I point out to honourable senators that one of the basic democratic rights under the Westminster system provided the foundation for the Queensland Government's action to resolve this electricity dispute. My belief is that elected governments are elected to govern. That is what the Australian Labor Party does down here. It brings in Bills and, with the support of the Democrats of course, gets them through. I think that if a government is elected it ought to be allowed to govern. If the people of Queensland do not like what has been done they will be able to tell the Queensland Government so at the polls. A poll taken at the time of the dispute found that the ALP percentage of popularity in Queensland had gone down by 5 per cent while the Queensland Government's popularity percentage had gone up. People want a government to be able to govern, not a government which is governed by the ACTU. I feel that that is very important.
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to honourable senators opposite that I did not scream and shout at them when they made their speeches. I sat quietly and listened to what they said. I think that I am entitled to be heard in silence also. The Australian Financial Review, in one of its editorials on the power dispute, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, and this is something unions ought to remember, no one wants to see a stark confrontation between the authority of an elected government and the unions, in which the elected government loses.
If unions can defeat duly constituted democratic authority then they have gone too far and become a threat to democracy.
An editorial in the Australian on 10 April headed '. . . . the penalties of not being tough' stated:
. . . there is no doubt that the public is heartily sick and tired of the disruption to their way of life which industrial disputes bring, especially in essential services.

I point out to honourable senators opposite that most countries have legislation with a no-strike provision in relation to essential services. That is all that Queensland has been trying to do. In this dispute the unions in Queensland did not care one iota about all the people who were hurt. They did not worry about the 6,000 jobs that were lost. They did not worry that the dispute cost $600m and that it cost the Queensland Government $25m. The dispute was just about settled, and then what happened? The ETU fellows rushed off madly to the ACTU and said: 'We are not winning up in Queensland. We want to get the dispute enlarged'. Of course, the ACTU came to the party and that is why we have this problem.

All I can say is that no self-respecting government would allow itself to be browbeaten by any procedure contemplated by this Government which would enable the transfer of the balance of power from a State government to the unions; that is what this is all about. This legislation is very important. I think it is very unfortunate that this Government has been so wishy-washy and just gone along with what the unions have said. As I said at the beginning, they cocked their little finger and away went the Federal Government. I just want to put my point of view here this evening. This Bill is very important. Unfortunately, it has passed its second reading, thanks to the Democrats voting with the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats always vote with the Government.
—Yes, unfortunately in most cases they do. The elected Government in Queensland-
—Minority government.

—The elected Government in Queensland is trying to give guaranteed supply of power. As far as the reference to a minority government is concerned, if the Australian Labor Party had the majority in Queensland, it would govern. That is a simple little fact. Honourable senators on the other side just cannot add up. They do not realise that they do not have 50 per cent and have not had it since 1957; so they cannot win. It is the duty of an elected government to be able to provide electricity on a no-strike arrangement. I feel very sorry indeed that this Government has been misled by the unions and has brought in a Bill like this to try, as it sees it, to bring a settlement to the dispute. I venture to say that the dispute is a long way from being settled because it will go to the High Court of Australia and I feel quite sure that the High Court will say that this is a matter for the State Government and not a matter for the unions. It is not really a matter in which the Federal Government should interfere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted that Senator Bjelke-Petersen said that duly constituted democratic authority should be sacrosanct and never subject to challenge by any group. I noted that Senator Boswell referred to the evils of blockades, and Senator Sheil expressed similar views. I must say that I am surprised, to say the least, that three members of the National Party of Australia from Queensland could have expressed those views. I remember, I believe it was in 1979, when a bunch of militant truck drivers blockaded Razorback Mountain, which blockade was a direct threat to duly constituted democratic authority, a defiance of the law and an attempt to use a blockade as blackmail to have the law changed. Who supported them? They had no stronger public supporter than the Premier of Queensland, who not only gave them public support but also promised immediately to repeal the road maintenance tax in the State of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I also remember that in 1980 militant unionists in central Queensland were trying to use not only industrial tactics but also physical intimidation to change or defy the law of the land regarding imputed income on company occupied houses. I remember seeing photographs and television footage of the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, being physically abused by militant unionists in central Queensland. And who was supporting them? The Premier.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Mr Lester.

—And Mr Lester. So I suppose circumstances alter cases. Those very views and actions are being denounced tonight by all the Queensland National Party senators. The people who are now indulging in those practices and using those tactics are following the precedents set and approved of by Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen within the last five or six years. That is an important fact that should be noted.

SPEECH.PARA: The logic is no sounder than the moral consistency. Indeed, I find quite extraordinary the stand of Senator Sheil, who gave us a typical States rights speech-the type one might expect to hear at any gathering of the League of Rights. The effect of the amendment that has been moved would be to extend throughout Australia the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill which are stipulated to apply in Queensland. The anti-centralist principle which the Queensland Opposition senators claim to uphold they simultaneously seek to extend right across the country. Perhaps it does not matter a great deal whether it does, but this Government, given that this was a unique Queensland dispute, felt that there was need only for legislation covering Queensland. The amendment, contrary to Senator Bjelke-Petersen's views, does not affect the dispute with the Queensland branch of the Electrical Trades Union, which is covered by clause 6. It affects other disputes involving the Queensland electricity industry.

I find quite extraordinary the humbuggery of the Queensland senators who denounce the very tactics that their own revered Premier endorsed and established a precedent for some years ago. Likewise, I am completely mystified by the purpose of amendment No. 3, which seeks the omission of 'Queensland' from clause 6. The effect of that would be to apply throughout Australia what the Opposition claims to be undesirable, even evil, principles embodied in this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I looked at the shocked expressions on the faces of the members of the Opposition, as Senator Walsh made the statement that the effect of the amendment will be to spread the impact of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill to all the States of Australia, I wondered whether the Opposition understands what this amendment represents. I further wonder whether the representatives from Queensland recognise that they are Australian parliamentarians.
—We are here to represent the rights of our States. That is what it is all about. This is the States House.

—I am very interested to hear the comments from Senator Boswell because I am sure that he will endorse what I am about to say. Senator Bjelke-Petersen gave a 10-minute speech in which she said-I agree completely-that parliamentarians are elected to protect the interests of their electors. Parliamentarians in Queensland are elected to provide the Government and to protect the interests of the people of Queensland. She said that the Government and the Parliament of Queensland have the responsibility for legislating on things that are of specific concern to the people of Queensland. Senator Bjelke-Petersen went on to suggest that this matter should not be within the province of the Industrial Commission but within the province of the political system. That is not what we are talking about. This whole thing has come about because the matter got out of the Industrial Commission into the political system and the politicians made an absolute mess of it.
