This Bill does its best, as well as Australian parliamentarians are able to bring this about, to get the matter back into the industrial system. I know that many parliamentarians would like to have it remain a political issue, very high on the political agenda.
—What is it going to achieve? It's not going to achieve a thing.

—It will achieve a speeding up of the processes by which this matter once again can be resolved by the Industrial Commission instead of by politicians. I return to the point being made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. She said that parliamentarians have the responsibility to carry out those deeds which will protect the interests of the people they represent and she gave as support for that argument the fact that the Queensland Parliament had taken a number of steps on this matter. Now, the matter has gone beyond being a local, parochial industrial matter. It has become a matter of concern to all the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Boswell that they are in the Australian Parliament and that this piece of legislation is being considered by the Australian Parliament. We are considering an Australian Parliament's Bill. We are about to vote on a Bill which will become an Act of the Australian Parliament or it will not, depending on how the vote goes. It is not a Queensland Parliament that is meeting in this chamber tonight. We are all here to look after the interests of all Australians. I can understand that we need to have the point of view of the people from all States in this debate, but when the time comes to vote we will be voting as Australian parliamentarians with all the rights and responsibilities given to this Parliament and its senators. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is not going to take that responsibility and that right away from me by saying that this is only a Queensland matter. It is not only a Queensland matter; it is a matter that affects all Australians because the blockade was an all-States matter. It is quite obvious that it has expanded into an all-States matter.

I want to make the Australian Democrats position quite clear. We will not allow this amendment to be passed tonight. Fortunately, we have the balance of power and the responsibility for a responsible decision on this matter and we will not allow the Opposition to blow this dispute out from a Queensland dispute to an all-States dispute. We are going to behave responsibly, as I believe we have throughout not only this debate but also all the processes that have led up to and caused this debate. I repeat that we did not get involved until this Bill came before this Parliament. It is because it is before this Parliament that we are now involved.

I wish to correct Senator Chaney's statement earlier today that I had spoken of high principles but would vote the other way. Senator Chaney subsequently-halfway through his speech-recovered himself and said that he had just realised that I did not speak in support of the Opposition's case when espousing his principles. He got it right the second time. My principles and my vote are right on line. I want to minimise the industrial disputation in Queensland and to hasten the processes by which the dispute will be channelled back into the arbitration system and away from politicians. My Party members and I will therefore be supporting this Bill and rejecting the amendment.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Messner's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 7 agreed to.
Clause 8 (Limitation on power of Commission to dismiss or refrain from hearing or determining industrial dispute to which Act applies).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 8 will be opposed by the Opposition; we will be dividing on it. It is a key clause in this legislation. It shows quite clearly what is the intention of this Government in attempting to override the rights of the State of Queensland. It is probably no better example of the many such measures sprinkled throughout this Bill which demonstrate the jack-boot approach of the Hawke Labor Government to the problems of the State of Queensland, and its attempt to override the industrial processes within that State. What is being proposed here is a total overturning of the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act as enshrined in section 41 of that Act, in such a way as to provide that the legislation which will now apply will ensure that there will be no redress in terms of industrial disputes occurring within the State of Queensland or even any right of appeal by State governments in the situations that are being envisaged and which are exemplified by the dispute in the power industry in Queensland. I might add that this is directly contrary to the recommendations of the report of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems which was recently released. It said that these kinds of amendments or any changes by any government to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act should not be contemplated. Yet the Hawke Government, being greater than all of us, has decided that it will so amend the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, this is no better example of the jack-boot approach of the Hawke socialist Government to the rights of Queenslanders and, I might say, to the rights of other Australians who will be affected by this legislation in due course. For that reason, the Liberal and National parties will be opposing this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Messner has said, clause 8 is the clause about which there could well be some concern in regard to States rights. Clause 6, about which there was considerable debate in the Committee stage earlier this evening, is not concerned with that aspect. In fact, I had intended to observe that clause 6 concerned the need to open the way for contractors to become involved in the consideration of matters designed to settle the dispute in Queensland. I acknowledge the points made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Boswell and Senator Sheil. I too have been in this chamber and objected very strongly when the rights of individual States have been under attack. I acknowledge that they-indeed, this includes the Queensland Government-have been subjected to situations, in which the people of the State concerned have been crying for some action. I acknowledge that. However, I wish to state that the action ultimately taken did not in fact resolve the dispute in the sense that it did not deal with all of those issues relevant to the proper resolution of the dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, this legislation fulfils a need but does not finalise the situation. In addition to this legislation there is a need to ensure that commonsense is brought to bear in regard to the individual dispute. I believe that actions have been taken which go too far. Incidentally, I must dissociate myself from the one or two comments trying to link the very courageous action of the Queensland Government in upholding the law to protect innocent unborn children to the action it took in relation to this industrial matter. I agree with the former action but I do not regard it as having any relevance at all to the actions of the Queensland Government in respect of this matter.

Having said that, I now turn my attention directly to clause 8 of the Bill, which purports to remove the operation of section 41 (1) (d) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Under that section the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has a discretion not to continue to deal with a dispute if the dispute is found to be trivial or, as is stated:
. . . has been dealt with, is being dealt with or is proper to be dealt with by a State Industrial Authority; or
(iii) that further proceedings are not necessary or desirable in the public interest;

As far as the latter point is concerned, one must acknowledge that the disputes dealt with by the Commission, and that particular dispute which has already been found by Commissioner Brown and upheld by the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and any subsequent disputes found as a result of the legislation will have to be dealt with by the Full Bench of the Commission. Of course, as I understand it, the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will certainly take into account matters of public interest. That is generally done by the Full Bench of the Arbitration Commission. The issue then surrounds the removal of the discretion that is now available to the Commission to refuse to consider the dispute if it has been dealt with, is being dealt with, or is proper to be dealt with by a State industrial authority of Queensland.

I am the first to stand here and admit that I have taken cases before the Commission utilising section 41 (1) (d) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I have upheld the rights and responsibilities of State industrial jurisdictions. But what tends to be overlooked in this debate is that the Queensland State Industrial Commission had this matter in its hands. It made at least two key recommendations on two separate occasions. The first recommendation was ignored by the leaders of the Electrical Trades Union of Australia. On the second occasion, when the Commission made a recommendation, it was ignored by the Queensland Government. Again, I acknowledge that the Queensland Government got so frustrated that it took certain steps. These steps were to remove the dispute from the purview of the Queensland Industrial Commission.

If members of the Opposition were prepared to say here and now that they would be happy to give a guarantee that the matter would be able to be dealt with by the Queensland Industrial Commission, I am sure that that would settle the dispute. But it is no good complaining that this legislation removes the discretion from the Commission to refuse to deal with the dispute under section 41 (1) (d) when one knows that, in fact, it has already been removed from the purview of the Queensland Industrial Commission. This clause purports to remove the section 41 (1) (d) discretion. I am sure that there will be a lot of discussion before the Commission about that very issue when it hears this dispute. I am sure that we have not heard the last of the arguments about whether this clause has or has not fully removed that discretion.
Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 9 (Proceedings in relation to disputes to which Act applies).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause again draws attention to the jackboot approach of the Hawke Labor Government in overriding the rights of the State of Queensland. There is no better example of the way in which the rights of the Queensland industrial system are being overridden by this jackboot legislation than the way in which this clause is being perpetrated as part of the legislation. The matters which should be considered in section 31 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act under normal conditions will be waived for the purpose of this legislation. These matters include such weighty matters as making provision for, or altering, the standard hours of work in an industry, making provision for, or altering, rates of wages and making provision for, or altering, a minimum wage and so on. Such weighty and important matters will be taken right out of the hands of the Industrial Commission of a State and overridden by any Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The point is the one we have been making since starting the debate on this legislation: This Government is beholden to the ACTU and the trade union movement. It is merely an extension of that body. At the ACTU's bidding the Government does all that is required of it, regardless of the interests of the people of Queensland or any other State of the Commonwealth. It does the bidding of the trade union movement, and this Bill is merely an extension of the trade unions blockade of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that honourable senators are shocked to hear that. Obviously they cannot cope with that kind of argument. I ask the small-State senators, such as Senator Foreman, Senator McKiernan, Senator Colston and Senator Elstob: Why do they not stand up for their small States and ensure that their industrial rights are maintained?

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Chairman. Senator Messner has implied that I and many other senators in this place will not stand up for our States.
—Order! That may be a debating point, but it is not a point of order.

—It is clear that they cannot stand up for the rights of their States, otherwise they would be entering the debate on our side. This Government is a jack-boot government, seeking to override not only the State of Queensland, but also the rights of all Australians. It is a shame that the Australian Democrats cannot see that and they are not standing with the Liberal and National parties in strong and firm opposition to this draconian legislation. It is obviously against the principles of all that we stand for in this country and it is clearly against the interests of every individual Australian. The Liberal and National parties seek the Senate's support for our amendment.
—Senator Messner, do you intend to move your amendment?
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 5, clause 9, leave out sub-clause (6).

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few observations about this clause and I would like the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, to take up my points and reply to them. I am at a loss to understand what this Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill will do. Will it provide jobs for the other 600 sacked people? If that is what the Government is saying, then I should point out that those persons, jobs are readily available. The jobs are there and all that the sacked Electrical Trades Union workers have to do is walk down to the gate, apply for the jobs and they will be hired. The Premier has made that statement and so has the Queensland Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Lester. The jobs are available to those people. The only people who will not get their jobs back are those ETU workers who have harassed their workmates, threatened them, or used physical violence on them. Those people will not get their jobs back, but the jobs are available to any other ETU workers as long as they go to the gate and apply. We are putting through this legislation on which we have spent the whole day, but it will not achieve one thing for the workers in Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell says that he does not know what this Bill will do. I think he has already made three speeches on it, and if he does not know now I do not think he will ever know. I think he should probably vote with the Government in the next division because if he has no idea what this Bill is about, there is no point in talking about it or voting upon it. Senator Messner gave the game away tonight when he failed to move his amendment. Not only that, but he also failed to speak to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing about this amendment is that it proposes to omit clause 9 (6), which would allow the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to restrict the application of the Bill to the Queensland electricity industry. I do not know what the Opposition wants in this place, apart from a bit of huff and puff. If Opposition members seriously suggest that the problems which this Bill is directed to solving would be helped by extending the capacity of this legislation to disputes in the electricity industry throughout Australia, I do not think they are offering a very constructive solution. I imagine that Senator Harradine, as a senator from Tasmania, would not want the Arbitration Commission to interfere in the Tasmanian electricity industry at this stage-at least I would not have thought so-but that is what Senator Messner's amendment invites. If the Opposition wants to huff and puff, it should not waste time cluttering its empty rhetoric with amendments that have no sensible purpose. It displays the Opposition's total lack of capacity to come to grips with this legislation.

Senator Messner indulged in a bit of heavy rhetoric-after-dinner rhetoric, I suspect-in which he described the Bill as an extension of the Australian Council of Trade Unions blockade. We have been through all this. There was a blockade in Queensland three or four weeks ago which was causing great disruption to this country and to the State of Queensland. There was no apparent way suggested by all the rhetoricians on the Opposition benches or anywhere else of dealing with that problem until this legislation was brought up. That is what we are debating, and that is why this Government is concerned to have this legislation adopted. I urge the Committee to reject the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to get something clear for Senator Boswell, because it is important. What Senator Boswell is now saying is that there are jobs available and that every person who wishes to be reinstated can turn up at the gates and seek reinstatement. Is that what the honourable senator is saying?
—Provided he has not harassed.
—Senator Boswell is speaking on behalf of the Premier's Department, is he?
—No, I am not.
—Then who is the honourable senator speaking on behalf of?
—The Premier and Mr Lester made that statement about two weeks ago.

—Are they prepared to support Senator Boswell's statement tonight that if we turn up on Monday at every depot with the men who want to be reinstated, provided they have not been guilty of harassment, they will be re-employed?
—And sign the no-strike clause.
—Oh!

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Messner's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 11 states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act, unless sooner repealed, shall cease to be in force at the expiration of-
(a) the period of 3 years next following the day of commencement of this Act; or
(b) if a day that is earlier than the last day of that period is fixed by Proclamation-that earlier day.

I wonder why three years was selected. The purpose of the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill, as I understand it, is to ensure that the processes of conciliation and arbitration are well oiled and that the dispute can come before the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as quickly as possible, thus overcoming a good number of measures that were being developed to drag out questions of jurisdiction, including Moore v. Doyle arguments over State registered unions and Federal registered unions and the like. I would like to know why there is a three-year period in this Bill, bearing in mind that this Parliament will expire before that three years is up. I think it would be desirable to have a sunset clause which would expire prior to the expiration of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine's question reveals that somewhere in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel there is a profound pessimist. I think that there is a lot of validity in the point Senator Harradine made. It may be that, if there are industrial relations peripherals, as it were, which belong within the context of this dispute, it may take some time to resolve those; we hope it will not. A wide margin was chosen, I gather, in assessing the potential necessary life of the legislation. As Senator Harradine pointed out, the legislation can be disposed of by proclamation and it would be the Government's wish that that would happen and happen quite rapidly. I cannot really answer the question beyond that. I regard it as an interesting point. It is a difficult point to try to answer, but that is the best explanation I can give.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the Bill now be read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the final plea on behalf of the Liberal and National parties to the Australian Democrats to defeat at this stage this jack-boot piece of legislation which will destroy the rights of the State Industrial Commission of Queensland as well as the rights of other Australians. I think it is quite fitting that I read into the record a telegram which I have just received which sums up the position very well. The telegram, which is addressed to my colleague Senator Stan Collard, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Master Plumbers Association of Queensland fully supports the Queensland Government in its recent industrial legislation.

The Association urges all Queensland senators to put the welfare of their State above party politics and to thus resist any moves by the Federal Government to bring down legislation which is a deliberate attempt to override State industrial legislation.
All thinking people must resist all union attempts at anarchy particularly when that anarchy is supported by a union dominated Federal Government.
There rests the case of the Liberal and National parties.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes to extend the bounty assistance currently provided to the shipbuilding industry in Australia to vessels constructed or modified for export from Australia.

The extended bounty assistance is part of a new shipbuilding industry package announced by the Government on 11 October 1984 following consideration of the report of a task force on the Australian shipbuilding industry released in January 1984. The task force was established by the then Minister for Industry and Commerce following representations from the Australian Shipbuilders' Association concerning the long-term viability of the local shipbuilding industry and its grim forward order situation.

The task force made several recommendations aimed at increasing the throughput of Australian shipyards. Concern was also expressed at the substantial increase in the number of yards constructing bountiable vessels since the introduction of the current bounty scheme on 1 July 1980. It was recommended to Government that it explore the possibility of prescribing conditions for the registration of shipyards.

I am happy to report that since the task force report a series of discussions have been held between the industry and the ACTU and both parties have agreed that they will try and achieve an industrial agreement covering a range of issues. This agreement represents a significant contribution by both the industry and trade unions.

As part of its contribution the Government has decided to remove the 2 per cent revenue duty from imported goods used in the construction or modification of bountiable vessels, to introduce certain registration criteria for eligibility for bounty, and to extend to vessels constructed or modified for export the bounty assistance currently provided to the industry.

It is proposed that the bounty be extended to vessels built for export for which construction was commenced on or after 10 December 1984. Bounty is currently payable at a rate of 25 per cent of construction costs for vessels commenced between 1 July 1984 and 1 July 1985; the bounty rate is to phase down to 22.5 per cent for vessels commenced between 1 July 1985 and 1 July 1986 then phasing to the long term rate of 20 per cent from 1 July 1986. There will be an annual limit on bounty payable on ships built for export; the limit being $6 million in 1984-85 and $10 million in 1985-86.

The Government believes that the extension of the bounty to vessels built for export combined with the recent improvements to the operating arrangements of the Export Finance Insurance Corporation (EFIC) will be very beneficial to the Australian shipbuilding industry. Exports should develop those sections of the shipbuilding industry most deserving of encouragement and should improve efficiency.

There are significant export prospects for the type and size of vessel built by the local industry. It has also become apparent that local yards may have lost potential export contracts to third markets because competing overseas yards appear to have received Government subsidies in addition to the usual export finance arrangements.

I mentioned earlier that part of the Government's shipbuilding package is the introduction of registration criteria for the purposes of bounty eligibility. These criteria will ensure that bounty is only paid to those shipbuilders with a clear long-term commitment to the industry. The criteria will not, however, prohibit entry into the industry by a shipbuilder prepared to undertake the necessary commitment. It is proposed that the Regulations prescribe the criteria to be met by applicants for registration and to this end clause 13 of the Bill includes suitable provisions in the new registration sections to enable the Regulations to prescribe conditions to be met by applicants for registration.

There has been a significant increase in the number of registered shipbuilders since the introduction of the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 on 1 July 1980. While it is difficult to estimate future domestic demand for ships it is apparent that there will be insufficient work to maintain the number of yards currently registered. The criteria should have a significant impact on the structure of the industry and it is estimated that when it is fully operative the 80 shipyards currently registered will be reduced to less than 30. The result should be a smaller, but more viable industry structure.

The proposed registration criteria were announced by the Government on 11 October 1984 in the context of the new shipbuilding industry package. To qualify for registration on or after 10 December 1984 a shipbuilder must:
(a) be a registered Australian company or organisation;
(b) demonstrate financial and commercial capability by way of an independent auditor's report to build a bountiable vessel;

(c) employ directly, or through nominated sub-contractors, or have demonstrated clearly that an average of 20 persons will be dedicated to shipbuilding throughout the period of construction for the purpose of building the bountiable vessel;

(d) have an ongoing apprenticeship scheme employing a ratio of at least 1 apprentice to 8 tradesmen directly employed by the shipyard, and encourage all sub-contractors to maintain a similar scheme; and
(e) own or have access to shipbuilding facilities including a waterfront site which are assessed as adequate for building the vessel or vessels for which registration is sought.

Registration may also be restricted to vessels of up to a specified size and if appropriate of a specified hull material. It is also proposed that the registration be valid only for a period of 12 months but may be renewed. I should point out, however, that any registration in force at the date of implementation of the proposed criteria will remain valid until completion of any bountiable vessels currently under construction or modification. This is one other aspect that I would like to make clear. If a shipbuilder was registered prior to the introduction of the new criteria and was not successful in gaining a new registration because of the inability to meet one of the above criteria the Minister will have the discretion to register.

The Government places great importance on continuing progress in the discussions between the industry and the unions. Because of the importance of these discussions to the long-term viability of the industry a Shipbuilding Consultative Group (SCG) has been established to monitor progress. This body consists of an industrialist, a Unionist and a Government representative. The Group will report to the Minister at least every three months.

If the reports from the SCG indicate that continual progress towards rationalisation is not being achieved, the Government will view the augmented assistance package. Whether the export bounty is paid beyond the 1985/86 financial year will depend on the degree of progress achieved. Subject to the combined industry/union response the Government will consider whether the general bounty assistance should also be reviewed.

The SCG is also responsible for advising on applications for registration from shipbuilders under the new criteria but the Minister will decide whether to grant or refuse registration of premises after report from that Group.

Finally, the Bill includes a number of provisions particularly in parts 3 and 4 which are designed to update the administrative provisions in the existing Act. These provisions are modelled along similar lines to provisions in recent bounty legislation.
Financial Impact Statement

The cost of the bounty assistance to vessels constructed or modified for export is limited by the provisions of clause 8 to $6 million in the period commencing on 10 December 1984 and ending on 30 June 1985 and to $10 million in relation to the financial year commencing on 1 July 1985. The assistance, if any beyond, the 1985/86 financial year will depend upon the degree of progress achieved by the industry. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (INTERCEPTION) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985[COGNATE BILLS:DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1985NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, may I suggest that the Senate have a cognate debate covering this Bill, the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1985 and the National Crime Authority (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a cognate debate covering these three measures? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985, the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1985 and the National Crime Authority (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985. I propose to address my remarks in the second reading debate to these three Bills in that order. The first Bill is the one that no doubt will excite the greatest interest, and maybe some controversy. It primarily arises out of events which occurred, to the great surprise of most people in this Parliament, at the end of March this year and which led to amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Bill, which are being further amended by this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: That serves to remind us of what occurred at the end of March this year when the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Government did a major about-face in relation to the policies and attitudes they were expressing in regard to the Age tapes, or the New South Wales police tapes, as they are now known. It will be recalled that over 12 months ago the Age newspaper obtained some tapes, published some, and handed to the then Attorney-General a great volume of material which, it appears likely, had been prepared as a result of the illegal interception of telephones by a unit of the New South Wales police. Those tapes were alleged to contain a large amount of information about crime in New South Wales over quite a long period. Some of the material published in the Age newspaper was referred by the Attorney-General of the day to a police task force and then to the Director of Public Prosecutions to consider what should be done. Without going over the history of the matter, from the moment those revelations were made the Opposition called for a royal commission into the use of the tapes and how they were obtained, what use had been made of them, what use ought to have been made of them, and whether they would be made available to assist further in the prosecution of major criminals, operating particularly in New South Wales but no doubt throughout Australia and particularly, although not exclusively confined to, drug trafficking.

Throughout last year and until the end of March this year the Government steadfastly opposed the idea of a royal commission into these matters. Steps of one sort or another were taken, in many cases forced on a reluctant Government by this Opposition, but nevertheless certain steps were taken. We maintained that the only proper step was to establish a royal commission into this whole matter. At the end of March the Attorney-General, on behalf of the Government, announced that although there would not be a new royal commission established to investigate these matters, the terms of reference of Mr Justice Stewart, who for some time has had a commission from the Governor-General to investigate other matters relating to drug trafficking, would be extended to cover an investigation into the New South Wales police tapes, including what further information could usefully be obtained from them for the purposes of prosecutions, whether or not prosecutions should be launched, whether full use had been made of the tapes, whether they were authentic and, if so, to what extent. There were a large number of questions, all of which raised very major issues which at long last this Government admitted deserved and required the attention of a royal commissioner. So Mr Justice Stewart has now been given those extended terms of reference to do just that.

The Government also required that all of those tapes, some of which had already been referred to Mr Justice Stewart in one of his other capacities, be made available to him. They may have revealed crimes against Federal laws or New South Wales State laws, but the material, if it had been obtained by illegally intercepting telephone conversations, could not be referred to Mr Justice Stewart without an amendment to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. This Parliament was invited to pass that amendment, and the Opposition gave the fullest co-operation to the Government to enable the legislation to be passed without delay. If my recollection is correct, the legislation was passed within a day or so at the most and Mr Justice Stewart's terms of reference were extended. So the Government, under this pressure from the Opposition for over 12 months, finally agreed to this proper course of action upon which Mr Justice Stewart has now embarked.

But, as with so many things that this Government embarks upon, particularly in regard to its attention to the problem of organised crime in this country, it did not do the job properly. It failed in this legislation, although, as I said, it had every co-operation from the Opposition, to ensure that Mr Justice Stewart had full power to inspect these materials which were referred to him and which his terms of reference were extended to encompass. The Government did not enable him to receive material which may have revealed only offences against New South Wales criminal laws. The purpose of this amendment to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act is to correct that error or omission. An explanation of how it came about has never really been made by the Attorney-General, either in the other place or through the Minister who represents him here, but this legislation is the result. It is needed and, of course, the Opposition supports it.

In order, I suppose, to give some respectability to the Government in this matter, the Government is now proposing two further amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act, but I think they have been introduced at this stage simply to put this omission into the context of a fuller amendment of the Act for the sake of appearances. I do not propose to go into those matters in any detail. One is simply to give power to the police in cases of emergencies to seek to intercept telephones in order to trace calls which may have been threatening or distress calls. There is at present some doubt as to whether that can be done. This legislation provides for that to be done, and the Opposition will support it.

The other matter to which I refer would perhaps cause some debate and it has certainly caused some concern. The Law Council of Australia has expressed some concern about it. It enables the Managing Director of Telecom Australia to issue a certificate which sets out the facts relating to actions by officers of the Commission to carry out a warrant for the interception of a telephone lawfully issued under the authority of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. That authority is given, as I said, by judicial warrant to the Australian Federal Police for the purpose of intercepting the telephones of people who are suspected of engaging in drug trafficking. If that interception results in evidence which could be useful in a trial, proof has to be given as to the actual mechanics by which the telephone was intercepted. Purely routine type of evidence as to how that was actually done would have to be produced by Telecom officials. This legislation enables that evidence to be given in the form of a certificate signed by the Managing Director. It is a conclusive certificate-in other words, it cannot be challenged-but it can relate only, as I said, to the mechanical processes carried out by officers of Telecom. Apparently the reason for that is that such officers have expressed concern about being identified in giving this sort of evidence, and the Government believes that this is an appropriate course to take. The Opposition has given consideration to this matter with earnestness and concern, but on the whole we believe that it is justified because we really cannot see how such a certificate could in any way prejudice the rights of an accused person because of the very narrow way in which this conclusive certificate is constructed in the legislation. However, it is clearly something which will have to be very closely watched.

Returning to the Government's change of policy in relation to this legislation and the whole matter of the New South Wales police tapes, I notice that my colleague in the other place, when speaking in the debate on this Bill, raised a number of questions with the Attorney-General, none of which the Attorney answered-which is not surprising in the light of the way in which that Minister is performing his role. But the Opposition is particularly interested in what has actually happened since Mr Justice Stewart had his powers extended and since the amendments we made to the legislation to enable him to effectively investigate the police tapes. One of the major matters of concern is whether the police, who it was hoped would co-operate and to whom indemnities were to be offered, have in fact come forward and accepted indemnities in one of the two forms that were mentioned by the Attorney-General in the House of Representatives and by his representative in this chamber, Senator Gareth Evans. There was some confusion as to how these indemnities would be offered and how they would work. The Opposition is interested to know just what is the position in relation to those matters. Perhaps Senator Gareth Evans will answer those questions.

I turn to the other legislation in this package; firstly to the amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act. Again, this is legislation to give effect to a matter which the Opposition has been supporting for some time, and which the Government has been delaying in implementing. The office of Director of Public Prosecutions was established by this Government, with the support of the Opposition. He is primarily a prosecutor, certainly, but he has not been given power to bring civil proceedings unless a prosecution has been launched by him. That limitation on his powers has been criticised by a succession of people who would, I think, have expert knowledge of the work that he would be doing-particularly, one of the special prosecutors who had both these powers, Mr Redlich, who recommended that the Director of Public Prosecutions should have the power to bring civil proceedings regardless of whether he has in fact commenced criminal proceedings. The Director of Public Prosecutions himself last year drew the attention of the Government and of this Parliament to that deficiency in the Act, and Mr Costigan, in his final report last year, drew attention to that requirement. Of course, all these people have had very close experience of conducting investigations and prosecutions of major crime, particularly those dealing with the revenue, and they had found the importance of being able to bring civil remedies quickly in order to freeze money before it disappears, often out of the country.

However, the Government did not act at all promptly in relation to this matter, despite the advice that it had. During the election campaign the Opposition said that it would amend this Act to give these powers to the Director of Public Prosecutions. That was reiterated early this year by my colleague the shadow Attorney-General. Fortunately, at long last, we have a Bill before us, promoted by the Government, to do just that and the Opposition will be supporting it.

When I was speaking earlier on the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2), I omitted to say that the Opposition proposed to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of that Bill, I move:
At end of motion, add: '', but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(a) telephone interception powers can be a valuable aid in the investigation of drug trafficking;
(b) the Commonwealth should extend such powers in relation to drug trafficking to the States, subject to stringent controls being exercised over their use; and
(c) those controls should include a requirement for judicial warrants.''.

The reason this amendment has been moved by the Opposition is that we have felt for some time that the power to intercept telephones for the investigation of drug trafficking crimes which is held by the Australian Federal Police should be extended to the State police. Certainly, the State police forces have been complaining for some time that they do not have that power. It has proved to be a very useful power for the Federal Police. As investigations are often conducted by joint police task forces and both Federal and State drug trafficking offences are often involved, it does not make any sense that that power should be held only by the Federal Police and not State police. We propose that such power be confined in the same strict way as the existing legislation provides. We have set out our views in the amendment I have moved.

When this matter was proposed by the Opposition in the House of Representatives, the Attorney-General said he would accept it. It does accord with the views that were expressed by the Government after the drug summit early in April, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a great show of the initiatives that the Commonwealth Government would take in regard to drug trafficking in Australia. He said that that power would be offered to the States. However, we have not heard anything more about that. It would be a matter of some surprise if the States did not take up that offer. Several weeks ago in the other place the Attorney-General said that the Government had not responded to this proposal but that he would accept the Opposition's proposed amendment. However, no doubt something went wrong procedurally in the way in which the sausage machine was operating over there. The amendment seemed to have got mixed up and misunderstood and it was not actually passed. We hope that the Senate, with the Government's support, will pass the amendment that I have moved. I would also like to hear from the Minister representing the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, just what is happening in regard to the implementation of that major feature of the Government's response at the drug summit about which we had heard nothing. We have had a flood of legislation in this Parliament in the last two or three weeks. One would have thought, in the light of that offer by the Prime Minister, that something would have been done about this matter. The fact that nothing has been done is of some concern. Unfortunately, as we have seen, most responses of this Government in regard to initiatives for dealing with organised crime in this country are slow and seem to be undertaken only after pressure from the Opposition, as a result of public opinion or other pressures.

The final Bill, the National Crime Authority (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, concerns amendments to the National Crime Authority Act. The Opposition will support those amendments. The amendments concern access to tax records by the Authority, again with a judicial warrant. That power is extended from the Income Tax Assessment Act to all taxation assessment Acts. Clearly it is the sort of information which has been of great use to the National Crime Authority, and will continue to be so, and will be of great use to any royal commission inquiring into crime. Therefore, we support the legislation. However, we propose to move an amendment to extend the powers of the National Crime Authority even further. I will deal with that matter in the Committee stage. The Opposition supports the measures. I have moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2). I trust the Senate will support that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thrust of the three Bills presently before the Senate is to provide mechanisms for the interdiction of crime. The first Bill, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2), as already mentioned by Senator Durack, allows evidence of the technical tapping of telephones to be provided by averment. There is some concern with that. I understand that later speakers will address that concern. Perhaps I should say that the Bill is directed to the protection of Telecom Australia technicians. Their union is particularly concerned that they be protected against criminal activity, particularly the activity of drug pushers-the barons of the drug trade whose mark includes that of a willingness to resort to murder and maiming to enforce their will.
—You sound like a B-grade movie.

—Yes. Well, one can understand in those circumstances the concerns that the union has. The second thing that the Bill does is to include crime against State laws in the category of crimes in respect of which unlawfully obtained materials within the meaning of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1985 can be used. The third point is that it allows Telecom to trace a call for the purpose of meeting an emergency situation, for example, a threatened suicide. One can see the merit, indeed the necessity, for that power to enable the authorities to trace the origin of a call which is made by someone who is distressed.

SPEECH.PARA: The thrust of the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1985 is to enable the Director of Public Prosecutions to take civil actions against people in respect of whom criminal proceedings have been instituted or contemplated. It should be understood that that is confined to a situation in which the Director of Public Prosecutions has criminal proceedings in mind or has instituted them. Of course, the court before whom the proceedings are brought has a discretion to restrict the publication of those proceedings. That provision is inserted to safeguard the civil rights of people who may be taken to court on a civil action and yet never have any criminal proceedings brought against them.

The National Crime Authority (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985 is directed to making information in the hands of government bodies available to the National Crime Authority at the same time as providing appropriate protection of civil rights. It strikes a balance between the interests of the state in detecting and punishing crime and the rights of individuals. These Bills as a whole steer the appropriate course between public interest and private rights. They deserve the support of the Senate. Indeed, in speeches following mine there may be calls for more draconian measures. I hope that is not the situation. It would be a pity to see an auction in crime prevention mechanisms and in criminal sanctions-each speaker outbidding the last in advocating the sorts of mechanisms he would employ to detect crime and in terms of the sanctions he would employ if he had the legislative capacity to introduce them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would definitely be a great movie.

—But an exciting one, I am sure the honourable senator would have to concede. In these circumstances I make several points. The first is that the balance between the interests of the state and individual rights must be of continuous concern. At the moment the public debate on crime seems to me to be putting the present balance at risk in favour of state interests and against those of the individual. That is why Parliament should earnestly debate the issues raised by Bills like those presently before the Senate. The detection and punishment of crime are not the only considerations in this context. There is also the issue of the means by which crime is detected and punished. If the means by which crime is detected is made too draconian and too oppressive and if little regard is had for civil rights, it is likely that more criminal activity will be detected and punished. However, do we want that? A learned judge made the following statement in 1846 in a civil case, and it is very apt to the present consideration:

SPEECH.PARA: The discovery and vindication and establishment of truth are main purposes certainly of the existence of Courts of Justice; still, for the obtaining of these objects, which, however valuable and important, cannot be usefully pursued without moderation, cannot be either usefully or creditably pursued unfairly or gained by unfair means, not every channel is or ought to be open to them. The practical inefficacy of torture is not, I suppose, the most weighty objection to that mode of examination, nor probably would the purpose of the mere disclosure of truth have been otherwise than advanced by a refusal on the part of the Lord Chancellor in 1815 to act against the solicitor, who, in the cause between Lord Cholmondeley and Lord Clinton, had acted or proposed to act in the manner which Lord Eldon thought it right to prohibit. Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely-may be pursued too keenly-may cost too much. And surely the meanness and the mischief of prying into a man's confidential consultations with his legal adviser, the general evil of infusing reserve and dissimulation, uneasiness, and suspicion and fear, into those communications which must take place, and which, unless in a condition of perfect security, must take place uselessly or worse, are too great a price to pay for truth itself.

That sort of statement made by the learned Lord Chancellor must be kept in mind particularly when questions of phone tapping or invasions of privacy arise. The civil rights this community has inherited have been hard won and should not be squandered. As a community, we face a particular problem at a particular time in history. In that context it should be remembered that precedents can be established which may well become oppressive in the future and thus harass following generations.

The processes by which crime is detected and investigated and by which alleged criminals are prosecuted, convicted and punished reflect the character and quality of the society within which those processes operate. The separation of functions is a dimension of them. In Australia it is usual for police to detect and investigate, for a prosecutor to present a case against an alleged criminal, and for a judicial body to assess that evidence and to convict and punish if considered appropriate. Civil proceedings have generally been kept distinct from those functions. In my view, changes in those conventions put at risk the character and quality of society. Conventions which affect civil rights, the functioning of a free society and the proper balance between individual liberties and the state interest should not be readily altered in favour of the state. These Bills have kept those values very much in mind. In my view, and hopefully in the Senate's view, they strike a happy medium between those two considerations and provide a proper approach to the situation we presently face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Cooney has already pointed out, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985, the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1985 and the National Crime Authority (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985 form part of this Government's attack on organised crime in Australia and they have the support of all parties in this place. The DPP legislation and the National Crime Authority legislation are essentially non-controversial. In the main, the National Crime Authority legislation extends section 20 exemption provisions to certain other sensitive information and documents which have not up to this stage been included. These primarily relate to personal or commercial data and to information given to courts, tribunals and so on. The Australian Democrats certainly support this legislation, as do the Opposition parties. We will also be supporting the unusually sensible second reading attachment from the Liberal Party regarding the need for the National Crime Authority to act in a co-ordinated manner with the activities of authorities and persons in other countries who are performing similar functions to those of the National Crime Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: The Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1985 is somewhat more complex but not particularly controversial either. All it does is extend to the Director of Public Prosecutions some additional powers to pursue civil remedies on behalf of the Commonwealth for the recovery of unpaid taxes and duties. When the principal Act was first drafted there was some discussion about exactly what powers the Director of Public Prosecutions would be given as to civil remedies on the one hand and the recovery of pecuniary penalties on the other hand. The exercise of both these powers was limited to matters designated by the Attorney-General and tended to authorise him only to recover pecuniary penalties in relation to tax matters. This Bill extends his powers, and again we support that.

The controversial legislation is the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985, over which both the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the Law Council of Australia have raised some concern. Essentially, there are two elements to this legislation. Firstly, it enables Telecom Australia, in specified emergency situations, to intercept a telephone call in order to establish the location of a caller so that appropriate assistance can be given. Some fairly appropriate examples have been given by speakers tonight. Secondly, it enables formal evidence of acts done by Telecom employees, in enabling members of the Australian Federal Police to execute an interception warrant, to be given by certificate in court proceedings. It is in that area that concerns have been raised. The Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee, in the report that was tabled today, under the heading 'Clause 6-Evidentiary certificates' states:

Clause 6 inserts a new section 25A in the Principal Act providing that the Managing Director of Telecom may issue a certificate setting out facts with respect to acts or things done by or in relation to officers of the Commission in the execution of warrants permitting the interception of communications made to or from a telecommunications service. Such a certificate is to be conclusive evidence of the matters stated in the document in proceedings by way of prosecution for narcotics offences.

The Committee is concerned that in proceedings relating to serious criminal offences evidence should be able to be given by way of conclusive certificate. The Committee acknowledges the weight of the reasons advanced by the Attorney-General in his Second Reading Speech in support of the amendment, in particular the need to protect Telecom employees involved in narcotic interception from public identification because of fears for their safety and the safety of their families.

However, it still went on to point out that there was some infringement of civil liberties involved in the operation of this clause. The Law Council of Australia expressed its concern about this proposed new section much more strongly. The Privacy Law Committee of the Law Council of Australia was reconstituted, at the request of the LCA's Secretary-General, on an ad hoc basis specifically to consider the amendment to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. I understand that that Committee comprised Malcolm McCusker, QC, Robert French and Malcolm Hall. They have come up with a very lengthy memorandum which sets out their concerns. In the interests of the speedy passage of this legislation tonight, I seek leave to incorporate that memorandum in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The memorandum read as follows-
MEMORANDUM
To: Law Council of Australia
From: Ad Hoc Privacy Law Committee
Re: Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985

The Privacy Law Committee of the Law Council of Australia was, at the request of the Secretary General, reconstituted on an ad hoc basis to consider an amendment to the Telecommunications (Interceptions) Act 1979. The committee so reconstituted comprised Malcolm McCusker Q.C., Robert French and Malcolm Hall.
The Amending Bill, which was introduced into the House of Representatives on the 9th May 1985 will, if passed, be cited as the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Act (No. 2) 1985.
The provision of the Bill which is of concern to the Law Council is clause 6 which proposes the insertion of a new section designated 25A in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
A general outline of the Bill contained in an explanatory memorandum explains the function of the proposed new provision as follows:

''The Bill also provides for evidence of formal matters in respect of acts done by Telecom employees for the purpose of enabling the execution of an interception warrant issued to the Australian Federal Police in the course of a narcotics investigation to be given in certain proceedings by a certificate signed by the Managing Director of Telecom. This provision is designed to protect the identity of Telecom employees engaged in such activities.''
Notes on the Bill's clauses are also set out in the explanatory memorandum and in relation to Section 25A state:

''This clause provides that a certificate signed by the Managing Director of Telecom, setting out such facts as he considers relevant with respect to acts or things done by or in relation to officers of the Commission for the purpose of enabling the execution of an interception warrant issued to the Australian Federal Police for the purposes of a narcotics investigation is conclusive evidence of matters stated in the certificate in specified proceedings.''
The full extent of the potential operation of the proposed amendment can best be appreciated by setting out precisely how it falls into the statutory framework.
Statutory Framework

Section 20 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 empowers Judges of the Federal Court to issue warrants authorising the interception by officers of the Australian Federal Police of communications made to or from the telecommunication service.

Interception consists of listening to or recording by any means a communication in its passage over the telecommunication system without the knowledge of the person making the communication. (See Section 6 of the Principal Act)
The use in evidence of information obtained from intercepted communications is facilitated by Section 7 (6) of the Principal Act which provides:

''Without limiting the application of subsection (4), a person may give information obtained by intercepting a communication passing over a telecommunications system, or obtained by virtue of a warrant issued under Section 11 or 21, in evidence in a proceeding-
(a) by way of a prosecution for a narcotics offence;
(b) by way of a prosecution for an offence against the Telecommunications Act 1975 or a Regulation or Bylaw in force under that Act;

(c) by way of a prosecution for any other offence against the law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period or maximum period, of not less than 3 years;
(d) by way of an application for an order under sub-section 243B (1) of the Customs Act 1901; or
(e) for the condemnation or recovery of a ship or aircraft, or of goods, seized under Section 203 of the Customs Act 1901 in connection with the commission of a narcotics offence.''

Sub-section (4) of Section 7 which is referred to in the opening words of sub-section (6) prohibits the communication to any other person or the use or recording of information obtained by the interception of a communication passing over a telecommunication system or obtained by virtue of a warrant except in certain specified circumstances which are not material for present purposes.

It is important to note that the power given to a Judge of the Federal Court to issue warrants under Section 20 is limited to the case where there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the telecommunication service is being or is likely to be used by a person who has committed or is suspected on reasonable grounds of having committed, or of being likely to commit, a narcotics offence.

Notwithstanding that limitation the provisions of Section 7 sub-section (6) allow the use of information obtained pursuant to such a warrant in proceedings relating to a wide range of Commonwealth and State offences not limited to narcotics offences.
The Proposed New Section 25A
As it appears in the Bill the proposed new Section 25A provides:

''25A (1) The Managing Director of the Commission may issue a certificate in writing signed by the Managing Director setting out such facts as the Managing Director considers relevant with respect to acts or things done by or in relation to officers of the Commission for the purpose of enabling a warrant issued under Section 20 to be executed.

(2) A document purporting to be a certificate issued under subsection (1) and purporting to be signed by the Managing Director of the Commission shall be received in evidence in a proceeding of a kind referred to in subsection 7 (6) without further proof and is, in that proceeding, conclusive evidence of the matters stated in the document.''

It is immediately apparent that the conclusive evidentiary effect of the certificate in relation to facts stated in it is not limited to proceedings for narcotics offences but the whole range of proceedings defined by Section 7 (6) in which information obtained from intercepted communications may be used.
Comment Upon Proposed Amendment

Assuming the amendment on its proper construction to be as is contended in the explanatory memorandum, it is nevertheless fundamentally objectionable. The fundamental objection lies in the use of a ''conclusive evidence'' provision to preclude challenge to any of the matters certified by the Managing Director of the Commission.
This is not a reversal of the burden of proof of the kind that occurs with provisions giving prima facie effect to prosecutorial averments. (See for example Crimes Act Section 30R).
This provision effectively silences an accused person in respect of the matters the subject of the certificate and prevents any answer to the Managing Director's assertions of fact.

For this reason alone the provision is in clear conflict with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its Report on the Burden of Proof in Criminal Proceedings (Parliamentary Paper 319/1982 published November 1982).
The members of that Committee were:
Senator Allan Missen
Senator Gareth Evans
Senator Noel Crichton-Browne
Senator Robert Hill
Senator Susan Ryan, and
Senator Michael Tate
In particular the Committee considered the use of provisions such as Crimes Act Section 30R giving prima facie effect to prosecutorial averments and said at paragraph 7.12 of the Report:

''The comparatively substantial increase in the number of averment provisions in recent years coupled with the potential for abuse by prosecutors has led us to the conclusion that there should be restrictions as to their use. While the Committee recognises that there is a legitimate need for such provisions, especially in circumstances where the prosecutor faces an insurmountable difficulty of proof, the inability of prosecutors in the past to use averments within reasonable limits is a matter of concern to us.''
At 7.13 the Committee referred to the need for objective criteria to limit the circumstances in which averments can be used.
In particular it cited from and agreed with a joint submission from the New South Wales Bar Association, the Law Society of New South Wales and the Sydney University Law Graduates Association:

''It should be a fundamental requirement before any use of an averment provision that the Crown must prove that the facts averred, if in truth they exist, are within the knowledge of the Defendant or that the Defendant has peculiar means of knowledge of the facts averred and that it is not reasonably practicable for the prosecutor to lead evidence to establish such matter.''

The Committee also cited from the first report of the Regulations Advisory Committee to the Commonwealth Attorney-General on 15th July 1944 which recommended that averment should be resorted to in the following cases:
(a) Where the matter which the prosecution is required to prove is formal only and does not in itself relate to any conduct on the part of the Defendant;
(b) Where the matter in question relates to conduct of the defendant alleged to constitute an ingredient in the offence charged and-
(i) such matter is peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant; and
(ii) it is not reasonably practicable for the prosecutor to lead evidence to establish such matter.
The Senate Committee's own recommendations at paragraph 7.16 were in the following terms:
''(a) As a matter of legislative policy averment provisions should be kept to a minimum.
(b) The Parliament should enact legislation to ensure that existing and future averment provisions are only resorted to by prosecutors in the following circumstances:
(i) where the matter which the prosecution is required to prove is formal only and does not in itself relate to any conduct on the part of the defendant; or
(ii) where the matter in question relates to conduct of the defendant alleged to constitute an ingredient in the offence charged and is peculiarly within the defendant's knowledge.''

It hardly needs to be said what the Committee recommended about averments of prima facie effect has significantly greater force in relation to conclusive evidence provisions, assuming that the Committee would have been prepared to entertain the possibility of such provisions at all.
Nothing in the explanatory memorandum or the terms of the amendments suggests a justification for this provision which would fall within the Senate Committee's guidelines for prima facie averments.

Quite apart from the inherent vice of the extreme privative operation of the provision proposed, it has a potential operation limited only by the Managing Director's ingenuity in discerning what is 'relevant with respect to matters or things done by or in relation to officers of the Commission for the purpose of enabling a warrant issued under Section 20 to be executed'.
An obvious example illustrates the breadth of the provision.

Were an officer of the Commission to transcribe a conversation intercepted pursuant to a warrant, then the Managing Director could under this provision conclusively certify that transcript to be a true record of the conversation.
It is no answer to this objection to say that this is an extreme example and that officers of the Commissioner would never be involved in recording or transcription.
That is a matter for which there is no statutory guarantee.
It is an answer which can only rest upon the shifting sands of administrative arrangements.

The subjective nature of ''such facts as the Managing Director considers relevant'' confers upon the provision an unacceptable width that compounds the fundamental objection to its privative operation.
If the object of the provision is to protect the identity of Commission officers that is an object which could be achieved in other ways.
One such way would be to authorise or require a Court to suppress disclosure of the name of such a person if called as a witness or otherwise referred to in evidence.
It should also be noted that the proposed provision conflicts with the terms of Articles 14 (2) and 14 (3) (e) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which provide:
''Article 14 (2)
Everyone charged with a crime shall have the right to be presumed innocent until proved guilty according to law.
Article 14 (3) (e)

14 (3) In the determination of any criminal charge against him everyone shall be entitled to the following minimum guarantees, in full equality: (e) To examine, or have examined, the witnesses against him and to obtain the attendance and examination of witnesses on his behalf under the same conditions as witnesses against him.''
CONCLUSION
In the view of the Committee the proposed Section 25A should not be passed into law for three reasons:

(i) Because it gives conclusive effect to the Managing Director's certificate and this, unlike standard averment provisions, goes further than reversing the burden of proof to effectively silencing the accused person.
(ii) The width of the Section is so great as to allow the certification of facts which may go well beyond the limits of what is considered ''formal'' matter.
(iii) The provision conflicts with Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
Dated the 24th May 1985.
M. J. McCusker Q.C.R. S. FrenchM. Hall

TALK.START.PARA: —In short and in essence, the Privacy Law Committee's objection to proposed new section 25A runs along similar lines to that of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, namely that it is an invasion of privacy and that it precludes challenge to any of the matters certified by the Managing Director of the Commission. The proposed new section also appears to be in conflict with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its report on the burden of proof in criminal proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Scrutiny of Bills Committee accepts the fact-and, I presume, so does the Law Council of Australia-that something must be done in order to protect Telecom employees, particularly those involved in narcotic interception, from the public identification, one is forced to ask whether the same protection could have been given to those employees without going down this particular route. I would be interested to hear from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) or his advisers whether consideration was given to any other means of achieving the alleged purpose of this amendment. There is no question that it does infringe civil liberties fairly severely and while the need for protection is there, there is, as the Law Council points out, the problem that it precludes challenge to any of the matters certified by the Managing Director of the Commission. That, in itself, is a worry. However, because the three Bills before us are part of the Government's and indeed the Parliament's efforts to combat or contain organised crime in this country, we will support them. We will also support the Liberal amendments to the National Crime Authority (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1985 and other Bills which are being debated cognately. I direct the bulk of my remarks to the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill because I do not think it has yet been sufficiently emphasised in this debate what a remarkable and novel piece of legislation the Senate is considering tonight.
—What about the powers of the Special Prosecutors?

—I may come to that. The Special Prosecutors were set up for a specific purpose for a limited time. Here the Director of Public Prosecutions is given a very secure tenure, although he is required to report to the Parliament and any directions given by the Attorney-General as to the exercise of his office must be put under some sort of scrutiny by the Parliament. Nevertheless, his office is a long-standing one and he may hope to occupy it for a considerable time. This distinguishes him from the Special Prosecutors.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the English or State equivalents of the office of Director of Public Prosecutions, under this Bill the DPP will pursue, where appropriate, civil remedies on behalf of the Commonwealth and its authorities at a stage not merely where prosecutions have been instituted or undertaken, or where it is anticipated that they might be instituted or undertaken, but where he is merely considering a proposal that he undertake them or even take them over from some other person who is already proposing to launch a prosecution. It is a rather unusual situation and I think there can be sufficient justification for it, but it warrants some emphasis, particularly in view of the fact that under clause 3 of the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill the link between the taking of a civil remedy and a relevant prosecution or anticipated prosecution that is said to be required by the Bill is not able to be challenged. There is an ousting of the court's jurisdiction, so that the link which the Parliament says must be in place to justify the Director of Public Prosecutions to pursue a civil remedy cannot be tested in the courts.

That also requires some comment in the Senate. I do not say that there is an alternative way of overcoming the problem. Of course one would not want the Director of Public Prosecutions to have to foreshadow in some court proceedings whether and on what basis-and whether it is a sufficiently sound basis-he is considering appropriate action under some portion of the criminal law. Nevertheless, it requires comment because it is an unusual situation for the person whose office was instituted to undertake prosecutions and that part of the Attorney-General's functions is vested in him-to be vested with the power to pursue civil remedies.

It is particularly worthy of comment because the general rule is that if a person is about to face some sort of criminal proceeding-for example, a person who has a car accident and who may be charged with manslaughter-then it would be quite improper and the courts would not permit generally speaking, I understand, some civil proceedings to do with an insurance claim to be undertaken before the criminal proceedings, for fear that the person would, by way of cross-examination, be required to divulge information which would then be of use during the criminal prosecution. It is that particular danger that needs to be noted and commented upon. I know from my chairing of the Caucus legal committee that it was the subject of extensive discussion within the Government party and was in some small measure met by the provision that the court may suppress publication of the proceedings in the civil jurisdiction. But of course that is directed simply to not permitting a situation to develop where a potential juror's mind could be inflamed or prejudiced by having read that the DPP had pursued civil proceedings, perhaps successfully, against an accused person. It does not meet the point I am making, that it is extremely unusual for a prosecutor to be permitted to pursue a civil remedy and subject the person concerned to cross-examination which may then be used in a subsequent criminal proceeding to test credit or in some such way. Therefore, it is worth commenting upon.

Senator Cooney, in a splendid and, as always, thoughtful address to the Senate, pointed out that attention and balance have to be considered, and I think the Bill, on the whole, has served a public purpose. What is that public purpose? Let me now refer to the National Crime Authority's report. I see that the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, has joined us in the chamber. He played a distinguished role also on that extended Senate committee, as did my colleagues who considered the Bill and came up with a proposal acceptable to this chamber, to the Government and I believe, as history will tell, to the nation. In that report, we found it to be a fact-it has been commented upon subsequently by the reports published and tabled in this place by Special Prosecutors Redlich and Gyles-that there was an absence of will, and certainly of co-ordination, among Commonwealth authorities in pursuing civil remedies where their pursuit, particularly by the Australian Taxation Office in relation to those who were engaging in criminal activities, could itself have been a very potent weapon in combating criminal activities. This applies particularly to criminals engaged in crime of the type we are trying to suppress-the drug trade in particular-because of the enormous profits which they unscrupulously obtain from the vulnerable and weak in our society and then devote to their nefarious purposes and of course to their own self-indulgence. If we undertake some activity which deprives them of the benefits of that nefarious activity we would probably be hurting them in a way which is much more realistic and much more likely to deter them than the occasional prosecution which is launched, perhaps with some degree of success or another.
