In fact, we thought it very important in our discussions on the National Crime Authority reference that robust steps be taken to pursue civil remedies where they are appropriate. We believe that the Director of Public Prosecutions probably has a role in that regard because, quite frankly, Commonwealth authorities still seem to be protecting their own turf. They do not seem to be that keen to devote resources to the pursuit of offences against their various statutes and requirements. In that situation the Director of Public Prosecutions may well be vested with that power if the link occurs, though, as I have said, that cannot be tested in the courts with a prosecution.

Because we are discussing such an unusual phenomenon tonight, it is proposed that a special report be prepared by the Director of Public Prosecutions at the end of two years experience of this legislation, as it will be enacted and in operation and that that should be presented to the Parliament for our consideration. To be quite frank, I think two years is a little too long. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-probably in October this year in any case-will be having a public hearing with the Director of Public Prosecutions in order to consider not only his first report, which has been tabled before this Parliament, but also by then, we hope, his second report because we want to pursue many matters with him, including, out of interest, the factors which govern the exercise of prosecution discretions. He wrote a very interesting article in an Australian Law Journal-

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm sorry, I did not hear that.

—We wish also to pursue the factors which govern the exercise of prosecution discretions; whether to pursue a matter to prosecution. The Director of Public Prosecutions may have to take into account the seriousness of the offence. According to Mr Temby, in an article in the ALJ, there is also some possibility that one should take into account the public office held by the accused. There may be a need to clear the air or muddy the waters, as the case may be, by a prosecution and I think all that has to be sorted out. In any case, we will have the Director of Public Prosecutions before us and we may get some early indication of how he sees himself exercising this power because it is something which must be put under parliamentary scrutiny since judicial scrutiny is ousted by that clause which, as I have said, prevents one from looking at the link between the pursuit of a civil remedy and an actual or anticipated prosecution.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note, and I think it is worth while to comment, that this additional power vested in the Director of Public Prosecutions will cost the taxpayer some $3m, I think it is, this financial year and $13m in the full year. From the experience of Mr Redlich one can confidently anticipate that, if exercised robustly-and fairly, of course-this operation by the Director of Public Prosecutions will recoup much more than the costs of running the office. As I have said, not only will many millions of dollars in funds flow to the Federal Treasury as a result of his action-that may be anticipated-but also the fact that he is undertaking these pursuits of civil remedies in cases where the Australian Taxation Office or other government authorities or agencies refuse to devote the resources that are required, I believe will itself be very salutary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without going into personalities, how can this Parliament be informed by the committee as to whether the Director of Public Prosecutions at any time is doing a good job or a bad job?

—I believe that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs may be a servant of the Senate as a whole in this regard and it will be undertaking a review in October by way of taking public evidence from Mr Temby as to the operation of his office. I think the Senate will find that that examination will be quite searching. It will be based, of course, on the tabled annual reports which he will have made available by then. Of course, any honourable senator is entitled to sit in on that Committee but not vote, should there be a requirement to do so. I am sure that Senator Chipp would be welcome at that table.

SPEECH.PARA: Dealing with the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2), I simply want to comment on the point, which is very well made, that the provision for evidentiary certificates is quite unusual, in that the Managing Director of the Australian Telecommunications Commission may issue a certificate in writing signed by him setting out the fact that certain employees of Telecom have undertaken the tapping of telephones when requested to do so by the Australian Federal Police under a judicial warrant. I have come to the conclusion that this evidentiary proceeding is justified. Telecom employees have made it known that they fear harassment and intimidation were they to be singled out and named for having taken part, in a purely technical way, in an operation authorised by judicial warrant. Of course, if it became widely known that Telecom employees were subject to such harassment, one could expect no co-operation from them in the tapping of telephones as required under the judicial warrant. But that would not be sufficient. The fact is that we are concerned with a purely formal matter.

I believe that, whereas the Senate Standing Committee raised a cautionary note in relation to the use of such conclusive evidentiary certificates, it is also true that we said in that report that prosecutors may resort to them where the matter which the prosecution is required to prove is formal only-as would be, the placing of some sort of instrumentation on the line-and does not relate to any conduct on the part of the defendant. I think that is the case in this instance, and on that balance it may be justified.

That is all I wish to say in relation to these Bills. There are matters of great moment and unusual character in these Bills, and I think it is essential that the Parliament and this Senate in particular, through its committees, keep an eye on the actual operation of this legislation. I can assure the Senate, and indeed the general public, that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs will undertake that responsibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985, the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1985 and the National Crime Authority (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985. I intend to restrict my comments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985. One might draw the conclusion that the Bill, on the surface, is of no great moment. However, I take quite a different view. Some of the matters I propose to raise have been raised already by Senator Haines, and the anxieties she has quite properly expressed reflect some of the anxieties I have. In reading the explanatory memorandum attached to the Bill, or the second reading speech of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), one could draw the conclusion that clause 6, which amends section 25 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act, is designed to allow the certificates signed by the Managing Director of Telecom to be conclusive evidence of certain facts as they relate only to narcotics investigations. The explanatory memorandum reference to clause 6, under the heading 'Evidentiary certificates' explains the amendment. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: This clause provides that a certificate signed by the Managing Director of Telecom, setting out such facts as he considers relevant with respect to acts or things done by or in relation to officers of the Commission for the purpose of enabling the execution of an interception warrant issued to the Australian Federal Police for the purposes of a narcotics investigation is conclusive evidence of matters stated in the certificate in specified proceedings.
I emphasise the words referred to in the second reading speech and explanatory memorandum 'for the purposes of a narcotics investigation'. The Minister's second reading speech reads, in part:

Initially, material obtained by interception was used for criminal intelligence purposes. However, as it is admissible as evidence in criminal proceedings, there are cases where it is appropriate and necessary to put the material into evidence.

Strict proof of actions taken by Telecom employees would require those employees to give evidence in court. Telecom management has been advised that employees are unwilling to give such evidence because public identification of their involvement in narcotics interception would cause fear for their own safety, that of their families and that of their fellow workers.
Telecommunications interception is of great assistance to the Australian Federal Police in the prevention and detection of drug offences.

However, the use of information obtained from the intercepted communications under warrant for the purpose of evidence in proceedings relating to a prosecution are not, in my view, in any way restricted to proceedings relating to a case involving narcotics. Section 7 sub-section (6) of the principal Act provides:

Without limiting the application of sub-section (4), a person may give information obtained by intercepting a communication passing over a telecommunications system, or obtained by virtue of a warrant issued under section 11 or 21, in evidence in a proceeding-
(a) by way of a prosecution for a narcotics offence--
that is conceded-
(b) by way of a prosecution for an offence against the Telecommunications Act 1975 or a regulation or by-law in force under that Act;

(c) by way of a prosecution for any other offence against the law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period, or maximum period, of not less than 3 years;
(d) by way of an application for an order under sub-section 243B (1) of the Customs Act 1901; or
(e) for the condemnation or recovery of a ship or aircraft, or of goods, seized under section 203 of the Customs Act 1901 in connection with the commission of a narcotics offence.

I put it to the Senate, with respect, that while section 20 grants power to a judge of the Federal Court of Australia or the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory, or judges who fall within the provisions of section 19, the power for the issue of a warrant on narcotics related offences in no way prevents the passing on of information as it relates to section 7 sub-section (6). It follows that all matters referred to in section 7 (6) may now be subject to a certificate issued by the Managing Director of Telecom and tendered in court as conclusive proof of the matter contained therein. Proposed new section 25A (2) states:

A document purporting to be a certificate issued under sub-section (1) and purporting to be signed by the Managing Director of the Commission shall be received in evidence in a proceeding of a kind referred to in sub-section 7 (6) without further proof and is, in that proceeding, conclusive evidence of the matters stated in the document.

References in the Minister's second reading speech and the attached explanatory memorandum relating exclusively to narcotics investigations are quite incorrect in my view or, to say the least, certainly misleading. This matter is not necessarily about narcotics. It covers the whole range of matters that are included under section 7 (6). A certificate will, as I say, relate to all offences falling within that section. Yet the Bill purports to apply only to narcotics. The amendments to section 25 are designed to protect the safety of Telecom employees when intercepting communications which may lead to a prosecution for offences relating to narcotics.

I turn to the fundamental objection which I have to this legislation; that is, the provision which allows the admission of a certificate in a criminal proceeding to be conclusive evidence. The document signed by the Managing Director of Telecom setting out such facts as the Managing Director considers relevant with respect to acts or things done by or in relation to officers of the Commission for the purpose of enabling a warrant to be executed shall be, of course, irrefutable, unchallengable and absolutely conclusive evidence in criminal proceedings. As the Law Council of Australia points out, this provision effectively silences an accused in respect of the matters which are the subject of a certificate and prevents any answer to the Managing Director's assertions of the facts. We are told by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that the matters which will be contained in the certificate are formal matters of evidence only and do not go to the issue before the court. On my-Senator Gareth Evans might think inadequate-reading of the legislation, that is not clear. Irrespective of that, I assert, to quote the Bill, that 'acts or things done by or in relation to officers of the Commission for the purpose of enabling a warrant' are matters which do go to the issues before the court.

I would have thought that a certificate would, at the very least, have to specify the time and the date of interception, together with the telephone numbers, presumably, from which the intercepted conversation took place. The defendant may wish to deny that the conversation took place on a certain number or he may rest part of his defence on the timing of the alleged conversation. These presumably are two basic facts that would be in the certificate. Under the provisions of this legislation he is denied the opportunity, and the certificate will be conclusive evidence of these matters. Perhaps a defendant may claim that the conversations are not complete and that therefore the contents of the conversation are distorted. He will apparently be denied that opportunity. If the certificate says that they are complete, again that will be deemed to be conclusive evidence.

As the Australian Law Council also points out, the provision has a potential operation limited only by the Managing Director's ingenuity in discerning what is 'relevant with respect to matters or things done by or in relation to officers of the Commission for the purpose of enabling a warrant issued under section 20 to be executed'. The example is given where an officer of the Commission transcribes a conversation intercepted pursuant to a warrant. The Managing Director could, under this provision, conclusively certify that transcript to be a true record of the conversation. I believe that the Law Council sums it up succinctly when it says:
It is no answer to this objection to say that this is an extreme example and that officers of the Commission would never be involved in recording or transcription.

That is a matter for which there is no satisfactory guarantee. That is an answer which can rest only upon the shifting sands of administrative arrangements. The subjective nature of 'such facts as the Managing Director considers relevant' confers upon the provision an unacceptable width that compounds the fundamental objection to its privative operation.

While I may well be alone not only in the Senate but also in the House of Representatives in expressing my concern at the proposed amendment to section 25, to the point that I am prepared to vote against the Bill, I note that my concern is shared by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which, when reporting on this Bill, said:

The Committee is concerned that in proceedings relating to serious criminal offences evidence should be able to be given by way of conclusive certificate. The Committee acknowledges the weight of the reasons advanced by the Attorney-General in his Second Reading Speech in support of the amendment, in particular the need to protect Telecom employees involved in narcotic interception from public identification because of fears for their safety and the safety of their families. However, the Committee draws the clause to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (i) in that by permitting the issuing of conclusive certificates in criminal proceedings it may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

I notice that the Committee seems, at least in my view, to be misled into the belief that the amendment will relate only to narcotics offences. That is the only conclusion I can draw from the fact that it states:
Such a certificate is to be conclusive evidence of the matters stated in the document in proceedings by way of prosecution for narcotics offences.
I suggest, as I did earlier in my speech, that that is a misunderstanding of the powers contained in the Bill.

I refer the Senate also to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs report of 1982 on the burden of proof in criminal proceedings. Of course, that was the reason I asked Senator Gareth Evans last week, by way of a question without notice, when we may have a definitive response from the Government to the conclusions and recommendations of that Committee. I am sure he does not need to be reminded that he was one of the principal architects of that document. Of course, the report essentially dealt with the onus of proof and did not deal with certificates being conclusive evidence. Had it done so, I am sure it would certainly have declined to give them status, and I am certain that Senator Evans would have been party to that conclusion. Averments were considered in the light of being at best prima facie evidence. In fact, the Committee report described the essence of an averment provision in modern legislation as a clause expressed in the following manner:
Every averment of the prosecutor or the plaintiff contained in the information shall be prima facie evidence of the matter averred.

It noted that prima facie evidence is what it refers to and not conclusive evidence. In addressing itself to suggestions for a form of increasing the use of the averment provisions, particularly in Commonwealth legislation, the Committee recommended:

The comparatively substantial increase in the number of averment provisions in recent years coupled with the potential for abuse by prosecutors has led us to the conclusion that there should be restrictions as to their use. While the Committee recognises that there is a legitimate need for such provisions, especially in circumstances where the prosecutor faces an insurmountable difficulty of proof, the inability of prosecutors in the past to use averments within reasonable limits is a matter of concern to us.
A further paragraph in the Committee's report expressed the view:
. . . that there is a pressing need for more objective criteria to limit the circumstances in which averments can be used.

The Committee referred with approval to the joint submission of the New South Wales Bar Association, the Law Society of New South Wales and the Sydney University Law Graduates Association, which all suggested that certain criteria should provide for averments to be relied upon by the prosecutor. It stated:

It should be a fundamental requirement before any use of an averment provision that the Crown must prove that the facts averred, if in truth they exist, are within the knowledge of the defendant or that the defendant has peculiar means of knowledge of the facts averred and that it is not reasonably practicable for the prosecutor to lead evidence to establish such matter.

The Committee also cited the first report of the Regulations Advisory Committee to the then Commonwealth Attorney-General on 15 July 1944, which recommended that averments should be resorted to in certain cases. It might be painful for me to read them but I would prefer to have this said than have it go past. The first case is where the matter which the prosecution is required to prove is formal only and does not in itself relate to any conduct on the part of the defendant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is not that the case?

—With respect, I suggest it is not just a formal matter, as I said from the outset. The time may come, as a result of administrative arrangements, when the person who intercepts the telephone call could also be transcribing the conversation, and that could be part of the certificate. I see there is disagreement with me--
—That would be a problem.

—Of course it would, but once it is admitted by way of a certificate, presumably it is irrefutable and unchallengeable in a court by way of a defence. The second case is where the matter in question relates to the conduct of the defendant alleged to constitute an ingredient in the offence charged. The third is where such matter is peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant. The fourth is where it is not reasonably practicable for the prosecutor to lead evidence to establish such a matter. They are the criteria that have been set down by the Committee in its report to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee recommended, firstly, that, as a matter of legislative policy, averment provisions should be kept to a minimum, and, secondly, that the Parliament should enact legislation to ensure that existing and future averment provisions are resorted to by prosecutors only in circumstances where the matter which the prosecution is required to prove is formal only and does not in itself relate to any conduct on the part of the defendant, or where the matter in question relates to the conduct of a defendant alleged to constitute an ingredient in the offence charged and is peculiarly within the defendant's knowledge. Clearly that does not prevail on this occasion. I suggest that the provisions of proposed new section 25A fail on every count and, in fact, constitute a circumstance which the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs would find totally unjustified.

If the Government is, as it says, intending by the proposed provision only to seek to protect the technicians of Telecom Australia who intercept such telephone calls in cases relating only to narcotics, I would have thought the provision would be restricted to such cases and, as has been pointed out by the Law Council of Australia, that the legislation which requires the court to suppress the names of the Telecom technicians could quite easily be put in place. There is nothing novel about that. There is nothing unique about such a course. It is a quite regular practice and, while protecting the witness, does not strike at a more fundamental right of law; that is, the right of a defendant to challenge evidence against him.

I conclude by reminding this Government, which in the past has seemed to have a preoccupation with international agreements-this applies particularly to the former Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans-of the terms of Articles 14 (2) and (14) (3) (e) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which have also been referred to by the Law Council of Australia. Article 14 (2) provides:
Everyone charged with a crime shall have the right to be presumed innocent until proved guilty according to law.
Nobody would dispute that as the first tenet.

TALK.START.PARA: —The golden thread.
—Absolutely. Article 14 (3) reads, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: In the determination of any criminal charge against him everyone shall be entitled to the following minimum guarantees in full equity:
(e) to examine, or to have examined, the witness against him and to obtain the attendance and examination of witnesses on his behalf under the same conditions as witnesses against him.

I would have thought that under those circumstances the proposed provision to which I have referred goes far beyond that which was intended by the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. It may well go beyond that which was intended by those looking at this legislation in the first place. I believe that it is excessive in terms of protecting Telecom technicians who are required to tap telephones. There are adequate safeguards and provisions to accommodate them without having legislation which stretches far past narcotics and covers a whole range of offences, at the same time making a provision which in many respects may well disadvantage the defendant in terms of the rebuttal of evidence against him. For that reason, although I will perhaps be a lone voice, I will be voting against this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although queries or objections have been raised to some clauses of these Bills, no difficulties have been expressed by anyone so far as the general policy innovations in them are concerned. Accordingly, I do not think it is necessary for me to track back over the general policy of the legislation. Those issues have been canvassed very well in the course of this debate. However, three specific matters have been raised by various honourable senators in the course of the second reading debate to which I believe it is necessary for me to respond.

SPEECH.PARA: The first is the Opposition's second reading motion amendment, moved by Senator Durack, which would commit the Senate to the opinion that the extension of telephone tapping powers to States in certain circumstances relating to narcotic offences is desirable. The Government will not oppose this amendment. It is consistent with the position taken by the Commonwealth at the drug summit in April and subsequently made the subject of a public statement in the communique following that summit, in which it was stated that the Commonwealth would extend telephone interception powers in the context of drug trafficking to the States, subject to stringent controls being exercised over their use. These controls will include the requirement for judicial warrants.

I note further in this respect that although the Law Reform Commission has recently expressed reservations about these matters in the context of its report on privacy, in its original report on criminal investigations in 1975 the Commission, of which I was then a member, gave some acknowledgment that it may be necessary in extreme circumstances to allow the States some powers in this area. The time has probably come to acknowledge that, although the Commonwealth Government is extremely concerned to ensure that very stringent controls are exercised over the use of any such powers.

I was asked by Senator Durack about the current state of play in relation to the States' response to the Commonwealth's legislative offer in this respect. The situation is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has written recently to the Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory indicating that the Commonwealth is prepared to extend telephone interception powers to State police in relation to drug trafficking. He sought confirmation as to whether or not the States in question wished to have access to those powers. He made it clear that any such access would be subject to acceptance by the States of strict controls. There have been some informal--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he not offer it to them at the summit itself?

—He did, but it was the subject of specific communications, made subsequently, setting out with rather more precision the terms and conditions under which the legislation would proceed. No formal reply has yet been received to that correspondence, which was some weeks ago, although there have been informal indications, some of them reported in the media, of willingness on the part of at least some States to take that up. That is something on which we will be happy to report further to the Senate, no doubt early in the Budget session, when the overall situation should be clear.

SPEECH.PARA: A second matter has caused some concern, particularly on the part of Senator Crichton-Browne-and it was an unusual treat to hear him tonight giving a speech in his civil libertarian mode. It was a speech which raised, very articulately, a concern which has been expressed in a number of quarters, not least of which is the Law Council of Australia in an extremely thorough submission that was tabled earlier this evening by Senator Haines. The Government has naturally given very careful consideration to the question of certification procedures of the kind set out in the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill, making it possible, in effect, for evidence to be led of the establishment of an intercept without the person who put the wires in place having to attend court to give oral evidence of that fact. Obviously, it does raise questions of the kind that Senator Crichton-Browne put in issue, and he and the Senate deserve a reply.

The basic point that we make-and we make it quite firmly-is that proof that a warrant was executed strictly in compliance with its terms is an essentially formal matter. In earlier court cases, there has been no requirement to prove compliance, but defence counsels seem to be now, as a matter of course, perhaps for want of other available weaponry, questioning that matter. Proving compliance by certificate, we believe, would not conflict with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which has taken the view, as Senator Crichton-Browne said, that Parliament should enact legislation to ensure that averment provisions are only resorted to by prosecutors where the matter which the prosecution is required to prove is formal only and does not relate in any direct way to any conduct on the part of the defendant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is not that only one of the recommendations that the Committee made? Did it not go on to say: 'When it is only within the knowledge of the defendant'?

—No, I think that the honourable senator is talking there in terms of reversal of the onus of proof and the circumstances in which it is appropriate to lay, in particular, an evidential burden on the defendant rather than the prosecution. As I recall it, the classic justification for averment provisions, or for certification provisions of the kind in issue here, is where the matter in issue is essentially formal. I think that the kind of example that was worrying Senator Crichton-Browne has to be addressed specifically, and that is the situation in which, for example, the defence wanted to put in issue the time at which a particular conversation occurred, and wanted, accordingly, quite reasonably, to be able to cross-examine the interceptor as to that possibly quite essential fact in the defence.

SPEECH.PARA: What I would say as to that is simply this: The person to be cross-examined in that respect is the police officer or group of officers who in fact were granted the warrant to intercept. The warrant to intercept is not granted to Telecom employees. They, essentially, are just facilitators of the interception process. They put the wires in place, as it were, to establish the intercept, but the actual listening, recording, transcription and giving of evidence about the content and timing of the intercept is done by other people, that is, police officers. They are the ones who are, quite properly, subject to cross-examination in circumstances of the kind that Senator Crichton-Browne has indicated. Certainly, I think there would be an unfairness were the defence to be denied access to that kind of opportunity to question the prosecution case.

We are really talking here essentially about proof of very formal matters. It is a track that one would not willingly go down were there not overriding reasons to do so. The overriding reasons in this case which we believe justify this kind of provision are those that have been mentioned by a number of speakers. It really is the only practical way to guarantee anonymity of Telecom employees. Certainly, we could have suppression orders in relation to their names but if we have them physically present in the witness box and if the concern is held, as I can assure Senator Crichton-Browne it is in fact, by the Telecom employees that they will be exposed to physical retaliation and physical danger by certain classes of defendants, that concern is not alleviated simply by issuing a suppression order in relation to publication of names. It is not an artificial worry that we are here talking about. I can assure Senator Crichton-Browne that it is felt acutely by Telecom employees. We just simply would not be ever able to get these intercepts into place were it not for this guarantee.

I was asked, I think, by Senator Haines, whether any alternative was ever considered to this averment certification procedure. The only real alternative, I suppose, has been the one that we have had to put very cumbrously and artificially into place in a number of prosecutions, certainly ones that I was mixed up in in the latter part of last year, in which it was necessary to have Attorney-General's affidavits and goodness knows what else testifying in effect to the court that it was a matter of public interest that particular evidence be suppressed and given in the form of affidavits without opportunity for cross-examination and without the physical presence of the Telecom employee. That is a most unsatisfactory course to follow on any regular basis. I simply assure the honourable senator that from my own personal experience I am quite sure that there is no practical alternative to the certification procedure that is here involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —How often do you anticipate that it will occur?
—I am not in a position to give that information even if it were appropriate to do so.
—To the nearest hundred a week will do.

—Senator Haines had better talk to Senator Chipp about that. He is one of the keener law and order advocates when it comes to dealing with potential drug traffickers and so on. There will have to be criteria satisfied. There will have to be warrants sought and issued by superior court judges in accordance with strict criteria. It is simply not possible to judge how many such cases there will be, but there will be enough to make it important that we devise some practical procedure which is workable in the real world and does not take account of the very real fears which exist. I believe, explaining as I have the practical way this proposal operates, that answers to some of the objections Senator Crichton-Browne and, for that matter, the Law Council of Australia have expressed can be better understood in that context.
—Is there going to be any way of finding out how often it occurs? Will there be some regular reporting on how often it occurs, such as annually, every parliamentary session or what?

—That is a matter for debate, I guess. It is one of the things that might usefully be dealt with by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority and by related legislation. It is something which the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs might well want to take up in terms of whether the annual reports, for example, of the Australian Federal Police, which are submitted to this Parliament through the Special Minister of State, should make some specific reference to this in the way that Australian Security Intelligence Organisation parliamentary reports are now increasingly doing. I believe that it may be possible to devise methods of that kind to get some sort of accountability in this area, but beyond that I am afraid I cannot be any more specific.

SPEECH.PARA: The final matter-I will deal with it very quickly because I wish to get this legislation through tonight if possible-is the matter raised by Senator Tate about the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill and, in particular, proposed new section 6 (7) of that Bill which, it has been suggested by the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, might amount to some kind of unacceptable ouster of the jurisdiction of the courts. Just for the record, that is not the Government's construction of this clause. We do not believe that it does anything remotely so dramatic.

The DPP Act does not purport to grant to the Director power to take any civil remedies not currently already within the competence of the Commonwealth. It does not give any new power; in effect it gathers together existing powers. The purpose of the proposed new section 6 (7) is to bring within the power of the Director all remedies available to the Commonwealth, as I have said, and to render nugatory attempts to challenge the power of the Director to bring proceedings simply because the DPP Act does not specifically confer upon him the requisite power. The Act does not purport to remove the right of any person to challenge proceedings on the ground that the Commonwealth itself does not have the requisite power. In simply terms what I am saying is that the provision guards against challenges on the basis that house keeping arrangements are not strictly in order. Substantive challenges-challenges with some merit-to the Commonwealth's powers are not removed by this section. I hope that assuages at least some of Senator Tate's concerns about the operation of that section. If it does not, it is too bad because time is getting on and it is time we got to the second reading vote.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, under standing order 168 I ask that my name be recorded as voting against the second reading motion.
—That request is in order. The name will be recorded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept and understand that a warrant is granted to police officers or Customs officers rather than Telecom Australia technicians. However, I do not accept that the matter is strictly formal. Presumable the minimum information in a certificate will be the two connecting telephone numbers; otherwise by and large the evidence will be of little virtue. In the event that the telephone numbers are material in the defence of the defendant I ask how that information can be challenged? Presumably a police officer, not being a technician, can only take it for granted that the telephone numbers connected by the technician are the ones the technician tells him. He does not have any firsthand knowledge. I ask why the Bill states that what shall be in the certificate is what the Managing Director considers relevant? Does that not necessarily mean that the whole gamut of evidence which might go beyond formality can be included or that, in fact, some matters which are relevant can be excluded? Finally, can a certificate issued by the Managing Director be used in cases other than narcotics related cases, as I would have read the Bill to mean?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter question, to the extent that evidence derived from a permissible narcotics tap can, in very limited circumstances, be used as evidence in the prosecution of other offences, to the extent that that is already part of the law then it would certainly be the case that the certification which is applicable to establish the credentials of the original tap would equally be applicable to such other use to which the material could legitimately be put.
—So it does cover a whole range of offences?

—My recollection of the terms of the Telecommunications Act is that an intercept can be granted only for a quite specific purpose. The police cannot go on some fishing expedition claiming artificially to be engaged in narcotics search.
—I accept that, but in the event-

—In the event that evidence turns up which does satisfy the other statutory criteria and is derived from the course of a permissible tap, then it can be used, and to that extent the certification process is as applicable to that use as it is to the original narcotics situation. The honourable senator might make what he may of that, but that is an objection to the terms of the legislation enabling lawful evidence so derived to be used on other matters. It is not any kind of additional ground of objection, as I would see it, to the certification procedure.
—I am just suggesting that it goes way past narcotics and covers a whole range of matters as described in the Bill.

—That is the situation under the telecommunications interception legislation in the very limited circumstance that one has a permissible narcotics tap on and evidence turns up which is probative of something else in accordance with the criteria in the legislation. That is a debate for another day on which opinions may well differ. I might well have some sneaking sympathy for the honourable senator's view on that matter but, with the utmost respect, it has got nothing whatsoever to do with the merits, the pros and cons, of this particular certification procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the first point the honourable senator made about the identity of a particular telephone connection possibly being a matter in issue, all I can say is that the certification will go to proof of the identity of the telephone number to which the wires were connected, but it will not go beyond that as to the content of the communications travelling backwards and forwards. If we are going to mount any kind of prosecution it will have to depend, obviously, on the content of that material. One would have thought that questions as to the identity of the participants in the transcribed conversations would be very much matters in issue on which it would be quite proper to cross-examine the police officer. Asking the police officer how one could be satisfied as to the identity of the callers would be one very obvious line of cross-examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to hold up the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans). I realise his anxiety because of the availability of time. Does the Minister accept that, under the present Act, there could be an administrative arrangement whereby the conversation so intercepted could be transcribed by a Telecom employee or a technician and then handed to the police? Is there anything to prevent that? In the event that that is the case, could that not also be contained in the certificate, which would then make it irrefutable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, it would in my mind not be within the terms of the warrant, which makes provision for the intercept to be done by a police officer rather than by someone else. One would really be exposing oneself to legal problems in the prosecution if it was done that way. Secondly, there would be an industrial explosion if Telecom employees were required to play that particular role rather than just bridging wires together, about which they are already not altogether happy and which is why we have got this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.TITLE: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 20 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say in relation to the answer just given by Senator Gareth Evans in relation to the ouster of the court's jurisdiction in clause 3 (3) of the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Bill 1985 that I believe that this is more than a housekeeping matter. There is an ousting of the jurisdiction of the court in the sense that once a civil remedy is instituted by the Director of Public Prosecutions the defendant has to deal with the pursuit of the civil remedy and cannot question the base provided by the legislation for the DPP undertaking that unusual function. In that respect, I do not think it is a simple housekeeping matter; it is a quite important ouster. I think it is justified but it was not adequately described in the explanation offered by Senator Gareth Evans.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, after clause 4, insert the following new clause:
Functions of Authority''4A. Section 11 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end of sub-section (1) the following word and paragraph:
'; and (e) as required, to co-ordinate its activities with the activities of authorities and persons in other countries performing functions similar to the functions of the Authority.'.''.

I do not propose to speak on this matter again at the Committee stage. I think its value is self-evident. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) indicated in another place that the Government was not opposed to it but he wanted some more time to think about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has until 3 o'clock on Friday, hasn't he?
—He has had plenty of time to think about it.

—I think we need a little more time to think about it. This is not something to which we are resolutely opposed, but the situation is this: The National Crime Authority has requested an amendment in similar terms; the matter has been under consideration by the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Australian Federal Police and everyone else's sisters, cousins and aunts. All their views have been sought on this matter. The Inter-Governmental Committee will consider the NCA's proposed amendment at its meeting tomorrow. This matter needs a degree of discussion as it has some international implications. The way in which it is cast has some potential implications, so I am advised by senior officers of the Attorney-General's Department, for the conduct of extradition arrangements, being an executive level arrangement embodied in legislation. These are only minor hiccups. It is anticipated that we will be able to introduce a clause in these or similar terms early in the Budget session as part of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, but we would appreciate the Senate-being a States' House, as we are constantly told by senators on the other side-giving the States the courtesy of considering this matter in the Inter-Governmental Committee tomorrow and possibly producing some variations to the language of it in order to deal with technical problems that may be involved.

—I indicated during the second reading debate that the Australian Democrats support the principle behind the Opposition's amendment. If Senator Durack is swayed by the Minister's argument, I will not be churlish about it. I will leave it up to my colleague.
—I do not see any reason why we should not pass this amendment at this stage. The Government has until Friday. It will be back here on Friday and it can deal with it then.

—Mr Chairman, may I ask Senator Durack, through you, whether the Joint Committee, which has the supervision of the National Crime Authority and which was instituted by the Parliament for this purpose, has been approached to give a view on whether this is a helpful extension of the terms of reference or the jurisdiction of the NCA? If not, perhaps we should also give it the courtesy of asking it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This happens to be a provision which was in the National Crimes Commission Act which was passed by this Parliament in 1982. I understand that Senator Tate supported it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Durack's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government-Melbourne Radio Station 3CR-Bulgaria-National Free Enterprise Limited

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of this adjournment debate to address the question of what is happening in the Australian Capital Territory in the run-up to self-government. I am sure that honourable senators opposite would love to stay in the chamber and listen while I give their Government a serve about what it is doing in the run-up to self-government. On 26 February this year the Minister for Territories, Mr Scholes, was supposed to speak to the Canberra Association for Regional Development. Unfortunately, he was unable to be present but his speech was delivered by the honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Kelly. She said for him:

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting, and sad, to note that the three major issues given insufficient emphasis during Canberra's initial planning-namely the administration of the Territory, financing of ACT development and effective representation of ACT community interests in the development of the Territory-are still the ones at the forefront of our concerns in 1985.
Later, Mrs Kelly said for the Minister:
The Commonwealth was currently wholly responsible for the ACT, through 12 Ministers, which made effective co-ordination difficult . . .
Later she said again, for the Minister:
It also makes an accurate picture of what is happening in the Territory almost impossible to obtain.
This was obviously quite a good speech as I have quoted so much of it. Mrs Kelly also said:
I consider that ACT matters do not receive their due attention because they are attached to nationally oriented departments . . .

Those are fine words. But what has happened? A picture is now emerging. We have had continued meddling by the 12 Federal Ministers in relation to the affairs of the Australian Capital Territory. There has yet to be consolidation of the Australian Capital Territory administration under one Minister or adequate representation of Australian Capital Territory community interests in the development of the Australian Capital Territory. About eight weeks ago, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), in the middle of a strike, abolished the Australian Capital Territory Health Commission. On 24 May he announced the proposed restructuring of the Commission. In other words, it took him about eight weeks after abolishing the Commission to make up his mind what he was going to do with the new Commission. When he announced this new restructuring he said:
The authority will remain responsible to the Minister for broad planning and administration of health service in the ACT.
Having imposed his philosophy on the Australian Capital Territory, he had the hide to say:
I believe this structure is sufficiently flexible that it could accommodate any changes that may result from a move to ACT self-government, without any major disruption.

We also have the proposed restructuring of the Schools Authority and the proposals for a national institute for tertiary education that will remove tertiary education from the responsibility of any self-governing legislature and establish yet another education bureaucracy. This afternoon, the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) argued, in answer to a question of mine, that the members of the House of Assembly elected by the Australian Capital Territory community to represent that community have the same opportunity as any other citizen to make a submission. The absurdity of that answer may have been lost on the Minister at the time but I hope that it will not be lost on the local community. It is entirely inappropriate that a Federal Minister for Education, charged with considerable responsibility of policy-making and administration of an Australia-wide portfolio, should be dabbling in local arrangements.

This Government is about to impose some form of self-government on the Australian Capital Territory without a referendum. That is the prerogative of the Government. But clearly, before it does so, a number of Ministers in this Government are determined to impose their political philosophies and their political appointees on the Australian Capital Territory before self-government. So the new Australian Capital Territory government, whatever may be its philosophies, will be locked in and obliged to suffer the burdens of these decisions from the grave, as it were. It reminds me of so many of my clients, when I was practising law, who wanted to control what their children and grandchildren were going to do for so many years after they had passed from the scene. That is what the Ministers of this Government are trying to do to the Australian Capital Territory. They talk about self-government and giving the people of the Australian Capital Territory some say in the administration of their affairs, but the Government wants to lock that administration into some long term arrangements which will continue long after it has abandoned responsibility for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Typical of socialist governments.

—Yes, I agree with my colleague Senator Rae; it is typical of socialist governments. The socialists always talk about these philosophies of freedom, access to government and freedom of information, and so on, when they are in opposition. As soon as they get into government they lock it all up behind the Caucus door, away from everyone, so that no one can even inspect what is happening, let alone find out anything at all about the responsibilities of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Major changes and major appointments have already been made in relation to these authorities. These authorities are not insignificant; they are of vital importance to the administration of the Australian Capital Territory. The National Capital Development Commission is not only an authority which plans the Australian Capital Territory but also a major building commission. Other authorities involved are the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. Still to come is social welfare planning, which is currently the subject of an interdepartmental committee studying the report of the Vinson Review of Australian Capital Territory Health and Welfare Services. That report offered a number of very expensive solutions.

Legislation to restructure the National Capital Development Commission has already passed through the House of Representatives and is listed for debate in the Senate. The White Committee of Review of the Role and Functions of the National Capital Development Commission recommended that there should be some nominees from the House of Assembly on the Commission, but this recommendation has been totally rejected by the Government. Let me quote from a letter I have received from the Conservation Council of the South East Region and Canberra (Inc), dated 28 May, commenting on the National Capital Development Commission Amendment Bill:

Our Council still supports most strongly the concept of a more open and accountable NCDC, but does not believe that this Bill answers the need at all. On the contrary, this Bill entrenches the very non-representativeness of the ACT for which it has been under frequent criticism over the years; it must thus be seen as regressive.

I could not agree more. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) announced on the 23rd of this month that he would take over the administration of more than 90 per cent of the Community Development Fund by transferring about $2.5m to a special territorial programs account over which the House of Assembly has no say. The House of Assembly has criticised this decision and the attempt of the Government to use the Community Development Fund to provide the equivalent to matching State funds in Federal-State dollar for dollar arrangements. An Australian Labor Party member of the House of Assembly, Ms Maureen Horder, speaking this morning on Radio 2CN about the Community Development Fund, accused the Minister of allowing non-accountable and dishonest administration of the fund. The leader of the ALP in the House of Assembly accused Mr Gordon Scholes of dishonest administration of the fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—That is right. As a member of the ALP she had some difficulty in blaming-
—The Minister?

—That is quite right. Ms Maureen Horder, the leader of the ALP in the House of Assembly, this morning on 2CN accused Mr Scholes of dishonestly administering the fund. At the beginning she had some difficulty in blaming the ALP Minister for Territories for what had happened in relation to the Fund, so what she did initially was to blame his departmental officers. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect it is a bit of the bureaucracy getting itself into a good position before self-government to make sure they still maintain control where they want to.
But even Ms Horder ultimately recognised ministerial responsibility when she said, referring again to the so-called bureaucracy:
They have obviously managed to get the Minister to agree--
one sees that she acknowledges that it is the Minister's responsibility-
to hiving that amount of money off for them to administer. Now I don't think that is efficient, effective nor honest or accountable administration of the fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honest?

—That is right. She used the words: 'It is not honest or accountable administration of the Fund'. I ask the Senate to think about what a terrible indictment that is of the Minister by Ms Horder. Then we have the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) apparently restricting overtime for Australian Capital Territory police to the quite obvious detriment of the local community. Does this mean that with self-government we will be told that the present contracted Australian Capital Territory establishment is adequate or that it will be the basis for Commonwealth Grants Commission consideration of the cost of policing the Australian Capital Territory?

SPEECH.PARA: The catalogue is almost endless, but I believe I have provided sufficient detail to alert the people of Canberra to the fact that they are being pre-empted on the size and shape of the bureaucracy they will inherit, a bureaucracy that once in place will be very difficult to dislodge and will largely reflect the philosophy of a government that uses Canberra as a social laboratory. It might also be totally unaffordable by the people of the Australian Capital Territory.

The House of Assembly is being largely ignored. One could almost say that it has been quarantined-by this Government. The Minister for Territories has told of the need for effective co-ordination and representation of community interests, the difficulties that 12 Ministers create, and the fact that it also makes an accurate picture of what is happening in the Territory almost impossible to obtain. These are the Minister's words:
It also makes an accurate picture of what is happening in the Territory almost impossible to obtain.
A good start would be to make one Minister responsible for all the Australian Capital Territory administrative functions during this transition period--

TALK.START.PARA: —One honest Minister.
—Yes, one honest Minister to ensure that the community's interests are properly served.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to raise the question of Melbourne radio station 3CR. The matter has been raised politically on other occasions and criticism has been levelled at that organisation. I must say that I have never joined in that criticism because I believe in having a diversity in the media and that all groups, no matter how iconoclastic or radical they may be, should be able to express their opinions wherever they like. I have always regarded 3CR with a sort of bemused tolerance. I turn it on once a week, hear myself get a big spray, and enjoy it enormously. However, I do believe that recently 3CR has been acting very much against any concept of a pluralist society in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise the case of a Mr Terry Muscat, who is of Maltese origin. Mr Muscat runs a program called the 'Western Region Maltese Community Show' on radio 3CR. He has run that show for a long while and has given many people much enjoyment. Recently, he has come under investigation for being too right wing. There are moves to remove him from that radio station, not because of his specific views but simply because he happens to be a member of a trade union which is regarded as right wing. That is the reason why efforts are being made to exclude him from the radio show. I have a document before me in which the station reports back and states that a meeting will be held on 19 June. A whole series of statements are made, none interconnecting, all leading one to the conclusion that this document is about as McCarthyist as any document produced by anyone in the Right. I know Mr Muscat. I do not know whether he is a right winger or not. He has been a member of the Australian Labor Party for 15 years. Apparently that qualifies him as being too far off to the right for radio 3CR.

I do not mind how radical radio 3CR is. I enjoy the concrete gang show when the Builders Labourers Federation boys get on and give everyone a bagging. It is great entertainment. I enjoy listening to some of the other ethnic radio programs and political views. I do not enjoy it when it becomes anti-Semitic as it occasionally has. Whenever this radio station has dipped into the public purse, as it has under different community employment program schemes, et cetera, I have thought that surely the radicals and the minorities in this community deserve to have their own voice. I think that is true. But they will have to come to understand that, if they want a radio licence, it is not good enough for them to say that they are going to kick off a radio show someone who is presenting an ordinary ethnic show because he happens to be a member of a union that they classify as right wing. The document states:
There is no suggestion that the affiliate--
that is, this particular radio show-
has, in regard to CRF, its objectives and guidelines, acted in any way unbecoming of a Member or prejudicial to the interests of CRF. There is no question of a breach of these requirements.

Consequently, due to the past and present policies of the FIA not being consistent with the aims and aspirations of CRF and its affiliates, the 3CR Committee expresses its concern over Mr T. Muscat-an official of the FIA-representing the 'Western Region Maltese Community Council' at CRF meetings and requests that Mr T. Muscat stand down as affiliate representative.

I might even accept this if someone has pointed to any particular program that he did not like or had isolated some of the views of this individual and said: 'This person is not acceptable because of the views he is putting over the program'. But, no, this person is convicted, and expelled from this radio station presumably, solely on his membership of a union and allegations that that union is right wing and may have connections with the National Civic Council or some other organisation. There is no specific allegations made against Mr Muscat. There is no recognition that he has been a member of the Australian Labor Party for 15 years. No doubt some of the galahs who are trying to put him off the air have been members for three or four years of the Labor Party or other leftist organisations.

In summary, I just say that I have never before criticised radio 3CR. I am not going to jump on some right wing band wagon and say that we should take the licence from it. Let us be realistic. Silver Top Taxis' radio cabs have a larger radio audience than 3CR. If people want to use the station as their toy and want to be able to use government money to prop it up, I would encourage that; it is diversity and pluralism in our society. But to run this sort of witch hunt against Mr Muscat, simply because he happens to be a member or an official of a particular union, is absolutely disgraceful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the opportunity of the adjournment debate to raise what I believe is a matter of considerable importance. The adjournment debate is an opportunity for us to talk about issues which are not immediate and urgent importance domestically but are of importance internationally. The matter that I wish to raise is the situation of ethnic Turks in Bulgaria. Bulgaria is a country which I believe has displayed an affiliation for hard line communism and for being a Russian stool-pigeon more than any other country of which I am aware. I find that what is being done to the Turkish population of Bulgaria is something which is not within the realms of reason, within the realms of tolerability, so far as international relations are concerned, let alone what human rights require.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that upset me is that there is a tendency for us to be a little selective about what human rights issues we raise and what human rights issues we do not raise in this place. Within the past 12 months, I have joined in pursuing human rights issues in Iran, Chile and a number of other countries. I now wish to add Bulgaria to that list. I wish to quote from a letter which I have received from the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) dated 20 May 1985 in which the Minister has given me an answer to a question on the position of ethnic Turks in Bulgaria and what is being done to them. After reading part of what is contained in that letter I will make some comments. The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs said:

The Government has been closely monitoring the situation through its embassies in the region. In addition, detailed information similar to that which you have received was in February provided to Departments in Canberra by a delegation from the Bulgarian-Turkish association.
The Government does not accept the Claim made by the Bulgarian authorities--
I pause to emphasise that the Government does not accept the claim made by the Bulgarian Government, not the Bulgarian-Turkish Association of Australia-

that such acts of Bulgarianisation as the changing of individuals' names are 'spontaneous and voluntary'. It entertains few doubts that the Turkish minority is being subjected to the denial of its cultural rights in the most crude form, and that the Bulgarian Government's aim is to strip it of its ethnic identity. The present repression is an intensification of a long-standing campaign which contravenes not only normally accepted standards of human rights, but provisions of a number of UN Human Rights instruments to which Bulgaria is a party.

The Australian Ambassador to Bulgaria has expressed Australia's concern to the Bulgarian Government. We will continue to monitor the situation and will make further representations as appropriate. Moreover, should the government assess that to do so would assist the victims of such violations, it will consider raising the matter in appropriate United Nations' bodies in line with its policy of condemning human rights violations wherever they might occur.

Having quoted that letter I go back to these words: 'The present repression is an intensification of a long-standing campaign which contravenes not only normally accepted standards of human rights, but provisions of a number of UN Human Rights instruments to which Bulgaria is a party'. I ask this Government not just simply to say that it is concerned but to take action a little more positively, as it has indicated it is prepared to do. I believe that the Senate should tonight, by accepting the comments which I make, acknowledge that the position of the Turks in Bulgaria is intolerable, that the Bulgarian authorities have engaged in a campaign of Bulgarianisation, which includes forcing people to change their names, which includes forcing people to change their whole cultural background, which includes penalising people and which includes the repression of individual rights and civil liberties in a way which is intolerable in any society which we would regard as being an acceptable member of the world community. I ask honourable senators to join with me in asking the Government to make the representations which the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs said would be made in the appropriate United Nations bodies, to condemn the human rights violations which are at this stage occurring in Bulgaria.

If no one speaks to oppose what I have just said, I will take it that the Senate accepts the points I have made and which have also been made by the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, and which I endorse and support. I believe we should take stronger action than we have already taken. I simply ask that the Senate adopt that attitude, that unless someone opposes it, we take it from this chamber that we would like Australia to voice its concern in the United Nations in relation to Bulgaria much more strongly than it has so far; in other words, that we take up the offer which the Government has made that we will condemn human rights violations wherever they may occur, including those at the moment occurring in Bulgaria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —During my short time in this place I have heard a number of references by my National Party colleagues opposite to the Australian Council of Trade Unions being the non-elected government of Australia. This evening I rise to talk about National Free Enterprise Ltd which is, of course, the non-elected government of Queensland. In 1983 the Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform investigated a number of matters pertaining to elections and election funding and provided a very comprehensive report, parts of which were later enacted into law. Section 305 of the Electoral Act provides that any person-that includes a company-which incurs expenditure for a political purpose is only required to reveal donations received in an election period; that is, from the issue of writs to the polling date. It is by using this section that the Queensland National Party hopes to dodge its responsibilities under the electoral legislation and escape the full force of the law.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish just briefly to outline the circumstances leading up to this rort. Last August/September, following the presentation of the Federal Budget, there was a lot of speculation about an early Federal election. During that period, on 27th September 1984, a company called National Free Enterprise Ltd was incorporated, with its registered office given as Cleary and Hoare, a firm of Brisbane solicitors which also acts for the Kern Corporation Ltd. One of the partners in this firm, Mr J. Hoare, is reported to be a member of the management committee of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Black has placed on the Notice Paper a notice of motion which relates to the matter he is now addressing. I believe that it is in breach of the Standing Orders for him to be making the speech he is making.
—What about human rights violations in Queensland?

—I condemn human rights violations in Queensland as much as I condemn them in Bulgaria. Senator Ray will remember that when Senator Georges had some problems I made a suggestion to him as to the authorities he could cite to assist him in his application for bail so that he could attend to his duties in the Senate. Let us be fair, please. I want us to be fair in another way.
—I hope it works tomorrow.

—I make no comment. I did not notice that Senator Georges was here. I simply make the point that Senator Black is anticipating debate which is the subject of a notice on the Notice Paper and, what is more, he is doing so without having given notice to the people who may be affected. Mr President, it is not only contrary to the Standing Orders but it is also contrary to what ought to be regarded as reasonably civilised behaviour in this place for somebody to raise a matter without giving notice to the other side that he intends to attack the personal probity of individuals associated with the chamber. My point of order is that, on two grounds-the first ground being that it is contrary to the Standing Orders and the second ground being that it is contrary to the practice of the place-it is not in order for Senator Black to continue the comments which he has been making.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. It is my understanding that Senator Black, probably knowing the Standing Orders as well as my namesake, took action some days ago to pull his notice of motion off the Notice Paper. I notice that Senator Peter Rae has not referred to today's Notice Paper. Does he want to nominate which page the notice of motion is on? It is not there. Therefore, Mr President, you should rule out the point of order.

—Order! I do not uphold the point of order. The existence of notices of motion has never been taken, in my experience in the Senate, to restrict debates on the adjournment, or indeed on the first reading of Bills. Senator Rae has related his remarks to the subject of anticipated debates but, as I have said, it has been common practice not to so restrict first reading or adjournment debates. Otherwise, in my opinion, the rule would mean that notices of motion on the Notice Paper, put on by anyone, would blanket out general discussion by the Senate on those items. That, in my opinion, has never been the intention of the Senate. For that reason, I do not uphold the point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. The matter has been withdrawn from the Notice Paper; I am in the process of drawing up a much more comprehensive proposal to put before the Senate at a later date. As I was saying earlier, one of the partners in this firm, Cleary and Hoare, is a member of the Management Committee of the National Party. The other partner, Don Cleary, is a member of the Queensland Harness Racing Board and the Racing Appeals Tribunal, and, as such, would be an acquaintance of the Racing Minister in Queensland, Mr Russ Hinze.

SPEECH.PARA: The objects of National Free Enterprise include the promotion of democracy, liberty and free enterprise in Queensland and Australia. Also among its objects are the solicitation of donations from supporters and the making of donations for patriotic or charitable purposes. This latter clause is included, word for word, in the memorandum of association of another company which I will discuss later. National Free Enterprise is empowered to do big business-for example, to buy, sell, deal and lease in all kinds of apparatus and real estate, to enter into arrangements with governments and so on. Those who drew up the articles of association for National Free Enterprise have made sure that their creation will not turn into a political alternative to the National Party. The articles provide that the company will not promote the election to the Commonwealth Parliament of any candidate endorsed by itself. It can be easily seen from these and other company guidelines that the company was set up specifically to pass on money to the National Party and to individual candidates.

On the board of this company is a very interesting group of people. It reads like a Who's Who of big business in Queensland. We have Leonard Knevitt, Chairman of Evans Deakin Industries Ltd, and a member of the board of the Bank of Queensland; David Tennent, an engineer and director of Evans Deakin; Sir Earnest Savage, a National Party member, a director of both Queensland Cement and Lime Co. Ltd and Permanent Finance Corporation Ltd-
A quorum having been called and the bells being rung-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. Is it in order for National Party senators to be standing outside while the quorum is being counted?
—There is no point of order.
—Order! The bells having been run for three minutes and there being no quorum present, the Senate stands adjourned until 10 a.m. tomorrow. The names of those present will be recorded by the Clerk.
