QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which New South Wales District Court judges have presided over Federal matters and offences since 1 July 1983.
(2) How many cases has each such judge heard.
(3) How many appeals have been lodged from judgments in respect of each judge.
(4) How many of the appeals have been upheld in respect of each judge.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I have assumed that the information sought relates to civil actions in the District Court in which the Commonwealth was a party or to prosecutions for offences under Commonwealth law. The records of my Department are not in a form which would enable the requested information to be readily obtained. It would be necessary for individual files and other records to be checked and for inquiries to be made both within a number of different areas of my Department and outside it to obtain the information. In these circumstances I am not prepared to authorise the diversion of staff resources from the performance of its other functions to the obtaining of the requested information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Resources and Energy provide answers to Questions on Notice No. 1057 (Notice given 22 August 1984) and Nos 1123 to 1127 (Notice given 7 September 1984), relating to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, Lucas Heights, New South Wales.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Childs asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 22 August 1984:

(1) Is there any particular reason why the Australian Atomic Energy Commission took 3 weeks to establish the Committee to examine the accidental release of uranium hexafluoride at the AAEC Research Establishment.
(2) Was the Committee established at the instigation or direction of the Minister for Resources and Energy.
(3) Was there any reason why the 5 members of the Committee were all drawn from within the AAEC.
(4) Is there any reason why representatives of the following bodies should not have been included on the Committee:
(a) Energy Authority of New South Wales;
(b) New South Wales Department of Health;
(c) Australian Safeguards Office;
(d) State Pollution Control Commission (New South Wales);
(e) Office of the Minister for Resources and Energy;
(f) Sutherland Shire Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This question implies that nothing happened in the period between 6 July when the accidental release of uranium hexafluoride occurred and 25 July when the Committee was established to examine this matter. In fact several actions were set in train immediately, including
a program to assess any possible health effects on staff
an environmental monitoring program initiated to assess any possible off-site effects
measurements of air-flow through the ducting to assess actual ventilation air-flows at the time of release
decontamination of the laboratory
reporting of an accidental loss of uranium hexafluoride to the Australian Safeguards Office in the context of Australia's obligations under the NPT
notifying the relevant Commonwealth and State authorities
However, once the wide nature of the enquiries became apparent, a Committee was set up on 25 July 1984 by the Acting Director of the AAEC Research Establishment to co-ordinate the investigation.

(3) and (4) Since the incident had negligible consequences for members of the public or the environment outside the boundary of the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories, it was appropriate that the Committee be drawn from AAEC officers. All the required expertise was available from AAEC resources.
Senator Childs asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 7 September 1984:

(1) Was it revealed in the 1981 Environment Survey Report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment, Lucas Heights, that Plutonium 239 and Plutonium 241 were present in the Little Forest Low Level Waste Burial Ground.
(2) Was the plutonium derived from reactor/fuel rods; if so, how; if not, what was the origin of this plutonium.
(3) Was this plutonium from the Maralinga Weapons Testing Program.
(4) What are the relative isotopic abundancies of Plutonium 239 and 240 in this material.
(5) What attempt is being made to identify both the quantity and exact location of this plutonium.
(6) What does the Commission plan to do to remove it from this site which is outside the exclusion zone and into the residential area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The minute amount of plutonium contaminated waste in the Little Forest Burial Ground originated from Plutonium which was imported by the AAEC from the United States in the period 1963-66 for research into the feasibility of a high temperature gas cooled reactor.
(4) Approximately 91 per cent Pu239, 8 per cent Pu240 and 1 per cent Pu241.
(5) The quantity of plutonium in the Little Forest Burial Ground is estimated to be approximately 7 grams. Records of the location of the material are held by the AAEC.

(6) The Little Forest Burial Ground is located on AAEC owned and managed land contiguous with the 1.6 km buffer zone around the reactor HIFAR. Because of the small quantity involved the plutonium does not represent a public health risk and there are no plans to remove it.
Senator Childs asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 7 September 1984:

(1) Did the 1981 Environment Survey Report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment, Lucas Heights, reveal that Strontium 90 was present in the water and sand in the Woronora River, upstream of Lucas Heights and at the point of the Lucas Heights drainage entrance.
(2) is this the first time Strontium 90 has been reported since 1970.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) No. Data on the presence of traces of strontium 90 in various environmental samples were reported in the AAEC Environmental Survey Reports for 1973, 1974 and 1980.
Senator Childs asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 7 September 1984:
(1) Did the tests conducted for the 1982 Environment Survey Report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment (published 1984) reveal much higher readings than earlier reports.
(2) Were there tests done by the Australian Radiation Laboratory, whereas previous analysis was done by the AAEC.
(3) Are duplicates of the 1982 samples to be sent to New Zealand for further tests.
(4) Will a copy of the results be made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) Analyses of the 1982 samples for the presence of strontium 90 in the Woronora River water and sand both upstream and downstream of the AAEC Research Establishment were initially carried out by the Australian Radiation Laboratory. The results appeared to show significantly higher concentrations than in previous years, particularly in sand samples. Subsequently the New Zealand National Radiation Laboratory was asked to test duplicates of the 1982 sand samples. The NZNRL results were closer to the AAEC results for 1981 samples, being in fact somewhat lower.

In looking at these variations it should be noted that the amounts of strontium 90 detected were very low, and near to the lower limits of detection. ARL advised that the levels of strontium 90 measured in the sand samples were similar to those found throughout Australia in undisturbed soil. These levels can be attributed to global fallout from atmospheric nuclear weapons testing over the years.

Senator Childs asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 7 September 1984:

(1) Will the Minister for Resources and Energy advise, in view of the concern over the adequacy of the environmental sampling by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission following the publishing of the 1982 Establishment Survey Report of the AAEC Research Establishment, whether the published records are complete.
(2) Are the environmental reports selective.
(3) Could a complete list of all monitoring equipment be supplied.
(4) Is the monitoring of discharges done 24 hours per day.
(5) How sensitive is the equipment.
(6) How adequate is monitoring to pick up, for example, Strontium 90 discharges.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The published records are complete. I am not aware of any concerns expressed by official bodies concerning the adequacy of the environmental monitoring program at the AAEC Research Establishment.

(3) A wide range of environmental monitoring equipment is used consistent with the different monitoring methods indicated in the AAEC Environmental Survey Reports. If further details of the monitoring equipment and methods are required, these may be obtained from the AAEC.
(4) Yes.

(5) In all cases, the sensitivity of the monitoring methods allows the detection of less than 5 per cent of the effective dose equivalent recommended by the International Commission on Radiological Protection and the National Health and Medical Research Council as being acceptable for continuous exposure by members of the general public.
(6) The environmental monitoring program at the AAEC Research Establishment encompasses the potential releases of all radionuclides.
Senator Childs asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 7 September 1984:

(1) Do the environmental surveys, at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment, Lucas Heights, show differing levels of radioactive substances being released into the Woronora River.
(2) Is there any formal agreement with the State Government to accept gaseous waste/discharges; if so, what date was this agreement made; if not, under what authority are such discharges made.
(3) Is there any plan to fund adequate independent environmental monitoring of the AAEC Establishment at Lucas Heights and; if so, what form would this monitoring take.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. Airborne effluents discharged from the main stacks at the AAEC Research Establishment are subject to a quarterly authorisation made under Regulation 13 (2) of the NSW Radioactive Substances Regulations. The authorisation was approved by the NSW Department of Health through the NSW Radiological Advisory Council in 1969.

(3) The NSW authorities currently conduct independent monitoring of the airborne and liquid effluent discharges from the AAEC Research Establishment to verify compliance by the AAEC with the State regulatory requirements. There are no plans to fund any additional monitoring activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the situation regarding staff employed by the National Aboriginal Conference now that funding of the NAC has been withdrawn?

(2) Have some NAC staff members been notified that they were overpaid during the 1983-84 and 1984-85 financial years; if so, have they been advised that the overpayment will be recovered at a rate of not less than 20 per cent of their gross fortnightly salary.
(3) If NAC staff are not currently receiving their salaries because of the funding cuts, are they still expected to make the payments referred to in (2) above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Funding for the NAC has not been withdrawn. Therefore the situation regarding staff employed by them remains unchanged and all staff are still receiving fortnightly pay in the normal manner.

(2) Yes, some staff have been notified that they were overpaid in 1983-84 and 1984-85 financial years and have been advised that overpayments will be recovered. However, no staff so affected have been advised that overpayments will be recovered at a rate of not less than 20 per cent of their gross fortnightly salary.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 April 1985 (Hansard, page 1356), Senator Hearn asked me a question without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate, concerning the Government's attitude to a national forest policy in the light of 1985 being declared the International Year of the Forest and opportunities for training/employment.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

The FAO Council, in declaring 1985 the 'International Year of the Forest', urged member nations to consider conservation of their respective forest resources as a matter of national and global concern, and to heighten public awareness of the threats posed by acid rain, air pollution and extensive clearance of tropical forests.

The Australian Forestry Council, which is the national forestry policy instrumentality, chaired by the Minister for Primary Industry, has released a draft National Forest Strategy for public comment. The Strategy aims to set out the basic principles and objectives for management of Australia's forest resources. Nationally, such objectives include reforestation and land rehabilitation through forestry. Wide public acceptance of the Strategy, which emphasises the need for consultation and co-ordination between Federal and State authorities on land use issues, should assist in achieving those objectives.

As far as capitalising on opportunities for training-employment is concerned the State Forestry Services have taken advantage of the Commonwealth Employment Program and Wage Pause funds to implement forestry planting and maintenance activities which would not have been possible otherwise. The Minister for Primary Industry will continue to seek ways of directing such funds to forestry projects and of implementing a reforestation program when economic circumstances permit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 March 1985 (Hansard, page 566) Senator Chipp asked me, as Minister representing the Attorney-General, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: What is the Attorney-General's response to today's very serious allegations on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program AM by journalist Bob Bottom that a senior politician in New South Wales has had access to the so-called Age tapes for several years and had actually used some of the material on them to prevent an embarrassing court action involving himself? Why is the Attorney-General so reluctant to facilitate the passing of the vital information on these tapes to the National Crime Authority by granting indemnities to the 31 policemen involved, just as the Stewart Royal Commission Inquiry into Drug Trafficking recommended . . . ?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

(a) I replied to the allegations made by Mr Bottom on the AM program of 21 March 1985. As I said at that time no assessment could be made of the allegations without further details being provided by Mr Bottom to Mr Justice Stewart. Mr Bottom gave no evidence or particular information of involvement of a senior politician.

(b) The decision to facilitate the granting of indemnities to New South Wales policemen involved in illegal interception of telephone calls required the balancing of concerns to pursue the prosecution of criminals with the need to ensure that police do not break the law and the real requirement that individual privacy be protected. By amending the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission and the provision of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 the Government has now opened the way for Mr Justice Stewart to recommend the grant of indemnities in appropriate circumstances as set out in the Letters Patent issued on 29 March 1985.
Both Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby have indicated that, even if 'the Age' materials are authenticated, they are unlikely to lead to criminal prosecutions.
